item.name: 1960: The Making of the President
item.comment:
A great shorter implementation of Twilight. I think it has a perfect theme as politics is really much akin to war.
Update:
Many have commented that this game is inferior to it's original due to some "tug of war" that occurs over given territories.
I'm confused why someone would allow themselves to be sucked into a fruitless contest such as this rather than focus efforts elsewhere. I'm of the opinion that this is an artifact of group think.

item.name: The 3 Commandments
item.comment:
Certainly this game will not appeal to everyone. It even takes a few plays before you know the types of things you have to do to get points. Further, it helps knowing your fellow players well so when they have their turn as high priestess you can have a inkling as to their possible choices.
Update:
With newer releases for larger groups, this game has lost most of what was appealing. That doesn't mean I will get rid of it, nor does it mean that it's a bad game; it has just been eclipsed by designs that have more creative freedom, more interaction between all players, or a shorter play time.

item.name: 51st State
item.comment:
While some would compare this to RftG, the only points in common are the wealth of symbols to learn the meaning of, and decipher the best decisions to make with the actions available.
This game is hand management, tableau building, worker placement, and an agonizing choice mechanism that really boils down to three primary actions.
Difficult to learn, even more difficult to master, but a joy to play.
Update:
Rating downgraded thanks to New Era.
item.wishlistcomment:
Hope for import, must have.
Ordered on Funagain.

item.name: 6 nimmt!
item.comment: I love it and have the jubilee edition....Enough variants availbe for this game to choke a donkey! It can even be used to play so many other games.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
4 plays with 5, 6, 7.
I have to start off by saying that I don't think that I care for this game with 6 or 7 at all. It simply takes most players too long to make their decisions for a game this light.
I've said it before and I'll say it again; this is an upgraded Fairy Tale and that's a high compliment in my world.
A game like this should be played fast and dirty. You can always play again or even several times in a row.
Update:
More plays and I'm still interested in exploring the game space more. There certainly are strategies at hand here. We always make sure that the purple/bonus cards that are being used are fully revealed and explained to allow for some long term strategy and planning.
My only real frustration is that often you lose by mere points through no fault of your own. It's still short, fast, and interesting. Certainly a fine replacement for Fairy Tale of which we have played far too much.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Cities
item.comment: It's certainly not the game changer that Leaders was, but it does add something noticible to the game. It's just a splash, and certainly you might as well use it as it serves to further break up the pattern of previous strategies.

item.name: Above and Below
item.comment:
If this game were just worker placement, it would be mediocre at best. However, it's the storytelling that really sells the system. While it's not as deep in terms of choices in a game like Arabian or Smersh, it does require some risk to get your rewards, which makes you play differently and choose what you build differently.
Of course, it also has Ryan's amazing art, which is always easy on the eyes.

item.name: Ad Astra
item.comment:
Don't let others fool you:
This isn't Settlers even though you gather resources and spend them in a similar manner.
This isn't Race just because there's roles for action selection.
The way that this game uses a chart of 12-15 action cards (3-4 per player based on number of players), executing them in order yet applied to the queue by player choice, is a crucial element that changes the entire formula. Given that phases can happen multiple times during a round makes the strategy of the order of your own actions coupled with the guessing game of what others will do even more tense and engaging.
First play was almost 2 hours including explanation. This one needs a much better player aid than what was provided to lower the boundary to entry.
Solid and worth playing again; certainly a 60 minute game AT BEST.

item.name: Advanced Civilization
item.comment: Definately the grandpa of most things I have played. Too bad once someone gets a lead it's hard to catch them.

item.name: Age of Conan: The Strategy Board Game
item.comment:
As long as we can bring this one down in play time, I'm certain I can continue to have the love affair I enjoy with it. I can certainly say that it didn't feel 3.5 hours long, and it was totally engaging. There are some possibilities for AP issues, as well as "dud" turns where there are no dice that are worthwhile for you to use, in a way; though this is exceptionally rare and minor.
I love that like Cleopatra, there is a total loss condition in the game. I also like that you have the option for playing against the game and/or the other players. I wish the objectives had slightly higher values to make non combat options more viable, but I supposed since it's a Conan game, it makes sense for it to be about fighting.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment:
This is by far the best design to come out of the "Drover" line.
The board is a bit too large, but then again, presentation does make this game stand out.
Fantastic bits, wonderfully clear rules (they give a brief overview then a detailed description, and even have an advanced variant for starting position), and a collection of familiar mechanics masterfully blended into what makes a fantastic game.
So many avenues to victory, and a wealth of synergy makes this one almost a 10...but more plays will prove that.
Update:
This one settles at a solid 7. In time other designs have appeared which do similar things either better or in a shorter play time. This game still does some unique things on it's own and the worker placement style is still not totally usurped. It certainly retains it's spot in my collection.

item.name: Age of Industry
item.comment:
Welcome to a world that is a more straight forward, simpler, Brass.
The choices are simpler. That makes the game tighter.
The choices are still not obvious. That makes it an equally challenging, yet fairly different experience.
I'm curious as to how this will play with 5. If it delivers with 5 like it did with 3 then this is my go-to Brass for 5. I'm fairly certain that with a more hardcore group, and of course 3-4 players, I would still prefer the more harsh and unforgiving original formula.
First play was with 3, second with 4. It seems the more the merrier, however I still have to play with 5.
Further, I have now played with both sides of the board and found both wonderfully different and worthwhile. I think the German side is more like Brass sans ships while the New England side is more game changing, especially with respect to coal.
People have stated that rails are less important. I whole heartedly disagree.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment:
Even better than I had expected. 1 play = 9, after subsequent plays I am thinking more of a 9.5 or 10.
After repeated plays it's definately a solid 9, though I tend to think it deserves higher; however, it is such a gamer's game that it might not ever make it to a 10.
Update: Yep, I was right. Make it a 10.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion #1: England & Ireland
Age of Steam Expansion #2: Western US and Germany
Age of Steam Expansion #3: Scandinavia and Korea
Age of Steam Expansion #4: France and Italy
Age of Steam Expansion: 1830's Pennsylvania / Northern California
Age of Steam Expansion: 1867 Georgia Reconstruction, South Carolina & Oklahoma Land Rush
Age of Steam Expansion: Alabama Railways, Antebellum Louisiana & Four Corners
Age of Steam Expansion: America / Europe
Age of Steam Expansion: Atlantis & Trisland
item.comment:
Rating is because of Atlantis.
The Atlantis map intentionally makes the game so hard that it's no fun. You struggle against the system and not the other players.
I wish there were something on the other side of the Triland map to make this worth the money.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Austria & India
Age of Steam Expansion: Barbados / St. Lucia
Age of Steam Expansion: China / South America
Age of Steam Expansion: Disco Inferno / Soul Train
Age of Steam Expansion: Germany & France
Age of Steam Expansion: Jamaica / Puerto Rico
Age of Steam Expansion: Mexico, Spain/Portugal
item.comment: Played Mexico.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: North Eastern USA / South Africa
Age of Steam Expansion: Vermont, New Hampshire & Central New England
Agents of SMERSH
item.comment:
If you've ever played Arabian Nights, you ALMOST know what to expect. However, there are far more decision points; in fact there are actually some, enough so that this feels like a game rather than just an experience.
The WW2 era spy theme oozes throughout, the stories are captivating, and you don't even care whether you win or lose, it's just that fun.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Think of it as Harvest Moon the board game with 3 levels of complexity, and a ridiculous of occupations (other than just being a farmer).
I say complexity, but the game does not get more complex with the I deck (and I doubt with the k either), and only serves to make it a deeper, richer experience. Also note that the change of deck type also does not lengthen the game.
It does play in about 30 minutes per player, and feels only a fraction of that. This game is simply brilliant.
item.conditiontext:
Update:
My rating is based on 3 plays, and the opinions of everyone else who played it at my house recently. Everyone loves it, and thinks as highly of it as any other game they might call their favorite. Many even said they prefer it to Power Grid or Puerto Rico. I personally simply make it a 10, as it's complexity, diversity, synergy based gameplay, and incredible tension make for one of the best games I have ever played. It's already been requested for our next session. I'm even buying an english copy....and when I let that cat out of the bag everyone discussed being able to play to games at once!!! The proof's in the pudding.\
Update: Now at 11 plays...long past when "hype" would spur me on. I've played with all three decks multiple times, and I think I is my favorite, though now I would play with any of the three.
20 plays. Believe the hype.
Over 50 plays, still loving it. Still finding new ways to play.

item.name: Agricola: Farmers of the Moor
item.comment:
Gives the base game all new legs (as if it needed them), adds another layer of complexity and shakes up the turn order quite a bit.
Not something I would play all of the time, but will see play semi regularly.

item.name: Aladdin's Dragons
item.comment:
Not as good a Ys.....Ys is the next step in Aladdin's evolution. Too bad I played Ys first.
Update: Much better played with the magic version.

item.name: Albion
item.comment:
This is really an action point system with some neat tricks.
First, is it odd that this reminds me of Attika?
You can gain resources or move & build. You can build or upgrade one building in a region. Other people with higher level building get a piece of the resources you paid to build or upgrade. Your goal is to build and then upgrade all 3 of your cities to level 4.
2 plays with 3 and 4 so far with equal tension and competition. Victory was achieved in a different manner each time.
Wrede made another good game that I'm certain will be as overlooked as Pompeii.

item.name: Alchemist
item.comment: Solid abstract. Interesting "hand management" of cubes. I still don't get the very tenuous comparison to Clans, however.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer.

item.name: Alfredo's Food Fight
item.comment: It's a silly kids game...wadda want. It's Loopin' Louie level fun, which is perfect IMHO.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: I like the tile-laying aspect of this game, and the tension the round cards add.

item.name: Amazonas
item.comment:
A nice area control game with lots of tension....I never thought money could be as tight as it is in this game.
Update:
Simply hasn't aged well. The choices are now obvious and tension non-existent.

item.name: Among the Stars
item.comment:
Among the Stars felt like a mess. Much like Briefcase's take on deck building, AtS tries to combine drafting with tableau construction, and in my eyes fails.
The problem is that so many of the cards are situational. Often a card that would give 2-3 points would be 4 or more if you had gotten it sooner or later in the game. Indeed, you never feel like you're guiding your own destiny, but are just along for the ride.
I guess its fine for some, just to play along and see how things turn out, but even 7 Wonders (which I'm also not a gigantic fan of) makes you feel like your choices matter.
There's also no gauge for how well you're doing until the very end. Our first game had an early runaway leader. Everyone caught up and things seem balanced, then the end game saw a 20 point blowout which no one could quite understand. Underwhelming is the word I would use.
I'd also add that the game's art is really ugly.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment:
This game is great for 3 and only gets better with more.
Update:
Years later and this still gets played at least a few times a year. The bidding system that we now see in Vegas Showdown, Homesteaders, and even Peloponnes started here; but in a harsher twist in the "cannot bid in the same location once outbid".
The more the merrier but I've never been totally convinced that you have to play with max players for this to be a good game.

item.name: Amyitis
item.comment: There's a lot going on, and a lot to be said for having a good grasp of abstract though and forward thinking. I liked it and want to play it again soon.

item.name: The Ancient World
item.comment:
The look and feel of this game is just wonderful to me. I look at the box, then when I take everything out, the theme continues. Ryan is a great artist, that's for sure.
As for the game? It's a solid worker placement with a nice twist to semi-restrict your placements. The restrictions force you to play in different ways rather than just be left out of certain actions. Almost everything is useful, and because of that, it's easy to forget your main objective: collecting banners.
The game is so tight, and it feels like there's never enough time to do what you want, and that is the sweet spot for a game like this. Too much freedom and you have a hollow experience. So far everyone has wanted to play again and again.

item.name: Android
item.comment:
Solid 8. I'm not sure that the rating could ever go higher for several reasons including:
- This game can be played by 5 players, but I'm not sure I'd ever want to. Time is the major factor here that even though there are a fixed number of rounds, it's still quite long. 3-4 is a great number for this game, and it scales amazingly well.
- There's a ton of fiddle here. I love the system and the theme so I don't mind that much, but the setup is 10x more arduous than the breakdown.
- The learning curve for a game of this length is VERY steep. So steep that they had to have strategy primers in the box (which I'm quite thankful for). Still, it makes new players start at a distinct disadvantage; and given the amount of screwage that you can inflict that could certainly be a factor to discourage repeat plays by newcomers.
It's a great game with quite a number of ways to play, and then there are "mini-games" that have to be managed within each character. Once we got the kinks out our 3rd play was smooth, fun, involving, challenging, tense, suspenseful, and satisfying.
One final note is that I was surprised at how balanced all the point strategies in the game are; meaning that there is a bonus as well as a foil for every point system in the game. The conspiracy puzzle can benefit early adopters and late comers equally as well.

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment:
Netrunner is one of those special games where the play and player interaction outshines the actual system. The core game is a 9, but because players can play the game well and win rather than just build well and win speaks volumes.
I'm at 60 plays and never looking back. In a way it's good that Netrunner failed in the early days because I think the time for things to simmer, ideas about card games to evolve, and players to mature as, well, players, makes now the right time for it to re-emerge. That it is not collectible is simply the cherry on top.

item.name: Android: Netrunner A Study in Static
item.comment: pack 4

item.name: Android: Netrunner The Universe of Tomorrow
Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Silly kids stacking game that needs a very minor variant to make playable for adults. It's fun every time though and has nice chunky bits.

item.name: Antics!
item.comment:
1 play with 4.
First: This is the worst artwork I've seen since the cover of Roads and Boats; and I didn't have to stare at that art the entire game :(
The game is very abstract and takes quite a while for everyone to build up meaningful levels of action ability. To compound this the most interesting parts of the game happen in the last 15 minutes, after playing nearly an hour.
Finally, the scoring is so tight that things could go in any direction at any given moment.
While I love the idea of building your hill for actions and the ability to play with the triggering of the anteaters I just cannot like this game as much as I'd like to.
Off the wishlist it comes :(
item.wishlistcomment: Curious use of Java and Taluva building in which # of levels high = number of times you do a selected action.

item.name: Antike
item.comment:
The Rondel (the way you choose your action each turn) is a beautiful mechanism. The game's combat is moderate, and quitre comparable in feel to Wallenstein, but with absolutely no luck; actually there's no luck at all in this game.
The fact that this game has more wood than any other that I own, coupled with the fact that it has 2 maps right out of the box, makes this one a winner; and I have to believe that my rating will rise with more players. This game has tremendous tension, and that will certainly be bolstered with more players involved.
If you can get you hands on this one, it's well worth it.
Update: With the advent of other Rondel based games this one drops a point.
Update 2: More plays in recent times. I don't know if it's because we've played so many more games now, or if the experience at this particular game has contributed to better play, but this one returns to an 8.
Update 3:
This game can suffer from new players versus experienced players. The advancements have to be equally gained first in order for equal play else there can be a runaway leader. That being said, I think the game is certainly all about the advancements and lacks the diversity in paths to victory that later rondel games have.

item.name: Antiquity
item.comment:
There's alot going on, and not enough time to do it all. It's one of the best engine building games I've ever played.
Pollution and famine are two of the most interesting mechanics of any game, and force you to balance all the actions you take.
I'm not so sure how balanced all of the win conditions are, but I am certain that over time we will see that they are more equal than they first appear.
Played again. This game will hurt your brain, but it never feels as long as it is. I have to concede that Larry Levy was right: I don't think you would use Pollution or Famine for a new players first game, but after the first play I wouldn't play without it.
Update:
Many more plays. Still heavy. Still brain melty. Still a 10.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment:
One of the best party games ever. It definately has to be played with the right crowd, however.
It's rarely played any more as there are other party games like Telestrations or the Three Commandments that have taken its' place.

item.name: AquaSphere
item.comment:
This might be my favorite Feld. The game is loaded with choices, and options, and though others might take your first choice you always have a second and even a third.
The game is initially visually overwhelming, and certainly brings out the AP even in the best of us. It's colorful and fun, and for me the submarine/bot scoring mechanism really has a feel of Terra Mystica, so I think that lends to my love of the game.

item.name: Arcana
item.comment:
It's a totally random majorities game.
For all it's flavor and art I expected more.

item.name: Arctic Scavengers
item.comment:
I guess I can see why Rio sat on this game for so long: It's not as light or as easy to learn as Dominion. The sad part is, it has some other things going on rather than just building your engine, such as the bidding at the end of each round of play. The digging is also a nice variable that, while it can harm a player's progress a bit, does add another element to the whole, making the package much more appealing in ways.
I actually think I would have liked it more if this wasn't my 12th deck builder or so; not that I'm tired of them honestly, I've just seen such a variety now that this is simply average rather than the fresh and unique it would have been years ago.

item.name: Ark
item.comment:
ALOT of crossreferencing to do in this one. It's definately not for beginners or the feint of heart, as figuring out all the factors for placement can be overwhelming for some.
Solid release for Doris and Frank.

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment: Meh. Build, place, try to get majority, rinse repeat. It's above average, but not by far his best. Maybe another play will convince me otherwise.
item.conditiontext: Like New. Comes with original insert.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment:
Shadows is my fave for co-op gameplay, but this is more of an adventure game like Runebound anyway.
Update:
After 30+ more plays with a myriad of expansions this settles into a 9.
Truly the newer content takes this game to greatness.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Curse of the Dark Pharaoh Expansion
Arkham Horror: Miskatonic Horror Expansion
item.comment: Still missing where this really does anything for the game even given all the effort it takes to sort everything in. It simply adds front end load time to such a degree as to be unacceptable.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Black Goat of the Woods Expansion
Arkham Horror: The King in Yellow Expansion
Arkham Horror: The Lurker at the Threshold Expansion
Army of Frogs
item.comment:
Seemed to be a little "you did this and I do that". I dunno, after playing Hive it's obvious that it was intended to make a multiplayer version that was simple and fast to play, but it just seems like there's no way to truely strategize. After my first plays I found that someone is always giving the win away unless they get lucky.
It needs a few more plays as I see glimmers of truth peeking out; I also love bakelite.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Ars Mysteriorum
item.comment:
Blind bidding + set collection in up to 3 dimensions = lots of fun.
Update:
Reintroduced this one to newer players in our group. I still find it interesting even if it outstays it's welcome.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment:
This one actually has quite a bit in common with Dominion and Thunderstone with some major differences:
- Multiple buys allowed in a round - Multiple combats allowed in a round - Randomized row of six cards available for purchase - 3 Standard cards always available - Row refills immediately following combat and purchases
It's much less predictable and strategic than Dominion but plays with the same light feel and fast pace. It also remains VERY COMBOLICIOUS.
I'll be excited to see where they take this system next.

item.name: Ascension: Return of the Fallen
item.comment:
Extended play with the base system and now minimal play with the expansion downgrade my initial ratings. There's only the illusion of strategy. It's still a fine game but nothing to be taken very seriously.
At least it's short and easy to set up or break down.

item.name: Asgard's Chosen
item.comment:
Asgard's Chosen was really the first deckbuilder/boardgame hybrid. It combines tense goal based play like that in Nexus Ops with the hidden foes from Kings N Things.
The powers are over the top, the combat is in your face, fighting favors the attacker (especially since you can go berzerk), and the goals are set up so you can strategize and complete them without giving too much information about your plans away.
I also love the theme and how well integrated it is. The wait has been worth it.

item.name: Ashes: Rise of the Phoenixborn
item.comment:
Sometimes it's the simple things. Simpler is almost always better. That's Ashes, simple, but brilliant.
Take a factionless game, add smaller decks, short play, and you're almost there. Add a dice-based resource system that lets you completely manipulate it at any time, and you complete it.
First, Ms Suarez, I'm in LOVE. You're one hell of an artist, and you have my attention; well even more than DoW, but now I'm fully locked in. Something like this needs to be captivating, and you've made women everywhere happy with 4 of the 6 Phoenixborns completely powerful, but not over sexualized, women. BRAVO.
So the system is rounds of back and forth actions until each passes. You play stuff, you attack with stuff, etc. I know it sounds mundane, but factor in the ability to manipulate your dice, however, your deck is so-very-finite at a scant 30 cards. It's amazing how much play can be had in a tiny deck size. The modes of play are here too; the draft is dead brilliant.
If you get the chance, play a demo. If you like lcgish games, you'll likely fall for this one. It'll even fit in to your economy with a slower release schedule. I have a feeling releases, though fewer, will have more value since every card is meaningful to any build. There is no chaff in this game, and no limits.

item.name: Assyria
item.comment:
Assyria is a game that has quite a bit going for it. There's a bit of area control, there's a building aspect, and some majority play.
The only fuzzy area for me is that of the card display. It's a random element that is awfully rogue. It can often spoil your plans and sour your attitude. It's feast or famine and nary in between.
While the cards can dash your hopes you can often refocus on other avenues to build VP's but ultimately the cards dictate your camel gathering performance, which is a key to victory.
There's obvious strategy here with a splash of tactical play to be had. I think repeated play will allow the cards to be overcome but time will tell.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment:
I can certainly see the core of Agricola and Le Havre here. It's got a hint of interaction in the helper cards as well as in the turn order mechanism.
What you mainly have is Antiquity distilled down to it's essence. While it might be perceived to be too long for what it is, I actually quite like it's similarity to the latter, while appreciating it's differences, which are more like the designer's other work.
There's quite a bit to learn, but it remains simpler and shorter than the rest of the trilogy.
It's the first design, but I'm glad it was released last, and further I'm happy that there promises more to come from this blossoming designer.

item.name: Atlantic Star
item.comment: Captivating and fast-paced. Nice set collecting game. The more the better IMHO.

item.name: Atlantis
item.comment:
Uses the shrinking board mechanism and tile collection mechanism from that's life.
Uses a twist on Cartagena movement and an interesting evolution of the card draw mechanism from Cartagena.
All in all a fine game that I look forward to playing more.
Don't be fooled by that 30 minute play time; you won't get it on your first play.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: I rarely pay resources for anything...the game s great with any number of players, though there is a subtle formula that you can play this game by to win. The only mitigating factor is the luck of the draw in the tiles.

item.name: Attribute
item.comment:
Underwhelming word game. There is so little game here and even less to say about it.
Avoid.

item.name: Auf Achse
item.comment: Ok if played with the die, good if played with 1-6 cards to replace the die, and probably best if you eliminate the road blocks.

item.name: Australia
item.comment:
Falls squarely into the above average category.
It's a fine design, and it's a bit light, with a dose of luck.
We used the variant of face up draw piles, and included the windmill, so it was as "good as it gets".
It could be worth playing again, but I wasn't too excited by it, and it may make an exit stage left...we'll see; perhaps another play is in order.

item.name: Automobile
item.comment:
Not for those who do not like math or some min/maxing in their games.
Automobile takes basically a marginal gains system and an incrementally more expensive cost track and makes a serious brain burner of a game.
Plays in 90 minutes and while I like it better with 4 than 3, I personally think the game would suffer, at least for one person, with 5; unless you like high screwage. I would wager in a 5p game one person knows half way in that they have lost.
It's a shame that Wallace doesn't seem to be focused on games of this weight any longer as he's VERY good at them.

item.name: Ave Caesar
item.comment:
When the instructions tell you there are just a few points extra in the cards, you would think there would be enough that you could finish a race right? Well there are enough points, but use them wisely, or your first game will end up like ours....with none of us finishing!
That being said, this game makes for a tight, strategic race, that's one part fun, one part screw your buddy.
Update: Formula D and Snow Tails make this one crash to a 6. Ave just hasn't aged well.
item.conditiontext: The more players the better, though with esxperience I think this one is better with a full boat.

item.name: Bacchus' Banquet
item.comment:
After 6 plays I'm confused as to where the game really is. The game seems shallow, and ends abruptly. It isn't even satisfying when you when, and much less so when you lose.
This one is going up for trade/sell.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Back to the Future: The Card Game
item.comment:
Exactly as expected: Silly, random, and fun.
It helps a ton if you're a fan of the movies.
It also helps to play with 4 or less and the game ends in a blistering 20 minute flash.

item.name: Baker's Dozen
item.comment:
Inferior to the original version in every way even though the rules are the same.
Round cards suck.
Munchkin style box sucks.
Amusing for kids, not necessary if you have the original.

item.name: Balloon Cup
item.comment: This one will take more plays to sort out exactly how much strategy there is to be had. There's alot of "tit for tat" card play in this one, though picking your battles and trying to bluff/goad your opponent into ones that are unimportant to you to mask your true intent is the heart of this game.

item.name: Basari
item.comment: I like infuencing other people's greedy nature

item.name: Batman: Gotham City Strategy Game
item.comment:
This is a mediocre area control game. Even with all the nice minis, the game has otherwise unremarkable bits. The game is really quite shallow, with only a single path to victory.
For my time and money I'd just rather play Chaos in the Old World. It's a shame too, because Chaos could easily have been re-themed to this and though the same would have been a MUCH better game.

item.name: Batt'l Kha'os
item.comment:
This is certainly not the war game that the box might fool you into believing. It's a majorities game, and quite an abstract one.
Essentially you're trying to get majorities at vertices, and then the most controlled vertices controls the towers for vps. The major twist is that there are 10 bonus tokens of various powers to modify play.
It's a fun romp, and it's pleasing to the eye as well.

item.name: Battle Beyond Space
item.comment: This one scratches the same itch as Neuroshima Hex. It's fast, fun, lightly chaotic, yet still allows some nice tactics.

item.name: BattleLore
item.comment: The best of the series. I still Love Memoir and Ancients, but some of the elements that were simplified, along with all the new elements melds into on great and unique experience.
item.conditiontext: Update: More figures, more cards, more games played, now it's a 10!

item.name: BattleLore: The Hundred Years' War Crossbows & Polearms
Bausack
item.comment: A fun a crazy stacking dexterity game that I have yet to see anyone who doesn't like.

item.name: Beer & Pretzels
item.comment:
A light, silly, fast-paced dexterity game with lots of flavor (no pun intended).
It's exactly what it looks like, though it's surprising how much the texture of the table and the coefficient of drag both on the coasters and boundary line comes into the strategy.
Fantastic little game. Came with Ted's map pack, the 6th player expansion, and ended at $15 free ship; a bargain!

item.name: Beer & Pretzels: Purple Coaster Expansion
item.comment: Adds the 6th player, and in a game like this, that means more game!

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment:
The expanding board is nice. I also like the story driven gameplay, and the fact that you can kill each other.
Update:
Kicked to the curb by Mansions of Madness. While I know Betrayal isn't moderated it's still a one versus many concept that delivers the same feel and the Mythos we know and love.
item.conditiontext: Gently Used: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Big City
item.comment:
I love it, even though I sucked at my first game of it. I look forward to MANY more plays.
Update: Would you look at that? More plays and it's a 9! I like the balance of hand management versus the timing of the buildings. With experienced players it can seem like someone has an unfair lead, and a timely play puts you with them or out in front.

item.name: Big Kini
item.comment: I had no issues with my friend using the discovery strategy....I had more Reef Barons anyhow.....and my wife had more of a combination of the other 2 positions and money to beat me by 1 friggin' point!!!

item.name: Big Kini Expansion: 5-6 Players and Action Cards
item.comment: Trade note: Spare copy for trade. New.
item.conditiontext: Brand new. Duplicate gift.

item.name: Blink
item.comment:
This game is so silly and frantic...even better when you're intoxicated.
The Good: The quintessential speed game.
The Bad: Not really a game but more of pattern recognition, luck of the draw, and hand speed.

item.name: Blokus
item.comment:
3 or 4 players is the only way to fly. It's like playing multiplayer tetris.
Update:
Still worth having for the occasional play, though right now it's gathering dust.
Also, Fits just walked up and bitch slapped Blokus.

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: A fantastic tweak to an already solid game. I had always felt the 2 - player game in the original lacking. The Travel edition brings it home in a big way. Simply great!

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment: This is just Blokus a different way. It's nothing all that special really.

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager The Card Game
Blood Bowl: Team Manager The Card Game Sudden Death
Blue Moon
item.comment:
Fantastic NON-Colectible card game. Tons of strategy under what had appeared at first glance to be a stripped down exterior.
All the good stuff I liked about ccgs, without almost any of the stuff I didn't. Add to that fantastic balancing, high production values, and wonderful art direction.
Some of the names are a bit unpronouncable and some of the others are groan inducingly comical as well as down right awful. Though if that's the game's only shortcoming, I see no shortcomings.
While I also wish I could find card sleeves for the oversized cards, I wouldn't wish the cards to be smaller just to accomodate being able to protect them.
The Vulca and Mimix are wonderful decks, though it is not necessary to buy the base set, as all other decks can work independantly, given you already know the rules and can produce 3 proxies for the dragons.
It is worth it to buy all the decks, as you can then play the "Consolidated" versions fo each deck, by returning the scattered cards of other races from the base deck they are in, over to the race deck the "belong" in.
Deckbuilding with the Emissaries and Inquisitors packs should be something very fun when I get around to it.
I highly recommend this game to anyone.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: A nice game of majorities, hand management, and planned movement. I really love the idea of previously scored tiles adding a bonus to orthagnally adjacent tiles when they are scored. The game is elegantly simple in it's design, and it's fast paced with tons of room for strategy. The card luck can be a factor, albiet a minor one.

item.name: Blue Moon: The Mimix
item.comment: In my first plays, this deck seems to be a slight step behind the rest, as much of it's power to sweep a fight is dependant on the "Pairs" ability. It played well, but not quite as consistently as the others.

item.name: Blue Moon: The Pillar
item.comment: With one of the most evil abilities, disclosure, on their side, and lots of power boosting boosters and support cards, many of them "Free", this deck is a tough act to follow. Definately not an introductory deck.

item.name: Blue Moon: The Terrah
item.comment: Almost the polar opposite of the Vulca in every respect, yet having a style all their own, this deck is solid and balanced. Like all the other's Ive tried I find it hard not to recommend this one.

item.name: The BoardGameGeek Game
item.comment:
Tentative rating that requires another play.
The crux of my rating is based on the guessing game that is worker placement. While you do have a range of possibilities to help you narrow down your guess there still seems to be too wide a "margin of error" to allow for consistent strategy.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment:
Riotous fun. I think the magic number of players might be 4 or perhaps even 5. I like this game as much as I ever used to.
Update:
Still sees occasional play. I still feel that this game doesn't play well with more than 5. One crucial lesson through the years is that one play can give away the farm, and indeed the game, becoming an unintentional king maker.

item.name: Bombay
item.comment: I was pleasantly surprised by this feather weight pick up and deliver game. It's got a few familiar concepts nicely blended with an extremely short play time. If it took longer it'd be a loser, but thanks for the 30 minute time frame it's a solid 8.

item.name: Boomtown
item.comment: One part Settlers, and 2 parts something new. Simple, fast and fun. The roll of the dice is one MINOR aspect of the game.

item.name: Bootleggers
item.comment: This is a nice majorities game in the sense that you want to have "control" of the different speakeasies to make the most profit. There is also room for negotiation as you can "rent" out space on your trucks. I think this one is vastly underrated.

item.name: Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
Brass
item.comment:
Rating could still rise, but after just a few plays this ranks as one of Martin's best. I like the income system a lot and the duality of the cards.
I cannot wait until they rework this and start releasing maps.

item.name: The Bridges of Shangri-La
item.comment: Lots of agonizing placement decisions.

item.name: Bringing Down the House
item.comment: While I TOTALLY detest this game personally, I think Simply Fun has a finely crafted game that truely embodies the sense of Armericana that classic games like Monopoly and Clue do. Quite a fine family game. Especially good with large groups. It's alot of randomness, but it's quite alot of silly fun.

item.name: Bruges
item.comment:
Over my initial play I really came to appreciate this system. The early going can be akin to stabbing in the dark, and indeed even some turns almost require a bit of blind faith that your preparations will be useful, there's the other side of things where the lack of player interaction actually serves to reduce the chances of screwage.
I do think experience will prove that you can predictively play and make wise decisions, and certainly the play time is so short that even the random elements do not hurt so bad.
In the end you have a game that's unique, fun, and fast. I'm looking forward to many more plays.

item.name: Bucket Brigade
item.comment:
Bucket Brigade:
There's an odd mish-mash of play and tactics found here. On one hand, you're trying to get certain firemen to the top to get the most points with your hand...but you have to use their cards to do so. On the other side of things pairs of ones are valuable so you don't want to use them...and ones might be all you have for a color. There's also the fact that someone might have a massive amount of one color and be able to get gigantic points..I also find it disturbing that so far, in almost 10 games of this, no one has score negative points...
This game is at the same level as Dragon Parade, only with a tactic more.
I've had fun with it, but I wonder how soon it might wear thin.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Bus
item.comment: Obviously the charter game of Splotter. Perfect information, and a lot going on in this pick up and deliver game. No catch up mechanism, so it's keep up or get left behind.

item.name: Buy Low Sell High
item.comment: Fast paced and fun....simple and elegant. No good for 2 players. Sold mine due to lack of plays. While a decent game, nothing compelling enough to get it off the shelf.

item.name: BuyWord
item.comment: Solid. It's like scrabble with several other facets. Much less limited than Scrabble too.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: Just plain silly fun. There is a touch of strategy, but there is more to this game than just random gun weilding.

item.name: El Caballero
item.comment:
This one predates Carcassonne so Im forced to believe that this has to be an influence. Further it feels like a cross of Carc and El Grande; the latter is no surprise.
Its incredibly abstract, quite engaging, very tense, and a little too long. It can take some time to build up steam and luck of the draw still has a large impact regardless of the 5 tile display.
Perhaps if this had come earlier in my gaming career it would have been more fascinating and garnered a higher rating, however its not the lack of merit the game earns but rather the sheer amount of competition for time it has these days.
Perhaps one day it will see play again, but that wouldnt keep me from trading this game away.

item.name: Caesar & Cleopatra
item.comment: A solid two player game worthy of the Kosmos name. 2 initial plays make it a 7, but I can see this one rising slightly to an 8 as the strategy is more fleshed out (mainly in constuction of the action card deck, which we chose to try the newbie version and just let it be random). I like the bluffing in this game as well, and we did not utilize it enough in our firt plays.

item.name: California
item.comment: Initial impression after playing it once. I need to play it again before I comment further. But it's essentially set collection, with a touch of strategic tile laying.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: Collectible Card Game
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game
item.comment:
It's a LCG all about crazy powers and nasty effects whilst in the midst of high strategy. I'm glad they made this as a LCG for all to get to know, as it drowned in a crowd of lesser CCG's back in the day.
Update:
The more the system is expanded and the more it evolves the better it gets. It's still one of the best of all time.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Ancient Horrors Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Aspirations of Ascension Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Conspiracies of Chaos Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Curse of the Jade Emperor Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Denizens of the Underworld
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Dunwich Denizens Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Ebla Restored
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game For the Greater Good
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game In Memory of Day Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game In the Dread of Night Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Initiations of the Favored Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Into Tartarus Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Journey to Unknown Kadath Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Kingsport Dreams Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Lost Rites
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Murmurs of Evil Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Never Night Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Perilous Trials Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Screams from Within Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Search for the Silver Key Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Secrets of Arkham
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Seekers of Knowledge
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Shadow of the Monolith Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Sleep of the Dead Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Spawn of Madness Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Terror in Venice
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game That Which Consumes Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Antediluvian Dreams Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Breathing Jungle Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Cacophony Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Gleaming Spiral Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Horror Beneath the Surface Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Key and the Gate
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Mountains of Madness Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Order of the Silver Twilight
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Path to Y'ha-nthlei Asylum pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Shifting Sands Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Sleeper Below
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Spawn of the Sleeper Asylum pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Spoken Covenant Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Terror of the Tides Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Thing from the Shore Asylum pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Thousand Young
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Twilight Beckons Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Unspeakable Pages
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game The Wailer Below Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Touched by the Abyss
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Twilight Horror Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Whispers in the Dark Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Words of Power Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game Written and Bound Asylum Pack
Can't Stop
item.comment: Good dice based filler.

item.name: Canal Mania
item.comment:
Solid meld of TTR and a hint of AoS.
The issue is that it certainly doesn't play in the 60-90 range without multiple plays, and even then does it stack up well enough against games of that length that I would still want to play.
I see this getting a few more plays to find that out as it's a solid design, a good effort and play might sweeten with experience and reduced duration.

item.name: El Capitn
item.comment: While the script of the lettering takes some getting used to, the new design is a definite improvement, and to me plays as well and balanced as it's predecessor. I also liked the addition of a fifth player. The game scaled well before, and continues to do so, though I will say that with that many players you can expect the full 120 minutes that the box advertises; though I would play with 5 any time.

item.name: Capitol
item.comment: Not terribly deep, but fast and simple.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: Great strategy and tile-laying. Infinite possibilities.

item.name: Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers
item.comment: Carcassonne's little brother. It may be cleaner and neater....but I like some of the dirtiness of the original. The bonus tiles are only ok.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Castle
item.comment: Carcassonne the City's nephew. I don't mind the restrictions, but there's something I don't like that I just can't put my finger on.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Carcassonne: The City
item.comment: A great evolution of the franchise.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Princess & the Dragon
item.comment: Worst Carc add-on EVER.

item.name: Cardcassonne
item.comment:
One part hand management one part press your luck game. There's actually a semblance of strategy to be found in the order which you play your cards.
Played quickly this is a light fun game that should survive at least a dozen plays. Perhaps it will inspire us to play more but I somehow doubt it's welcome will wear so well.
One final note: I wish Klaus had relied on his name to sell this one. I guess after the poor reception Pompeii received he felt he needed to attach the moniker to see it even though it was entirely unrelated to the original; just like Mr. Friese.

item.name: Careers
item.comment:
Roll, Move, Sleep ....I doubt that I will ever volunteer to play it again.
The Good: Easy to learn and play
The Bad: Overly random, high downtime between turns, little strategy.

item.name: Cargo Noir
item.comment:
It's quite a clever game of set collection, risk management and an odd-duck reverse bidding system that adds a ton of tension all within an extremely compressed time frame.
I was shocked at how much I liked it. It's not amazing by any stretch but it certainly has it's own place and time. I'm looking forward to more plays.

item.name: Carolus Magnus
item.comment:
Another very good abstract from Leo! My rating will probably improve with further play.
Update:Further plays have shown limited avenues to victory. I question whether I still want to play this game again. I guess another play is in order to see.

item.name: Carson City
item.comment:
Caylus? No. Worker Placement and the actions executed in order "like Caylus", yes.
There's the main area where you build, gain multipliers for your income and or points, as well as potentially screw your opponents income.
Then there's the matter of the characters that determine turn order for the round with variable powers; tack onto that that they are chosen in ascending passing order from the previous round.
It's all tense, diverse, and quite fun.
I will say however that the dice can be a little unforgiving, though this can be mitigated and perhaps avoided altogether with the variant. I also do not think this game is as good with 5.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: Brilliant and simple. Highly variable and replayable.

item.name: Castle
item.comment: Light strategy, with a little chaos from the draw. Play after play reveals more strategy from this one.

item.name: A Castle for All Seasons
item.comment:
Short. Simple.
There are so few strategies in this game that once you begin to dominate one you've got a huge advantage. Get your foot in the door to what seems to be the only other strategy, and you've got a lock.
So let me get this straight: There's the tower strategy, house strategy, the "hope people don't place too many helpers" strategy, and the "please god don't let people build too many buildings" strategy.
It's a total dud. Some of the bonuses simply don't pay enough. I mean, who exactly isn't going to try and play as many helpers as they can or build as many buildings as they can? Perhaps they're trying not to help people using those strategies, but then what are they to do?
I was a runaway leader when playing this and I can honestly say that 3 experienced players were left with a game that was not even as good as Stone Age.
I know they're going for family style games these days but this one needed to bake a bit longer in the over before they served it up.

item.name: Castle Merchants
item.comment: A very easy to play connection game. More random than I had hoped, but stil light fun.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: The Castle of the Devil
item.comment:
This one really takes the right group.
There's a smattering of inductive reasoning coupled with he blind guessing/attacking of Shadow Hunters and Werewolf.
At one point the facts are on the table and it's a mad scramble for someone to end the game.
Expect an uneven reception to this one.
Update:
Sloppy and un-fun. There are too many newer games of this style, especially The Resistance, that have really honed this style to a razor's edge with equal simplicity.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment:
Castles is the best dice-based game I have played since Troyes. Castles is also VERY long. I really enjoy the game, the variety, tension, and wealth of options throughout each play however.
I'm concerned that Castles is likely best with 4 given that every tile appears in a 4P game and that there are more available tiles vs player actions leading to each round being 5 turns of great choices not 3 or MAYBE 4 with good choices. I still had a fun time with the 3P experience but there's something to be said for the full player count.
I'm also highly motivated to use the alternative player boards as I think there will be less player collisions based simply on equal desire from a static setup. I think the tension would be even higher, the games more varied, and the competition more fierce at times when the variable boards create uneven levels of demand.
I think it's Feld's best game with In the Year of the Dragon being a very close second.

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment:
Obvious statement of the year: This game is a very close cousin to Suburbia.
I actually find the theme much more engaging than Burb. I also find it, mostly, less chaotic. Smart plays and wise master builder turns can lead to advantage, even if you're not doing well with bonuses.
What a great evolution of the system.

item.name: Catan
item.comment: Dice can't be consistent....Great in concept tho. Granted if you are a good trader you can play VERY consistently.

item.name: Catan Card Game
item.comment: I have to say that this one was alot better than I thought it would be. There's a good effort to make this feel like Settlers, while still remaining it's own game. I have yet to try my expansions with it, but I know the game will only get better with subsequent plays.

item.name: Catan Histories: Struggle for Rome
item.comment:
Definately a different direction for the Catan franchise. The game does have limited trading, and the first play through is on the long side (though it doesn't feel that way). I know with experience that this game can be played in much less than the 90 minutes it's rated for.
It's a good game; but not great; but definitely worth playing many times to come.
Update:
As our gaming experience has grown so too has that allowed us to see more bad than good here. It lasted less than 10 plays before the trade.

item.name: Catan: Portable Edition
item.comment: Rates a notch higher than the original for the convenience and portability.

item.name: Cathedral
item.comment: 2 player Blokus.

item.name: Cave Troll
item.comment:
Very simple area control with minor powers for some of the pieces. Best with 4 IMHO. Recently sold to make way for games we actually play.
The Good: Great theme, art, and movement/majority mechanics
The Bad: Too long for what it is and as it drags out the fun dies with the ticking of the clock.

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment:
For me this is like Agricola only it has more freedom like you'd find in many resource conversion games such as Homesteaders. That's a double edged sword because as much as the system opens up it also takes away the uniqueness.
This game is certainly one big pond to swim in. I'm sure some Gric purists will poo-poo this game, perhaps others will simply be tired of the genre, however for anyone like me that still enjoys a cube churner with lots of flavor and freedom, then this game will hit all the right notes.

item.name: Cavum
item.comment:
Abstract, long, boring, chaotic. Most likely the worst game of the Essen crop and even more likely the worst Kramer/Kiesling design.
Avoid at all costs.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment:
Such a variety of avenues to victory....even when the game is tight, there are many, many options.
First came Ys from Ystari, which was a 9...with it's expansion it became a 10.
I was never surprised that their next release would be even better. I expect great things in Ystari's future.
Superb production values and graphic design are a hallmark of this company and it's games. If you are looking for a short game, or a filler, they have nothing to offer you. If you are looking for a deep gamer's game, welcome home.
Update:
Pending another play, this might drop as far as a 8. The mechanics are brilliant, and I really want to love this game, but I suppose maybe I just don't get it.
Either way, I'll play again and we'll see.
Update:
More plays, more effort, more paying attention to the people beating me silly finally gave me my light bulb moment. It's as good as I ever thought.

item.name: Caylus Magna Carta
item.comment: Nice light version of the base game. Not the same depth, ans has 2/3 the play time (I would think a simpler version would be shorter). I have some issues with the simplified road, such as the limitation of the Provost not being able to move pas it's end like in the board game. I also miss the Baliff.

item.name: Chairs
item.comment:
A mildly interesting and silly little dexterity game in the vein of bausack, but with far less variety.
The Good: Dexterity game.
The Bad: Uniform pieces add little variety and there are other games of this genre that do it better.

item.name: Chang Cheng
item.comment:
This game is actually deceptively strategic, yet it still has a light air about it. It plays in a very short amount of time, and looks cool while you play.
Update: After the lore of the chrome has worn off, it's easy to see that this is not all that great of a game. It's in the same boat of many rock paper scissors games, and while it is thankfully short, it doesn't feel all that satisfying; thus it is beginning to gather dust.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment:
Preliminary rating with "wrong" rules and extended playtime due to newbieness. If playtime drops the rating is sure to rise.
Update:
Playtime dropped to 60 minutes or less. The game is just so thought provoking, filled with conflict and chances to feel clever.
Update:
Continued play, continued fun.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World: The Horned Rat Expansion
item.comment:
I love the new spell and upgrade cards. There is a much higher lever of combo goodness and interactivity. There is much more of an opportunity to do clever things.
The new Skaven faction is well done and compliments the game nicely.
Overall I'm wondering if they could have just waited an extra year or two and released the game with this "expansion" in a complete form.
The 5th player does make the game longer but it's incredibly tense and our initial plays have been quite close.

item.name: Chteau Roquefort
item.comment:
The game has alot of bits, but overall isn't all that fiddly. I though for sure that setup and breakdown time would take a while, but even before the first play it took only minutes; and even less time with subsequent plays.
I like the "layering" of the board. It gives a 3d feel that most games cannot relay. I understand that this is a trademark of Zoch games, and this is no exception. From the Mouse shaped tokens, to the holes in the insert that act as the Dungeon to the castle, this game screams flavor. I also have to add that, for those of you that have played it, causing an opponents mouse to fall into a "trap" is as satisfying as getting to throw a piece into the volcano in Downfall of Pompeii.
There is alot of strategy to be had in this fun little game. The modular board also ensures endless variety. I am truely glad that I bought it.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: I like chess...it's just a bit dry and most other people either don't have the patience or aptitude...

item.name: Chez Goth
item.comment:
Less chaos than munchkin...which is what I like about games like this
The Good: John Kovalik
The Bad: Munchkin Wannabe

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment:
Tentative 8, which could rise and fall. Rating is based on two 4 player games, which is supposedly a "bad" number for this game, though both were very competitive.
It's reminiscent of Stephenson's Rocket in some respects, and actually has a ton of new elements. The short time frame is great as well.

item.name: China
item.comment: Several strategies for placement of your pieces that allow you to choose your route to victory. VERY solid, mayhaps my favorites Schacht game.

item.name: China Moon
item.comment:
To be honest, I bought this on both the Bruno pedigree and the frog theme alone. I dove in eagerly as I knew it was quite a thinky abstract.
Game play was more strategic and back-and-forth than I had expected, however the near ties in the final scoring really put a cramp in my opinion. This games real saving grace was the speedy play time.
Good is you dont over think it. It will get at least one more play to see if it eventually sinks or swims.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment:
Much lighter than I had expected, but still a pleasant surprise.
Has similar aspects to Acquire, but plays much more like Big City. Add trading to the mix, which I do so love, then you make a game of endless possibility. The trading knocks out the random element for the most part.
I played the new edition, but plan to break out my original and see how the bonus cards play out and whether to include them in future plays or not, and also to see how the different layout effects the game (I suspect not much).
Classic Alea.

item.name: Chupacabra
item.comment: One of the better card games to come out in recent times. It's almost entirely unique.I especially like that you have to pick your moment to strike, and that since other players cards contribute to your own, the card luck is almost entirely mitigated. There is also a nice level of bluffing inherent to the system.The art for this one is phenomenal as well.
item.wishlistcomment:
Maybe Morgan will read this and get Z-Man to publish it.
Update:
Guess it will never be Z-man :(

item.name: Circus Flohcati
item.comment: Fast paced fun from Reiner Knizia! I prefer the original german rules as opposed to the changes that rio grande saw fit to make.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Solid with any number of players. 4-5 is probably best, but fast and light with even 3.

item.name: La Citt
item.comment: I've heard this called "Settlers for Adults".....more like a cross between Settlers resource gathering and Attika's bulding placement. Very scaleable.

item.name: Clans
item.comment: One of Colovini's best IMHO.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: It's a hand/resource managment game at it's heart. It also has a nice bit of strategy in the mosaic aspect of the game. You also have to be very flexible, as often opponents will beat you to what you were just about to build. I also think that you have to be willing to eat a good deal of corruption. I have only lost one game out of 6 plays, and that is due to the fact that I came VERY close to having the most corruption. It's a fine line you must walk, but it will lead you directly to victory.

item.name: Cloud 9
item.comment: A decent mix of card and die play. Makes for a fast light push your luck game, though i still prefer other better.

item.name: Coconuts
item.comment:
Never since Alfredo's Food Fight have I had so much fun with catapults!
While the coconuts to look somewhat like poo, which would also been thematic, they're bouncy and lead to some outrageous turns of events.
It's silly fun, and if you like this sort of thing, buy it; it's exactly what you're expecting.

item.name: Coda
item.comment: A nice light game of deduction.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment:
It's password with teams and lots of variety. I really like how brain-melty trying to give the clues can feel.
The game didn't exactly wow me, but I would never turn down a play that's for sure.

item.name: Colonia
item.comment:
This game needs to be SHORTER.
There are 4 sections: The Market , The Craftsmen, The Ships, and The Relics
All 4 are random and all 4 need to align somehow to allow you to make points. That's not saying you can't save resources, goods, or money for the "right time", but then making money with your goods is difficult as how many ships will sail is also random, and if like in our game an average of 1 ship sails, there aren't many opportunities to make money.
Random, random, random, and if you get lucky you make points.....and I came in second.
Sorry, this one is a PASS. It only gets a 6 for the core mechanisms.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: Very subtle strategy, and you gotta know when to grab or when to screw a friend :).....great for 3...even better with 4...can't wait to try it with 5

item.name: Coloretto Amazonas
item.comment:
Total random crapfest...
The Good: Pretty pictures
The Bad: Totally random to the point where there is no guessing element left compared to Coloretto. There is no "should I or shouldn't I". No tension at all.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Colossal Arena
item.comment: You have to be vicious to win with this one. Randomness can rule the day.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment:
I see the parallels that people draw to Princes, but those ties are tenuous at best. I would actually liken the gathering of sets of tiles in this game to that of Ra, yet you cash them in to make a "work" like PoF. The individual tiles hold no value themselves though.
There is a good deal of luck in the tiles that come out and when, not to mention the fact that you have the die rolls to move the pieces around the track to gain bonuses and medals.
This game is WAY over produced.
There are more ways to gain points than in almost any other game I've seen.
This will either be a 9 with further plays, or drop to a 7.
The game does a really god job of balancing itself, and even one false move can be recovered from.
I think that like most Wolfgang games that this one will pick up steam with age, and as people play it more they will appreciate it more.
Update: Dropped to a 7 then a 6. The movement of the pawns around the track is awful. 2 players can bounce them between on another, and he who starts with Caesar can win most of the time. There's also little variety in the shows, and even less control in them than at first blush. 15 plays proves this is really a 6. Play Princes of Florence or Leonardo instead.
item.conditiontext: I continue to see room for planning, consistent trading, and consistent results of strategies in this game. I understand that it's not deep, or totally without luck, but you can certainly be consistent, and that is the mark of a good game. My rating rose from 8 TO 9.

item.name: Colt Express
item.comment:
Colt Express is nearly pure chaos with the basic game. That's a LARGE nearly, as repeated plays have seen significant decision points arise, but honestly, one errant card will derail you. The thing is, it happens to everyone fairly equally, so much like a bar room brawl you're just trying to get hit less than anyone else.
The game is fast, furious, and fascinating to watch unfold. It is full of flavor, and is just plain fun.

item.name: Commands & Colors: Ancients
item.comment: Everything I had expected and more. Even easier to get into that I had hoped. Our first play was alot of player aid referencing.....but it started to smooth out by the end. 1st game was only 1 hour after rules explanation. I can't wait to play again.

item.name: Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #1 Greece & Eastern Kingdoms
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #2 Rome and the Barbarians
Commands & Colors: Ancients Expansion Pack #3 The Roman Civil Wars
Comuni
item.comment:
Decidedly average.
For me, it was another exercise in bidding, collection, building, and point scoring.
I've just got so many games like this. I'd actually prefer to play this group of developer's original effort Leonardo Da Vinci.

item.name: Container
item.comment:
This is the first game that I felt like blind-bidding hinders the gameplay. I'll play it a couple more times as the rest of the ideas are top notch, and I love the bits.
Update: Slowly improving over time, and perhaps might go higher. It now sits at a solid 7; meaning worth pulling out semi regularly in my book. This game is about resource manangement and taking risks. It's not all that hard to catch up with a crafty play or two.

item.name: Control Nut!
item.comment: A nice mix of auction and trick-taking. The control cards are very well balanced. There is a bit of luck-of-the-draw in the cards with stars on them, but this is usually balanced in the actual play of the game.

item.name: Cosmic Cows
item.comment:
Yahtzee with a theme, shorter plaing time and *gasp* a smidge of strategy.
It's still alot of luck...but it's fun.
Did I mention it has nice little Cowples?

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment:
Better with 4, but does well with 3. Some of the powers can throw the game, but careful bargaining can make your worst enemy think he wants to be an ally...this is the key.
Update:
For trade as we have the FF edition.
item.conditiontext:
Like New: 90's Avalon Hill
For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment:
Maybe it's just that this negotiation game takes the right group, or the fact that inexperienced players can tip the scales to the experienced, or perhaps that I'm just not as enamored with this game as I used to be.
I find it just a good game, not great. Fine for an occasional play as it's fast and I do like negotiation.

item.name: The Count of Carcassonne
item.comment: Oh My, Oh My, Oh My, You EVIL little COUNT!

item.name: Coup
item.comment:
I never imagined I'd find another hidden role game that would fit a niche in my collection, but Coup manages to do just that.
Where I have Love Letter for a smaller group and the Resistance for a larger one, Coup lands in a comfortable middle ground and for that reason it should see some serious table time.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: Waaaaaaaayyyy too expensive for what it is. It's a fun romp though.

item.name: Cthulhu Dice
item.comment:
Silly dice game like Le Boom that's sure to have a limited life span (hence the lower rating than I actually feel it "deserves" atm).
There's a bit more diversity and more fun. The chances for player interaction on every turn, even after you are out of the game, really make this shine.

item.name: Cuba
item.comment:
Call it a Caylus wannabe, or Puerto Rico 2, whatever; it's nothing like that.
It has a bundle of familiar mechanics implemented in new ways, and introduces new ones seamlessly. After 3 plays I can say this: It's not earth-shattering, but it's a credit to the economy genre, and one of the best at that.
Perhaps this will go up to a 9 with more plays, but I can definitely say it's no 10.
Update: A solid 7. Too bad the expansion doesn't do anything for this one.

item.name: The Curse of the Ruby Rhino
Cyclades
item.comment:
Cyclades is an odd game. It has you chasing generation of an economy as well as building and collection of discounts. The issue I have is just how "sudden death" our first play was. I'm uncertain that the game could end in any other way without all players involved turtling.
If the latter were to happen the game would become longer and the entire premise and game play are far too thin to support any length beyond an hour. This game should be fast, dirty, and nasty.
Another play is needed but somehow I think I'll be hard pressed to find opponents.
item.conditiontext: Played once. Punched and bagged. Original insert included. Like New.

item.name: D-Day Dice: Atlantikwall
item.comment:
While I enjoyed the experience I had some frustrations while I found there were an enormous number of foils to the German abilities and strategy built into the game. Sometimes I was doing something evil and wonderful that I had waited half the game to do just to have the Allies deny me :( There were tons of back and forths but in the end, and we were playing on a later scenario, I came out WAY ahead as the Germans.
My only real trepidation playing them again is that they can make the game MUCH longer, and I'm not sure it's worth while at that point.

item.name: Daimyo
item.comment:
Lightish abstract wargaming. It plays in 20 minutes and the more advanced cards are incorporated easily. There are some interesting bluffs and feints you can make and turtling will not save you.
I'm pleasantly surprised and this one stays in the collection after a long time without a initial play. I'm sure many wouldn't care for this based on it's serious abstract nature alone.

item.name: Dawn Under
item.comment: Memory on steroids with a goofy vampire theme. Plenty of chances to screw thy neighbor tho. Sold recently; nothing compelling in this game to warrant additional plays.

item.name: Days of Steam
item.comment:
I'm really conflicted on this game.
It's fast light tile laying; it's got a simple system using action points; it's got simple pick up and deliver.
It's also counterintuitive in the fact that you often are reluctant to make moves like adding cities or creating loops as they work to mutual advantage rather than creating greater opportunity for yourself than other players.
It has the potential to be blissfully short, such as thirty minutes, which would certainly raise my rating. Another factor would be a couple other plays to find out just how strategic the set collection mechanism is and if that would make the risk/reward curve better.
Will either be a 7/8 or a 5.
Update:
5. I guess I'm too much of a fan of heavier train games to be able to enjoy this properly, but to be honest it feels even lighter than ticket to ride. I just feel like it's a game of holding back to do what will benefit your opponents the least.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment:
I think this is a game that requires loving the theme. Truly, it's standard zombie-shtick, and for me that's awesome. Being a lover of the Walking Dead, I think it delivers even more strongly for me.
That all being said, this is a TOUGH coop; probably the toughest since Ghost Stories. Adding a traitor element. Ales it even harder, for both sides, and if your group is good at bluffing like ours is, there is serious tension added to the experience.
We are just a few plays in and the a-ah! Moments keep coming in rapid fashion. With the upcoming expansion I expect this not only to see table time, but consume us for some time to come.

item.name: Deluxe Pass the Pigs
item.comment:
Once in a blue moon this is fun.
The Good: Pig shaped dice and a dash of dexterity.
The Bad: Still simple and random. Not really much of a game but more of a gimmick.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment:
Doom given the fantasy treatment, and done right.
Despite many saying how "easy" this game is, I felt very in control as Overlord, and the game goes down to the bitter end.
Any "imbalances" in difficulty can easily be tweaked.
Another game that has had a map generator created, leaving almost endless play possibilities.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark Quest Compendium Volume One
Detroit-Cleveland Grand Prix
item.comment: It is what it is.....beer and pretzels racing.

item.name: Diamant
item.comment: Solid filler and great party game. Close cousins to both Can't Stop and Circus Flohcati.

item.name: Dogs of War
item.comment:
I honestly KS'd this one based on the designer and the one play through I saw. I had no certainty that I'd love this game, but I'm glad I got it, because I think it's quite good.
The play is fairly straight forward, combining tug of war games like Battline or Blood Bowl: Team Manager with the token collection and valuation of those tokens a-la Princes of the Renaissance. So there are 3 battles each round, worker placement which collects you cards, points, and tokens, and the result of each battle increases the value of the house whose side won, and ergo the value of the tokens increases.
My god are the decisions difficult. There's almost always 3 things you want to do at the same time, and ordering them is difficult and often gives something good away to another player. I find that a good thing as no one player can lock down all the good choices for themselves. There's also the matter of the captain you choose, or Dog of War, which has a special power and drives each players strategy a bit.
The game is WAY overproduced, but I love it for that as well.

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment:
Really the game is about area majority, set collection that results in majorities in adjacent "elements" for bonuses, and of course the main mechanism is worker placement. There is quite a bit of information, almost overwhelmingly so at first. You soon realize that you only need to focus on what you need and what will affect you. That boils each round down to a hand full of actions and a much more manageable amount of information.
Tentative 7 after we called the game 2/3 of the way through our first play. We want to play again. We played with 3 and I think the game will be better with more, while 3 might be best played with experienced players or the latter and all players using 2 animals.
I've read quite a bit about the end game scoring and given the volume of points that you gain, not to mention the game seems to be about gearing up for the end, we obviously missed a huge part of the game. We learned quite a bit, so it wasn't for naught. Perhaps another play will prove this a great game, or as it stands just an ok game that I had high hopes for.
Update:
Another play with 5 eliminated all my doubts and frustrations with DS. The game is brutal, requires detailed and abstract planning, and is almost completely unforgiving. Skilled players actually do have a chance to catch up and the game provides avenues to do so.
It's a shame that Mr. Jensen's games require several plays to simply understand the actual goals and the important aspects of the game. Some people might view that as part of the discovery but it certainly makes players feel lost and somewhat helpless in initial plays.
It's quite a game, easily in the top three heaviest games I've ever played, and with subsequent plays threatens to push into my top ten of all time.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment:
It's a really great game that I suck at. I predict my rating will rise with further plays. It's got 3 rules, it's easy to learn, and turns go lighting fast. It's the essence of constructed CCG play without the CCG.
Update:
More plays, rating rises to 9.
Update:
It's a 10.

item.name: Dominion: Alchemy
item.comment:
Overall the set has a handful of "very good" cards, however it all does come off somewhat samey in comparison to previous cards.
I'm actually liking this one the more I play it, however I do not think this set is either as useful or versatile as previous releases.
