It does seem that attempting strategies using Alchemy are frequently defeated by strategies that do not include cards from this set. Time will tell.

item.name: Dominion: Cornucopia
item.comment:
Cornucopia is the second in the line of "small box" Dominion expansions, which now means, I suppose, they will all have a quantity of cards some or all people do not like.
Unlike Alchemy, which had about 4 cards I would ever use again, there are only a few cards in this set I could do without. The reason in Alchemy was the use of the Potions, which I thought just took away from the game. Other cards were either too cruel or there were existing cards that didn't require a potion to acquire and had superior costing.
In the case of Cornucopia it's not quite the same. There are some cards that none of us would use at all. There are, however, some very nice additions to the game here.
One major note that lowers my overall score of Dominion when using this expansion: Also like Alchemy this does not seem to be a stand alone expansion. The game is VERY long unless you mix in cards from one of the 4 big box expansions and in future we certainly will treat it as such.

item.name: Dominion: Dark Ages
item.comment: Extending the added complexity of Hinterlands, Dark Ages adds even more layers to the luscious cake of Dominion.

item.name: Dominion: Hinterlands
item.comment: Simply the best and most game changing expansion since Seaside. It's the reason that I became strongly interested and motivated to play Dominion frequently again.

item.name: Dominion: Intrigue
item.comment:
This expansion really reinvents the game. It takes all of the core ideas to a whole new level and adds a plethora of new ones that make this expansion every bit as playable alone as the original was.
The added components will allow more players to play, which is a huge plus.

item.name: Dominion: Prosperity
item.comment: More Money, More Better.

item.name: Dominion: Seaside
item.comment:
Brilliant.
As the dev team continues to release new content the game continues to evolve into the vision that I think the designer had to begin with; in this respect I believe Dominion and RFtG are quite similar.
The game received several more layers and legs as long as it wishes to be.
And to think we still have 2 more planned expansions the second of whose theme is WAR.

item.name: Doom: The Boardgame
item.comment:
Fun run and gun action. Classic dice-fest, new age exploration. I love the idea of having a moderator run the bad guys.
Update: Descent knocked this down a peg or two to a 6.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Dos Rios
item.comment:
I was pleasantly surprised after almost being let down, however I was not at all taken with this game. The most unique aspect here is that its a racing game with an action point allowance system that also has a river whose course you can alter for fun and profit. The river itself is quit ingenious; however the scoring cards are random, but can come out in streaks to your negative benefit; especially later in the game when movement is much more limited.
Its a fine game thats for sure, and possibly one that will see play again, its just that I see more value in the mechanics and interactions than that of the overall play.

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment:
The first half of the game is all about hand management, while the last half is all about good tile placement with the lava, and careful consideration of which pieces to move first.
There is a large element of luck, but I have yet to lose a game after almost 10 plays, so that tells me there is more strategy here than meets the eye.
It's alot of fun, and as many other people have said, the chance to throw your opponents pieces into the volcano is just nasty fun.

item.name: Dragon Parade
item.comment:
It's random and silly, but damn is this little game ever fun!
If you are allergic to randomness and lack of control, steer clear, but it's so much fun....we laughed so hard as we played this...
item.conditiontext: Update: After a few more plays, there is ALOT more strategy than meets the eye. There is still a dose of luck, but it's more managable than I think most would suspect.

item.name: Dragonland
item.comment: Simple abstract from a not so simple designer.

item.name: Dream Factory
item.comment: Solid bidding from Knizia. You work at building the best valued sets, and try not to overpay in the auctions. The balancing mechanism of spreading the winner of the auction's payment is a nice touch in this game.

item.name: Dreamblade
item.comment:
Fantastic new minis game that feels like they melded chess and magic with a few other minis ideas.
What I especially like:
Preset board: no special movement ranges or measuring, or the like. Simple and easy. There is also a beginner's side of the board that has most of the starting rules on it, including reminders about important info.
Info: Everything you need to know is right on the base of the mini. a summary is on top of the base. All the bases are color coded for easy reference.
Quality: Simply the best non metallic minis I have ever seen. They have McFarlane toys quality paint jobs as well.
It's easy to learn too. The building of armies, just like deckbuilding in other games, is flexible, fun, and challenging.
Update: Now with the release of Night Fusion the game has definitely come into it's own. This is definitely the best set released thus far AS A WHOLE. It most certainly has some of the most powerful pieces in the game. Given this expansion, I have upgraded my rating to a 10.

item.name: Duck Dealer
item.comment:
Indeed this game is Merchant of Venus meets Neuland, but plays almost as long as both combined.
I think with experience that time could come down significantly but I'm just not certain that I want to play more than occasionally so it might never come down.
Further there are games that do this sort of thing better; one of which is their own design, R&B.
Better than it's given credit for even if it is butt ugly.

item.name: Duel in the Dark
item.comment:
It's game is a bit more of a 2 player abstract puzzle with a heavy theme than the war game it might first appear to be; it's not really war at all, there's no active combat.
I like the bit of guessing and deduction, though the advanced rules allow for adjustments during the actual play and other weather changes to occur to continue to shake things up.
The rules say it's longer than it is; perhaps with a ton of elements and still being new you'd take longer, but a round of this is still a 30 minute experience.
I actually think my rating will rise over time.

item.name: Duel in the Dark: Baby Blitz
Dungeon Lords
item.comment:
This game seems to be inspired by the great PC game Dungeon Keeper.
It retains all the flavor and feel of said game while taking the best of worker placement and Vlaada's own mechanics, as well as tensions, from Galaxy Trucker and Space Alert.
There's certainly a heaping serving of luck and screwage, and much of the "just survive" element in this game; but perhaps that's much of the charm. Further once you have mastered the combat the game becomes an effortless fun-fest, and you can bask in the glory of your own evil.
It's more than what I expected, and on flavor alone this would get a 9; however the play is quite nice, and promises even better as it has a major set of unused components whose purpose is as yet unrevealed.
Can this designer fail? Not yet at least.

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: Due by August 2013

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment:
Lots of strategy. Good dungeon crawl with NO LUCK. I am positive that my score will improve once I recieve my expansions in the mail.
Update:
Has not aged well under repeated plays. seems predicable and solvable.

item.name: DungeonQuest (third edition)
item.comment:
It's really just a game of either move and place a new tile or search. The rules are wonderful and every tile is simple to understand. Skill checks are a simple "roll two dice and hope you are equal or less than your score"; though failures are rewarded with determination tokens for your next try, which means eventually you will pass.
The catacombs are a side game like affair that really can make stunning advances or escapes in the dungeon.
Should be played quickly and with as little thought as possible. Its totally random and often times totally insane!
A fun hour romp that no one is likely to survive.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment:
This game is essentially a stripped down 4.0 rule set/minis; a good thing.
They created a really nifty monster AI system; a great thing.
It's totally coop without the need of a moderator; a great thing.
It can be played in 90 minutes or less with 5; an amazing thing.
Our first game was great! Looking forward to more. If you want a good dungeon crawl with all the D&D flavor in a short period of time, look no further.
The minis are also wonderful and seem ripe for replacement with their painted counter parts.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
The Dutch Golden Age
item.comment:
While this might scare most away, bear with me:
This game is like Roulette crossed with Slots.
The crazy part is that there are definite strategies and the game does a good job of mitigating it's own luck factor.
The outer track of the board is Roulette; two regions of the board pay out or everyone gets paid for one of 5 merchant or the king. There are cards you can gain to increase this payout. Every card that provides a bonus is keyed to a specific region, but also pays out on all merchants and king cumulatively.
The cards themselves are like slots. You activate regions where you have influence markers allowing for a random pull from that color deck. There's some set collection involved for some decks while one is all bonus vps or payout increases. There are however, ways to get multiple pulls, and the volume mitigates luck here.
The whole game is one big gamble yet it doesn't feel totally random nor a big mess.
One thing is for sure: This is one of Colovini's best.

item.name: Easy Come, Easy Go
item.comment: It's a filler...wadda ya want? Nice Yahtzee variant tho.

item.name: Eaten By Zombies!: In Cahoots
item.comment: More cards, more players, more fun. The new weapons, especially the Kickstarter stretch rewards, and simply wonderful additions to a fine game.

item.name: Eaten By Zombies!: We Have the Bomb! Promo
Eaten By Zombies!: Weapons of Mass Destruction
Eclipse
item.comment:
Eclipse is not the second coming of 4x as many would have you believe. It is, however, and interesting combination of old ideas. I believe the randomness of exploration and the reputation tiles will turn many players away while others will find ways to overcome those elements to see the neat system that lies underneath.
For me it is the simplicity and clarity of combat and the rules for it. I love the way the tech is handled and that you're not forced into a tree. The game encourages combat (though some would have you believe turtling still rules the day).

item.name: Egizia
item.comment:
I was thinking I should rate this lower but I just can't; it's simply much better than I could have ever hoped.
I know that sounds negative, but given the glut of worker placement games over the past few years, I'm sure many of you can identify with those feelings.
I think the genius in this game lies in the fact that the people furthest ahead go later in the turn, but the clincher is that the worker placement balances the turn order with only allowing you to place further down the river than your previous placements, making decisions quite tense.
While there are a number of random elements here, there is an equal number of predictable ways to gain vp's. I also like the nod to roads and boats in the pyramid scoring.
Count me pleasantly surprised.

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment:
Fantastic twist to the "Settlers Odds" system. Much more of a gamer's game than any other in the series IMHO, and many more ways to directly effect your opponents.
Update:
A little long for what it is, especially since experienced players can drive this to a weird end game. Perhaps it's our group think, but either way it's for trade.
item.conditiontext: Gently Used: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment:
It's an Arkham dice-based coop romp. There are some significant decisions to be had but none that should make the game play as long as the box says (1-2 hours???). It's a 30-45 minute dice fest with all the frills, spills, and tension of the very best dice games.
It's quality in every way, my only concern being that the game might be too easy for "advanced" players, IE people that game A LOT. Two plays in so that remains to be seen.

item.name: Elfenland
item.comment: A nice hand management game that uses a "programming" aspect like Robo Rally.

item.name: Empires of the Void
item.comment: Empires offers a more basic/pure 4x experience. Less fiddle, less turtle, yest still not as good as it should be. The issue is that it still plays in 2-2.5 hours and other games in our stable, like Eclipse, can be played with more bang for the buck. Further, the last few turns are min maxing which deflates an otherwise good experience to purely average.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment:
Improves on the Goa formula in almost every way. It has perfect information, player interaction, and a shorter play time. It steals Goa's 9 and Goa reduces to an 8.
Update:
Thought play has fallen off after 20+ games it's not something I would ever turn down. We've since gone back and played Goa and Industrial waste and this one seems to do things faster/lighter/better. You accomplish so much so fast. It would likely have gone up to a 9 or 10 if Hansa Teutonica had never come out.

item.name: Epic
item.comment:
It's a MtG pod that's been balanced. I'm pretty sure to get the most out of this game you have to draft.
That all being said, if you already play Magic I'm not sure why you'd play this.
I'd also add that multiplayer is REALLY long.

item.name: Eruption
item.comment:
I had thought I was getting into basically the latter half of Downfall of Pompeii wherein you draw random lava tiles to reduce your opponents possible score. In the most literal sense this is indeed what you're doing. This is not related to that experience in any other way, however. It's mainly trying to make best use of a lava tile, either offensively or defensively. You have to make some hard choices at times given that you harm others, or gain resources, or simply stem the tide of lava at your doorstep. Sometimes a play is a real gamble, which adds to the tension. The card play in the game is also multi-faceted and all cards are always useful. My favorite aspect of the game is that the more damage you take the greater the bonuses you have. It's even feasible to intentionally take damage or deal yourself damage simply to gain bonuses to strengthen your game.
So far with both 2 and 3 players this is quite a good game. It has moderate luck and moderate tactics. There are ways to make the game more strategic, found in the variants of the game, but I'm not sure I would want it to be. I'm interested in trying the game with all player counts. given that this goes to 6 I'm sure the chaos factor, and the utter insanity, will actually lead to a different kind of fun; or so I hope. With 2 or 3 the games were entirely different animals, in a very good way. This game has easily met my expectations and is a good deal of fun. It's also CHEAP, even at a FLGS, and the components are quite nice for the price.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment:
Simply the purest most adrenaline filled time pressure experience, which in many ways trumps Space Alert. I think the soundtrack is a must as the sand timer makes it more about time management, which seems dull to me.
I can't wait to try the included expansions, and I think this will have quite a number of plays before its popularity wanes with us.

item.name: Eye To Eye
item.comment: This is a fun, easy going, word game. It's definitely a slice of amaericana; it's easy to play, and fun for family and VERY casual gamers. It's silly fun, and almost total luck unless you know all of the players fairly well.

item.name: Factory Fun
item.comment:
If you enjoy puzzles, you'll love this game as much as I do.
This game is quite difficult, and will take several plays to ferret out the right strategy.

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: Solid drafting mixed with tons of synergy. It plays fast an furious, and you can get consistent gameplay from this one. I must have played this one at least 50+ times and I still love it as much as I did on day 1.

item.name: Famiglia
item.comment:
Simply one of the best two players games to come down the pike in a very long time. This game honors the very best that is the heritage established by the Kosmos two player line.
It's really a game of hand/deck/tableau building. If there are no zero value cards on the board you can discard a card from the display. You add back cards from the draw pile equal to the value of the one you discarded. There are 3 factions. One acts as a joker, one as a discount, one can return cards you used to your hand, and the last is just worth more points than any other faction. The game is played by playing a pair of the same faction and value which allows you to pick up a card of a value one higher. The card you gain and one of the cards you used to gain it return to your hand, the remaining card is placed face up in your tableau. The trick to the game is: clever use of jokers and returning them to your hand, using the discounts in concert with this or making the cards zero value (you can pick up zeros for nothing), and timely use of the faction that allows you to return used cards form your tableau. It's actually much more diabolical that it seems, and much more complex than first blush.
Awesome Maura art tied into a wonderful efficiency engine makes for a very wonderful game. There are a ton of tough choices. Often times you have to play a bit of a push your luck game. The first half is totally random, but the second time through the deck, given that you have a decent memory, you can actually have some foresight as to possible draws.

item.name: Family Business
item.comment: It's a take that game with elimination. Fun if played quickly.

item.name: The Farming Game
item.comment:
Is there any way to rate this lower? Jesus Christ, this old roll and move we Americans came up with is so very perverted in this form, even worse than with careers or monopoly. They suck too, but they don't last quite as long as this load of bat dung.
The Good: Colorforms
The Bad: Playing it

item.name: Fast Flowing Forest Fellers
item.comment:
Take Robo Rally, make the moves strictly steps (no turns per se), make the obstacles only conveyors that move you backwards, and the play time 30 minutes.
Fast, fun, dirty, and modular (replayable).
Recommended.

item.name: Fealty
item.comment:
A rather deceptively complex abstract that takes at least a few plays before you understand the long term ramifications of placement.
You simply have to be aware of what the tile is, how it gathers points and how to place it so that you at least get a few points for it. An average of 5 per piece will win you the game, so it's easy to think "oh I would have gotten 15 before I was surrounded, now I get 2" but it's the big picture that experience brings.
Combined with having yet another complete variant set included in the box there's long legs in this box; the box is a bit oversized though :)

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment: Good random fun (with room for a bit of strategy). I die alot. The more players the better on this one.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment:
Fast paced bluffing and bidding. There's a lot to be said for knowing your fellow players as well. Given that everyone has the same hand, and that only 10 of the 11 cards will get played, this game is about 60% strategy and 40% luck. I like this one a lot and it's soon to become a fast favorite IMHO.
Update:
After a few plays this one never caught on. Much like High Society the system is love or hate; almost everyone in my group hates both.

item.name: Feudality
item.comment:
At first this appears a random mess; actually quite a bit of it is still random. There is, however, some control when it comes to surviving the events but it seems somewhat separated from the rest of your game and your "strategy". It's certainly more of an old-school romp and that's what should be expected. Hell, GARY FREAKING GYGAX WAS A PLAYTESTER!
Someone in the forums mentioned statistical probability of the two dice and that there is a zone for best placement of new tiles. I cannot imagine finding a statistically probable zone given that you are not combining the values of the two dice rolled rather you are creating coordinates.
We all enjoyed our first experience and look to see if a second game makes this rise or fall in opinion.

item.name: Finca
item.comment:
This is a wonderful game for 2-4 in 45 minutes. It combines a "rondel light" with the movement of Downfall of Pompeii and payouts of Cartagena.
Played twice in it's first outing, it offers a bit more strategy than you'd expect.
It's a fun romp that should last for quite a while; though we'll see which is why it's got a provisional 7.
Update: While there are a few elements of chaos here, there's certainly enough strategy for the long term. 6 Plays and counting :) Upped rating to an 8.

item.name: Fist of Dragonstones
item.comment: I'm a sucker for Bruno...I like this one played using the 6-sided dice/random auction variant posted on his site.

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment:
Wow. So they went and made super-thinky mancala with a ton of ways to gain points. I like it.
Every game feels different, and AP aside, is generally fast and interesting. I never imagined that DoW would make a true gamer's game, but here it is.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment:
My initial rating was a 6, as this game simply didn't excite me like I expected it to. That ate at me, and drove me to keep trying for some reason; that and we hadn't actually won, so there HAD to be something more.
THERE IS MORE. My rating rose to a 7. So this isn't a wonderous original game, but it's a very good game that has some subtle signs you have to train yourself to observe. The role switching is certainly this game's unique contribution as you really MUST switch roles at some point otherwise you will fail.
There have been times of being seemingly way ahead and some crazy circumstances happening. It at first appeared luck, but then we recognized some signs and realized where we had gone wrong.
What does all this add up to? A game that's seriously growing on me and that I want to play more. It plays in 30-40 minutes, so that's a REAL plus for something is dynamic.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue Dangerous Waters
Flash Point: Fire Rescue Extreme Danger
Flash Point: Fire Rescue Honor & Duty
Flash Point: Fire Rescue Urban Structures
Flash Point: Fire Rescue Veteran and Rescue Dog
Fleet
item.comment:
Fleet is an interesting mix. It has the auction system of Power Grid, though no replenishment between the auctions, and it has the tableau building plus the engine building of Race for the Galaxy.
It's clean and simple yet still feels a bit meaty and gives a satisfying sense of accomplishment; all in a 30-40 minute play time.
The only downer is that the theme isn't very exciting, but the game is good enough that it doesn't detract from the experience either.
My rating may yet go up with more plays and use of the expansion materials, which are surprisingly modular.
item.wishlistcomment: Kickstarted - Due December 2013 - Delayed to February/March

item.name: Fleet: Arctic Bounty
item.wishlistcomment: Kickstarted - Due December 2013 - Delayed to February/March

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment: Random fun. Easy on the brain. VERY good casual party game.

item.name: Foppen
item.comment: What a fantastic little trick taking game! The unique mechanic in the Foppen token just makes it all come together, blended well with the different quantities of cards in each suit.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Probably one of the best fillers I own. Fast and fun. I love the combination of open auction melded into blind bidding. Plenty of room for strategy, minimal luck (luck only exists in the blind bidding).

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment:
Take Pandemic, simplify it to the nth degree. It's distilled to it's essence; and essence I very much enjoy.
Plays quickly and differently enough to be worth owning.
Perhaps even more random that can cause more screwage or an easier game.

item.name: Formula D
item.comment:
I think it's actually an improvement on the original system in terms of added options, quality, and variety; especially with the new road races (which everyone might not like).
I'm just glad to see the series revived and with regular expansions on the way.

item.name: Formula D: Circuits 2 Hockenheim and Valencia
Formula D: Circuits 3 Singapore & The Docks
Formula D
item.comment: This game's a nice blend of dice luck and planning. Future plays with the advanced rules can only serve to deepen the experience.

item.name: Founding Fathers
item.comment:
A very simplified multiplayer version of Twilight Struggle or even 1960.
Still lots of room for strategy. Generally can be a very close game. Plays quickly.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment:
Lies on the fence of cube pusher/luck fest and decent game.
The central tiles are the cause for concern though the added strategy of the mixing of paints is a nice touch.
Played with all variants this is quite a good game....so far.

item.name: Freya's Folly
item.comment: I like the ability cards and the movement mechanics of this one. It's kind of a distant cousin to Cartagena.

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment:
It's Sims the board game, and it's loads of fun. I just wish the rules were better written.
Update: After several more plays the seeming depth just isn't there. The call tokens are a joke, and seem almost meaningless. The game also overstays it's welcome, then ends so abruptly the best thing that can be said is "what should we play next".
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Frstenfeld
item.comment:
Won at Euroquest 2010!!!
Tentative 7, played with 2, 3, and 4; best with 4 so far.
Interesting game of weighing using the bonus cards for their advantages versus saving the money to create a pool and eventually build the monuments.
It's kind of like starting a deck building game half way through but with a stock market mechanism and tableau management. Totally unexpected and much better than I had first believed.
I'm totally uncertain of any firm strategy but I can certainly say that as long as this is played at a 45 minute maximum then it's a fine game.
Update:
The advanced game makes this one a 9. It's worth playing the basic rules to understand the game, the buildings, and the overall flow of the game.
Playing with the advanced rules makes the game shorter, much more intense, and previewing 1/3 of your deck, then seeing additional cards and brings your total to seeing half your deck, allows for some serious planning, precognition, and if your memory serves you well, strategy.
I'm certain this game will fool most into thinking there's nothing there at all. I find it a shame when games use the basic version as the default when the real meat and potatoes is listed at the end of the rules as an advanced version.
Update:
Repeated plays really show this one as a consistent performer both as a game and in plays with our group.

item.name: Fzzzt!
item.comment:
Using the cards in your hand you bid. Cards won become part of your deck. Eight cards are auctioned a round. You start each round with 6 cards. you do not get more cards unless all players run out, in which case discards and remaining deck are reshuffled and hands are refilled to 6 (I haven't seen this yet).
It's a minor deck building element coupled with auction and set collection for end game bonuses.
It's fast, it's easy, and it's quite fun. Totally unique as a filler in its' style and implementation of its' mechanics.

item.name: Galactic Emperor
item.comment:
There's more here akin to Twilight Imperium than any other game. It's lighter, faster, and easier to get into, but still has a wealth of avenues to victory. It's also VERY easy on the eyes.
Interestingly it has an exploration option that works very similarly to Big Kini...another game I like.
It's not "original" in the most common sense, but what it does do is deliver a solid, tense, fun game, with plenty of opportunity for player interaction.
Update:
Eclipse just upped the ante and made this game irrelevant.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: You can't take this game too seriously, otherwise you will hate it. If you play it for fun, with a dash of strategy, you came to the right place. I do have to specify that you can mitigate your luck in 2 ways: you can look at the event cards so you know what's coming (even though you sacrifice build time, and you get to know the cards over a few plays anyway), and as you get better at building.

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: I think that this is a very good game, but where it failed my wife and I was the 3 decks of cards. the chaos there led to some very badly timed moments that tarnished the bright outlook we had for the game. By the end things evened out a bit, but the chaos left a bad taste in my mouth.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment:
Tentative 8, rating might rise.
Easily the most complex card game I have ever played.
Update:
Now it's a 9. Plays as well with three as it does 4.
Update:
It's a 10. Simply the best multiplayer constructible game I've ever played. The more I dig into it the more I see that I didn't know. Everyone in our group that's played loves it.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game
item.comment: Second set for duplicates and triplicates.

A Game of Thrones: The Card Game Trial by Combat
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game Valar Dohaeris
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game Valar Morghulis
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game Where Loyalty Lies
A Game of Thrones: The Card Game Wolves of the North
Gang of Four
item.comment: Nice ladder game that offers flexibility to play with either 3 or 4. I like that it offers as much depth as it's partnership based cousins, but allows for individual play.

item.name: Gassy Gus
item.comment:
It's a simple random kids game about farting that takes 2 minutes to play.
The Good: Fart noises and fast play time
The Bad: Totally random and pointless

item.name: Gears of War: The Board Game
item.comment:
Take the AI driven games that Wizards made (Ravenloft and Ashardalon) and amp them up.
The game maintains the simplicity while adding difficulty and several new mechanics like cover and range to the formula. The entire "level" is built and populated making the experience more intense as the whole board marches toward you. I also like the idea of the quadruple use command cards, that work roughly like the Command and Colors system; Your hand is your life total, how you use special actions, how you perform regular actions, and perform reactions.
Corey continues to be a designer to watch. OH, and did I mention the BEAUTIFUL bits and the wonderful art on the cards and tiles?

item.name: Genoa
item.comment: Sweet talk is king in this game. Barter, barter, bargain, and swindle! Try ato get the best bang for your trading buck/resource, and try not to give the "best" actions away. This one is for those who don't mind games where you have to trade to win.

item.name: Gheos
item.comment:
This is a fast paced strategy game that encourages conflict. Since you aren't building features per say, and you can take any color resource cube you wish when you build, added to the fact that you can build over almost any existing tile, makes this game different from any I have seen before. This is NOTHING LIKE CARCASSONNE!
Update: Another play and even more ways this game can play out. Tile luck is minimal as you have to gamble if what you've done will last another turn or whether to score now! Another interesting element is that you always have a stock of two tiles in front of you, so you can always hold onto a tile for the right moment. This is definately a quality game, but stay away if you don't enjoy conflict.
On another side bar, David Fair told me he had made 3o some odd points in one go, and I thought that was outrageous...until I scored 42 in one shot!
Fun, fast,....oh yeah, and fun.

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment:
Like Pandemic? Then I'm thinking this is another coop you need to play. It allows for more independent thought and action, and gives a wider variety of things that you can do/accomplish. It's also beautiful.
I think it scales even better in terms of difficulty, and that there is less luck that drives your win/loss.

item.name: Ghost Stories: The Village People Expansion
Ghost Stories: White Moon
item.comment:
While I'm certain there's something to be said for the new tools provided for the Monks there also a heightened level of difficulty if you haven't already consistently done well, or at least started to play on a higher difficulty.
In any case, I like the way it shakes the game up, I like the ghosts it adds, and look forward to playing it more when we are "ready".

item.name: Giants
item.comment: A little long, and a bit fiddly. We also forgot to had out the bonuses for using other peoples pieces for movement; which actually seems like it would add chaos and perhaps a lack of predictability or calculability to the game. Another play will flesh it out.

item.name: Gipsy King
item.comment: I like the concept, but I need to see how this plays with a full compliment.

item.name: Glass Road
item.comment:
So what we have here was an apparent rework of a mechanic from Witch's Brew that apparently is actually from an older game that Ewe created; go figure.
Many people have said there are few choices, but I actually disagree. Of course, those choices and your planning can be largely mitigated or accelerated by opponents' card play.
For some reason this game grabs me. Not in a huge way, but what I found interesting in Witch's and chose to leave behind is much better developed and diversified in this game.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment:
WOW! A very nice card game in the same vein as San Juan and RftG, with a totally different spin on things.
Some really nice, smooth play and interesting interactions.
Should cure my Race burnout for a while, and in tandem with Race almost certainly assures that San Juan won't see much play again.
Update:
Took some time away after a handful of plays of this. Playing other games by this designer, more RftG, and a number of other games really renewed my interest and all those combined skill in the game.
In all the game is much shorter for our gaming experience not to mention MUCH FASTER. Play time is down to the 40 minute mark.

item.name: Go
item.comment: Simple abstract elegance.

item.name: Go West!
item.comment:
While my geek buddies would have me believe that choas rules the day our first play was quite the opposite. You cannot spend multiple turns building up; you cannot form a very long term strategy at all. You can however invest your self across multiple areas, save resources for scoring, and at an opportune moment strike while the iron is hot.
I'm certain some are frustrated when they do not make large gains or when other players catch up, but it's the small points here and there, not to mention the most efficacious use of your double move that will win you the game.

item.name: Goa
item.comment: I love of all the decision agony. There are many avenues to victory.

item.name: Godzilla: Kaiju World Wars
item.comment:
As most other reviews you might read, this too is a negative opinion. I actually went into this game after having read the other opinions, so I had no illusions that this might be a GREAT game, but certainly GOOD would have been nice.
I think the main issue is that the advanced cards only serve to muddy a good, basic system. The basic cards are superior for what your trying to do. Another issue is direct interaction. This game should be all about it, but ultimately serves up a bland point-fest. Even smashing buildings isn't all that fun.
We'll try again in teams to see if that spices things up, but my hopes are VERY low.

item.name: Goldbru
item.comment:
I loved this game at first as I thought it was vicious, and full of conflict. That assessment has not changed over time, but the sheen has dulled over the years.
I love the area control, and I love the majorties game inherent to the system.
I hate the random luck of "who gets to do an action twice", and the share cards.
A recent play has brought me to the conclusion that the card luck is VERY difficult to overcome in this game. Therefore the rating as plummeted to a 6, and is probably soon to be an ex-game in my collection.
item.conditiontext: Gently Used: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Gonzaga
item.comment:
One part route building and another part set collection.
Hidden goals add purpose like long routes in TtR (more like the ones in Europe).
Abstract, thinky, and scales very well.

item.name: GOSU
item.comment:
Gosu is about building the most valuable tableau. After everyone passes for the round tableaus are evaluated (quite easily) and the winner gets a vp. Win 3 vps and win the game.
There are quite a few nods to MtG here. I'm a huge goblin fan from my Magic days so this certainly doesn't hurt my enthusiasm about the game.
There is room for both long term strategy and short term tactics amid the chaos that this game is. I also like to say "what goes around comes around" as it always seems to even out luck-wise in the long run.
Good, tempered, hand management, and clever use of synergy rule the day.
item.wishlistcomment: Due out in September. Uses a cool Goblin theme and wonderful art. Tableau builder.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment:
Played 2 times with 2 players. I love area control games.....which means I love this game. I am POSITIVE my rating will go up after I play with more players.
Update: several games later, a couple with 4. This might be a 10 with 5, but so far rates a 9 in my book.

item.name: The Great Dalmuti
item.comment: Pardon the vernacular, but for those of us who know; anyone who has played the drinking game asshole has played something much akin to this game. The only difference being that there are 12 suits (numbered one thru 12) rather than 4. The number of the suit relating the quanitiy of that card in the deck. A basic game with a mild amount of strategy. Luck wins out the day for the most part, but its a fun romp with a group of friends, that doesn't try to take itself to seriously, as you do not keep score.

item.name: The Great Zimbabwe
item.comment:
It's funny, my first instinct was to compare this to Neuland; which itself is an omage to Roads and Boats.
Essentially you have a abstract quasi-pick-up-and-deliver game with special powers. It's fast and intense, the only real down side is for those who have poor spatial visualization skills, who'll have trouble plotting their turns and the costs involved.
Otherwise we have a fine addition to the Splotter stable.

item.name: Greed
item.comment:
This is a somewhat generic drafting game, though it's cleaner and simpler than 7 Wonders or even Fairy Tale. The spin in this game is the combos. Much like you would combo in Dominion within your deck build, this game has you doing it a bit more openly within a tableau. The downside is that some combos work better than others given certain player counts. Another negative is that while some combos are really great the draw back is that they make certain lackluster ones amazing in the face of them, basically giving away the game.
Perhaps with more plays timing will be a bigger element, balancing out the negatives I see. Overall a decent enough filler that we do enjoy.

item.name: Greed Incorporated
item.comment:
I'm going to give this a tentative 8. That could easily rise or fall with additional plays depending on how things play out. As of right now all those involved in the first play though there was PLENTY more we could have done, certianly more corps would have changed control, more would have been created, and in the end the game would have evolved more.
The best thing so far is that everyone wants to play again. There's some negotiation, which we all quite like, there's SOME control in terms of which corps you get into (though not much); I think it's a question of gambits in hopes to get into particular compnaies by playing cards that serve them best and once you get a chance to be the CEO then acting out your vision for the best cash until you can bail for the big payout.
One disappointment is that there's only an illusion that you're controlling the market. In the end the market swells and then recedes at a given rate and I do not see that changing much from game to game.
I think this is certainly a game for those who also enjoy Imperial, yet it's more the economics and less the board play.

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment: Name one other game that has a Piss Boy...

item.name: Gulo Gulo
item.comment:
This is one of the most fun games in my collection!
If you have been holding off on purchasing this game, stop waiting. This game is so much fun that no matter who wins everyone is a winner.

item.name: Hacienda
item.comment:
Anyone who says that this one is unoriginal is full of it. What game has so many familar elements blended together in such a unique way.
Someone said it was just average.
Well to that I say, an average Kramer is most of anyone else's masterpiece.

item.name: Hamburgum
item.comment: Certainly another great game, as I continue to love the Rondel. This one is totally different, being a more building and majorities game with special scorings smattered throughout. It's amazing how the same mechanism, and even slightly different takes on the same base concepts serve up a totally new experience. Very brain melty to boot. Will certainly rise in rating with more plays.

item.name: Hamsterrolle
item.comment: An interesting mix of dexterity and luck. I will have to play this a few more times to see just how predictable the gameplay will become, but the sheer amusement I have found in it so far is incredible.

item.name: The Hanging Gardens
item.comment:
Alternate turns, plays cards, take tiles if you score. Rise, repeat.
Too light, too luck based, too long for what it is.
The Good: Set collection and creative hand management for building sites.
The Bad: Random bonus tiles that instantly change the tide of the game.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment:
Definately needs more play to work out the intricacies.
Rating raised to an 8: Subtley ingenious. Gets better with every play....best with 4.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment:
Absolutely solid game. While using a version of the sliding scale mechanism from Goa and Endeavor, yet maintaining yet another different interpretation, this game couples that with what is essentially worker placement, majorities, and hand management; yet in a whole new fashion that I have never seen.
The game is fast paced and tense, and quite fun. I expect my rating to rise.
UPDATE:
Now a 10. Are ya happy Jonathan? =p

item.name: Hansa Teutonica: East Expansion
item.comment:
Steding returns to bring us another map for one of my favorite games.
The "action" cities are re-imagined, rearranged, recombined, and much harder to commandeer to rush the game clock. Permanent bonuses are on the board now with new and more powerful abilities.
Overall the new board serves to shake things up for experienced players and perhaps even attempt to mitigate negatives detractors have served up in the past; successfully I might add.
I still like the base map but after almost two dozen plays I was ready for a change of pace and Steding did not disappoint.
Perhaps after a number of plays I'll revisit the original map to see how the new secondary expansion, the cards, shakes things up.
item.wishlistcomment: Must have. Look for reasonable import though looks like Z-Man will also publish.

item.name: Harbour
item.comment:
I played this a dozen times with all player counts before publication and overall opinions were favorable. Sometimes it seemed a blowout but that's just the way the scoring in this game works.
Having played the final version it's basically the same game with some end game bonuses. Our last game was VERY close, then ended in an 11 point difference in the end. It felt almost impossible to deny the leader. Perhaps that's just an exception, hopefully time will tell. I would just hate for close games to suddenly become a runaway in the latter half of the game.

item.name: Hart an der Grenze
item.comment: An amazingly good bluffing, hand management, and semi-deduction game. Plays light, medium length, and with enough people to make it a riot.

item.name: Havoc: The Hundred Years War
item.comment: There's alot more meat on the bones of this game than I had ever expected! It goes by poker hands for the conflicts, but adds many more combinations to flesh out 17 types of hands you can have (topping out at a 6 card straight flush).

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment:
I'm going to hate this game.
I'll hate it so much that I'll buy the German edition so I can play it before an English release. I might even hate it so much that I do full color paste-ups.
I KNOW I will hate it enough to buy the English edition as well.
Update:
It's Agricola's cousin Sally; the HOT cousin. She likes you, and you'l love her right back.
The actions are buildings, and while there are some centralized actions, the majority are spread between the players as they "build" them. It can be a bit tougher to know what your options are at a glance, but there are MORE options, MORE synergy, and MORE avenues to victory. There are also more bits in this one than Agricola.
Play time is relatively the same, though I think the learning curve longer.
Update Update:
Ewe is 2 for 2. Amazing. Fantastic, multipathed system. I'm enjoying this one just as much as Agricola.

item.name: Heimlich & Co.
item.comment:
Great fun for up to 7 though likely 5 is the ceiling. Playing with the Top Secret Cards and Dossiers is not only fun but a MUST.
Some might say deduction has evolved past this yet this is simple, fast, and accommodates a larger number of players.

item.name: Hermagor
item.comment: This game has a lot in common with a few games out there, in large part Elfenland. I've liked this game a lot, though it does play longer than I'd like for that it is. Still, it doesn't feel that long once it's all said and done.

item.name: Heroes of Graxia
item.comment:
It's one part Ascension, in it's tactical nature and buy/combat row; yet you're building a tableau and can attack other player's tableau/army for points, which is another way to reach an end game condition.
It's strange that those two games have so many similarities yet came out at the same time.
I think I'm leaning toward Graxia a bit more yet Ascension has such a short play time and setup/breakdown to it's advantage.

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
item.comment: Fast, fun, and Cool minis. Little long on the set-up though.

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
Hey, That's My Fish!
item.comment: A fast light ans easy abstract with a heck of alot more depth than would first appear.

item.name: High Bohn Plus
item.comment: I like the buildings and order cards, but can leave the rest. It does make the game significantly longer, but in many ways better. I can see this being used occasionally.

item.name: High Society
item.comment: The strategy is driven by how much do you think you can afford to spend. I still haven't won a game because I always spend too much. It's pure auction, and the little "poorest loses" mechanic is brilliant.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: There's alot more strategy here than meets the eye. The game is simple, the builds it's own board. I bought the bakelite version which seems way cooler than the old wood one.

item.name: Homesteaders
item.comment:
Simple Amun Re building with decentralized Caylus style actions, yet with Puerto Rico production and bonuses; all in 10 short rounds.
One word: INTENSE.
Component quality was sub par, but the price point and game play made up for it in spades.

item.name: I'm the Boss!
item.comment:
I like the mechanisms present in this game, and the negotiation suits me.
On the other hand, people tend to play favorites, so it's easy for some negotiations to be a bit predictable, though I'm sure with more plays that will even out.

item.name: Ice Flow
item.comment:
Neat little racing game that requires an abstract mind. I particularly like how you can bounce the polar bears around the board a bit, either sending them back at the "attacker" or even off the board to reduce the threat of them altogether.
Really sings thematically and visually.

item.name: If Wishes Were Fishes!
item.comment:
Better than most give it credit for. It's one part luck and two parts strategy.
I especially love the duality of the fishes.

item.name: Igel rgern
item.comment: Solid game, lots of luck with a dash of strategy....not to mention a boatload of variants.

item.name: IGOR: The Mad Scientist's Lament
item.comment: Bwah-ha-ha-ha-ha!! I like the outrageous powers....though it can drag a bit with more or less than 4. I had never seen a tile laying card game before this.

item.name: Iliad
item.comment: There's alot more strategy than meets the eye in this hand-management/take-that card game. I especially love playing this with teams.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment:
Really great stock market game with some area control aspects. Will need to play again with the Investor card variant to see if it's so much better; though I'm not sold on it improving the game, only changing things drastically.
It's not as heavy as it was billed, it also isn't the best Rondel game IMHO.
Quite good, starts out at an 8.

item.name: Imperial 2030
item.comment:
I would never have imagined that, while there are some significant differences, this game would be SO similar to the original. I certainly need to go back and play that game again, but for all intents purposes I think the map alone makes this a superior animal.
One thing I have never tried though is the investor variant, and having played this series again I can think of so many reasons that I might want to play either way. There are some incredible timing considerations when playing with it, and I feel like there might be too many changes to control of nations without it; so what I'm saying is that, at this point, I think I'm in favor of the investor.

item.name: Impulse
item.comment:
PNP Version
Update:
For really-real version!

item.name: In the Shadow of the Emperor
item.comment:
We aborted a 3 player game mid stream as no one had any understanding of the meaning of any of the decisions we were making; there didn't really seem to be any. We were also having no fun. It's the most convoluted mess I've ever played.
The rule book was a mess, and it took 3 player aids/summaries/sets of clarifications to even get into the game.
This game was a cardboard travesty. A shame really as this was on the back burner since it's release and was highly anticipated.

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment:
Bears a vague similarity to Pillars, but vague might be too strong a term. This game has tension throughout, and is incredibly well balanced with a pleathora of strategies available.
Update: After further play I've found that the latter half of the game can become somewhat procedural and in a way predictable. Many of the choices lose any worth.
There's also an issue that you can be behind and stay behind.
It's really not bad for something occasionally played.

item.name: Indonesia
item.comment: Geat economics game with tons of conflict and treachery. More plays needed to se if it's the ten I think it is.

item.name: Industria
item.comment: The auctions can turn into "which tile do I want"....then again if you want money you have to auction something other people want. More play will prove better or worse here. UPDATE: now a 7.5 from 6....much better with sucessive plays...best with 4 IMHO.

item.name: Industrial Waste
item.comment: Some agonizing decisions....no "right" way to win. Tight money.

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: The more I play the more I like it. Abstract placement game with scoring like T&E.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
PRE-RELEASE COPY
Since all 105 cards are unique and totally random draws, not to mention some of the effects can cause a bit of chaos; this game is not for the feint of heart.
That being said there is a TON of strategy in the game. Experienced players know when to change cards, activate dogmas, and more.
It's really a fun experience. The only downside is that it does take some experience to get the play time down from 15 minutes a player, but that's hardly a bad thing.
I'm thinking my rating will rise.
Update:
Rating rose to a 9. There is far more control here if you invest time in learning the cards. It's just like playing Race or Dominion; card knowledge is key.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
FINAL PRODUCTION COPY
Minor improvements in card abilities, phrasing, cards stock, and card coloring.

item.name: Innovation: Echoes of the Past
item.comment:
Takes Innovation to the next level. While the game does have some front end load time, EotP does it extend that a bit; while with practice it's negligible.
A larger number of available symbols seemingly evens out the odds letting players either even out or specialize. Further, bonus icons add a new dimension to the score system. Finally, Echos cap off the clever factor by allowing monumentally momentous turns taking this game to a 10.

item.name: Innovation: Figures in the Sand
item.comment:
I won't kid you, adding this to the game does make it longer and definitely more complicated, yet it adds so many new options and avenues that I never want to play without it again. We actually play with the whole set, which makes for a 90 minute game (which we love) but the complexity is high and definitely not for everyone. We have tried Figures with just the base game and it's awesome with that as well.
I can't wait to see what the next expansion brings.

item.name: Intrigue
item.comment: This game is unadulterated evil. And I do so like evil. If you're afraid of conflict, shy away from this one.

item.name: It's Alive!
item.comment: Simple, fast, set collection that should be used with the advanced rules for best results otherwise you get a random ending that's totally unsatisfying rather than a strategy driven game of choice.

item.name: Jamaica
item.comment: It's a pirate racing game for up to 6 players that plays in an hour or less. It's stunningly beautiful, easy to learn, and fun to play.
item.conditiontext:
I find it beautiful, light, luck based (with a smattering of hand management and strategy), and extremely fun.
If you don't overthink it, a game, even with 5 players, zips by in 40 minutes.
Very fun racing game. It got 4 plays in the first weekend I owned it.

item.name: Jambo
item.comment:
Perhaps my favorite of the 2-Player Series.
It's an action point system wherein you try to develop a card advantage engine ultimately allowing you to sell more and win. There are slight variances to the strategy, but that is it's core.
The game can be lighting fast. Hoping to nab the expansions some time soon.

item.name: Jambo Expansion 2
item.comment: While you should own both expansions, this is the one with the most content and truly makes the game feel complete.

item.name: Java
item.comment:
One of Kramer's best. I love the action point system games he creates and further love it when games create a 3d landscape as pieces are placed.
You can certainly see where Taluva got it's inspiration.

item.name: Kablamo
item.comment: Very random and chaotic. I love it when I kill myself perhaps more than when I get others to eat the live ammo :)

item.name: Kaivai
item.comment:
The game's economy feels almost artifically tight, and some of the mechanisms feel forced. Many times, bidding was a matter of "Player a bids 1, b goes 2, and c goes 3"; it uses the same mechanism as New England, which has a flaw.
The overall idea was good, but future plays will either redeem this one, or put it on the trade pile.
And yes, the box is too damn big.

item.name: Kaosball: The Fantasy Sport of Total Domination
item.comment:
First:
- If you're expecting GW or Reaper quality you're kidding yourself for this money
- If you're expecting a sports game it's not that at all, it's more of a combat game crossed with a king of the hill game
Talk about exceeding expectations! The miniatures are easily the best I've seen in anything other than FF stuff and the Ringers are multi-piece molds, so they're more detailed than that. The quality throughout is great and a few plays already shows the depth it has.
The game itself plays like a couple of multiplayer modes from first person shooters. One mode it plays like is king of the hill. If you can get a runner to remain on a scoring zone at the end of a round/period you get points. The other mode it plays like is Skull from Halo, which is "hold onto the ball and get points the longer you do". How that translates here is when a runner is on a scoring zone with the ball, instead of scoring at the end of a round they score at the beginning of each turn for that player.
There's a ton of micro customization, most similar to Star Wars: X-Wing, though you bid for the handful of upgrades and ringers (super duper players with a special ability) with a meager amount of money. You'll also use that cash for getting rid of cheating cards to avoid penalty points, so money is TIGHT.
Everything plays out in an hour or less; even our very first game only took about 60 minutes. It's another win for Eric Lang, and it's a complete system, so it's going to be a joy to explore.
[hr]
[b][u]Core Team Ratings:[/u][/b]
[b]Ogres:[/b] 8 - Stomp is HIGHLY subjective, and often useless. When they're ON they are ON.
[b]Amazons:[/b] 9 - Wow, what an evil ability, and a +2 fight makes them tough to outlast.
[b]Demons:[/b] 10 - The easiest core team to play as, though I think in the long run they might have a predictable strategy.
[b]Fangs:[/b] 10 - Their stats are awesome, and their ability keeps them coming back at you with little fear.
[hr]
[b][u]Core Ringer Ratings:[/u][/b]
[b]Macho Libre:[/b] 10 - You want a team that can tackle, but in the long run he'll help outscore you, and if you're not getting kill points he will help will ruin you before the half.
[b]Dragon:[/b] 10 - Another killer ringer. 8 move on a sprint, 9 with one speed training, 10 with 2. What team is Dragon NOT good for?
[b]Cretin[/b] UNPLAYED
[b]T-Bone:[/b] 8 - One high priority tackle target, of course he does basically negate being attacked and a couple of the teams love his auto-heal. T-Bone + Brick = Madness
[b]Spectre[/b] UNPLAYED
[b]Zorra[/b] UNPLAYED
[b]Kong Bad (AKA Thrilla Gorilla):[/b] UNPLAYED
[b]Pandamonium:[/b] 9- The big dumb panda makes you hate reacting, and it's awesome...if he's your ringer. :)

item.name: Keltis
item.comment: A light and fast multiplayer take on Lost Cities without the calculability or tempo manipulation.

item.name: Kemet
item.comment: This might be the quintessential dudes on a map game. It's all about the tech and combat. If you're shy of conflict, you need not apply. Another great part of the game is that it doesn't overstay it's welcome; there are just too many ways to get points for that to ever happen.

item.name: Key Harvest
item.comment:
While one of Breese's lesser games it's still not a bad one.
It's quite abstract and with almost all of the pertinent information decentralized and somewhat visually hard to track, it can be a little difficult to gather intel for your next move.
Another negative is that you essentially have to wait for your turn to plan as tiles can be stolen and the ones you had up for auction or others you hoped to buy may no longer be present.
I did enjoy my play and as long as the play time and downtime between turns reduces with future plays it will certainly remain in circulation.

item.name: Key Market
item.comment:
I spent the first half of my first play thinking "is this all there is?". I continued to wonder about the marginal gains everyone was making. I continued to be unenthusiastic.
The second half of the game was an awakening. I had developed a rhythm for putting workers on the board and when to take them off. I had promoted workers in my guilds. I had also gotten good and arranging the turn order I needed. Indeed the game blossomed into everything I had hoped, even if our first play was a little long.
So we have Breese's classic interpretation of resource gathering and worker placement combined with a ladder climbing affair coupled with resource management. In all, as long as the play times come down I certainly look forward to playing this for many games to come.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment:
Even though this game is not 100% Breese it's still the best Breese game since Reef Encounter.
I love the combination of elements that seem to be derived from other games, but still they're used here in a unique way. It certainly doesn't feel like anything else in my collection. I also enjoyed the wide variety of avenues to gain vp's, the way you could manipulate your position, and the ways you could manipulate your ability to, well, manipulate :)
Oh, and it's a 90 minute game that's only going to get faster in time. That's an amazingly short period of time for a game with so much going on.

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: Very nice resource gathering game. Very few games set up like this one, but it does relate closely to Settlers (without trading or luck).

item.name: Kill Doctor Lucky
item.comment:
That damn Dr.Lucky can be elusive....the beginner map is the only way to play this game that doesn't take 3 years.
The Good: Hunting the good doctor is interesting and serves as a fun competition.
The Bad: Deadlocks in the line of sight and even the random weapons/foils that drag the game out until the fun burns out and you have to play another hour more.

item.name: The King Commands
item.comment:
It's a take-that card game that plays in 20 minutes with up to 6 players. There's actually some strategy as the "artifacts" do have tactical use to them and you can save/create combos of swords for well timed attacks. There's even a bit of basic deduction/guessing game play going on that make this one intriguing.
If it were longer it would be a dog, but it's so fast we even play several times in a row. Reminds me of when we played Zev's first small box release Fairy Tale.

item.name: King of New York
item.comment:
I'm giving this a preliminary 8 with the feeling it will rise to rival KoT.
It's a Trzewiczek style evolution of a system, which is a very good thing. The dice have been massively tweaked making each roll more tense and decision filled.
It's a bit longer, but much of that seems to be inexperience. The game also seems to lean toward winning by VPs, even though tons of damage is doled out and players killed, it seems TPKO wins might not occur as often. Time will tell.
So far owning both is a great thing. The old game is so different, especially with expansions, that I won't be selling it off any time soon.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment:
It's a dice chucker that can be played in 20 minutes even at full player count. There's a very MINOR tactic of attacking to take over "the hill" and when to duck out. Otherwise it's just dice.
Update:
Now a 9 with the inclusion of Power Up!

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment:
Light, fast, variable, and not prone to useless turns like most would have you believe.
I liked it, expected to like it, and now actually itch to play it again which is completely unexpected. I just thought it would be a neat super-filler to have.

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Nomads
item.comment:
While the expansion does have a higher price point than many might prefer it offers quite a bit to the fans of the game. The fifth player adds little length but some fierce competition, while the new bonus tiles fill the gaps that were left by the base game and even add a couple nifty ideas. I like the idea of most of the nomad tiles though there is one that I will never play with again as it seems against the spirit of the game. The most significant addition is the new scoring cards; when the conditions are met you gain the vp's immediately. That means that you can often reuse those settlements with bonus tiles and this makes for a significant strategic shift in the game play.
While I don't think there's a need for another expansion (though now that the game has won SdJ there will be, I am certain) I'd welcome it. This game continues to have legs for our group with almost 20 play and still going strong.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment:
What a nice, fresh take on the so called "Yahtzee" genre of games. Much like Ysphahan, the dice luck has been per mutated into something entirely different, and almost entirely controllable. The characters and buildings seem well balanced, and the game is a joy to play. I'm not so sure the king is worth it, as I feel the queen is the best deal on the board (tied with the alchemist). Beautiful art too.
Update: The luck of the dice kills it for me sometimes. There have been a few recent losses that I can attribute directly to luck. Downgraded to a 7.

item.name: Klunker
item.comment: They call it Basari the card game. I don't see it, but what I do see is a fine filler, with set collection and hand management. Just a hint of luck and a smattering of strategy.

item.name: Knig Salomons Schatzkammer
item.comment:
More strategy than meets the eye. I had high hopes and was not let down. Oddly, the patterns on the cards resemble the same of those in Blokus. This one's unique and fun.
Update: After another play this one moved from a 6 to a 7. Alot more here than even met my eye after inital play.

item.name: Kremlin
item.comment:
At one time this was a grail game I had decided to give up on. I'm so happy JR decided to reprint this, and despite a few production issues, the game is really great.
I've played modern games such as Power Struggle or Tribune, but nothing quite this cutthroat. The only downside I've seen is the three rules sets. Our first play was with the "original" rules. Looking at the other two sets I can definitely see why no one really plays with any of the three, much less the same set of rules as each other. I like that you can easily pick and choose what you like, play with it, and the core experience never changes; that's the sign of good design.
I look forward to many more plays.
item.wishlistcomment:
Kickstarted - Due January 2014
UPDATE: HAHAHAHAHAHA! KS'ers are fun!

item.name: Kreta
item.comment:
I thought the randomness in the selection of the areas that get scored would kill this one a bit, but it made very little difference.
Gameplay is tight, and tense. This is definately one of the better area control/majorities games I have played.
item.conditiontext:
Update:
Upped this one to an 8. It's a solid effort, hampered only by the fact that there is randomness in the cards that select which regions will be scored next. There are ways to mitigate this luck, and it doesn't even have a "game breaking" affect on the game, but it's there.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment:
Its simply the definitive zombie game.
Though movement is still dice driven, character abilities and event cards create offsets to the detriments of the movement, and truly most of the flaws you might find here. I also enjoy that the game play is simple to the point that AP shouldnt ever have a home, and that the turns are bite sized enough that the game moves along briskly. Further, since combat often occurs on both zombie and hero turns there always seems like something to do. The objectives also seem well balanced and impress a sense of urgency and tension heretofore unseen in other games of its ilk.
This one is already slated for our Halloween party, and its certain to see more than one play that day; certainly many more to come.

item.name: Last Will
item.comment:
Last Will is a tableau building game with the central action selection mechanism found in Pergammon, though a bit different in its implementation.
The stress of the simple turn order mechanism is amazing and is scaled incredibly well based on number of players. I also find it fascinating that a game with so much randomness doesn't feel random at all, and indeed you can mitigate most of the luck in such a way as to make your endgame feel well planned and structured. I think the timing decisions are the biggest challenge and will take the longest to learn. I also love that your tableau size is limited and that in just 8 rounds you have to sacrifice to expand it; and this is also a gamble.
In all I love it and finally have felt like my skill is "decent" after 4 plays.

item.name: Last Will: Getting Sacked
item.comment:
The expansion is just, well, fine. Personally I find it both unobtrusive, streamlined, but almost forgettable. I feel like I am playing the exact same game that I was in the base set.
The real refinement here is the action spaces; the combinations aren't randomized but they have been fine tuned and in some cases completely altered from the base game.
So there you have it, you can either take that as an omen to save yourself $$ or you can buy it and know it's not going to do anything wacky or zany to the game you know and love AND you'll get some new features.

item.name: Leaping Lemmings
item.comment:
Who knew you could improve on Igel Argern!?
Actually a game of fairly high strategy with a smattering of luck from the special cards to break up the seriousness.
Perhaps a bit long for what it is if you don't use the short game rules, but fantastically perfect in it's shorter form even with a larger number of players.
I have to give a big not to the graphic design on this one; simply wonderful graphics.

item.name: Lectio
item.comment: Could have almost been done with cards....but then again I love the solid feel of those chunky blocks in my hand. Rating will probably improve after subsequent plays.

item.name: Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment:
Somehow this game has a feeling of Princes of Florence about it. The gameplay isn't very similar, and it's not the Italian theme either, but somehow, this game feels very remeniscent of Princes. I think that it has alot to do with having to collect various components to complete inventions for points. Money is points and points are money. There are a few other things in the game that bring that same air as well; and that's a good thing.
That being said, I very much like this game. There is so much to do in so little time.
item.conditiontext: Update: Took this up a notch to a 9. There is ALOT more forward planning that one can do to eliminate the possibilities of more than one person building the same invention. There is still an element of "dumb luck" as the final inventions reveal themselves and some people just happen to have the resources for a gold on hand.

item.name: Letters from Whitechapel
item.comment: The game itself is an 8 drug down by the 3 hours play time to a 6.

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment:
Finally a game that follows the same vein as 51st State with multi-function cards. It's more of a race than anything, and exhillerating until the end.
There's an interesting counterpoint between the hand management and resource management aspects of the game. You want to rotate through your hand as fast as you can but when you do you also get penalized for carrying over too many resources and Indians. You might try and reduce your resource and Indian load but then each card becomes less efficient.
One thing is for certain: No two players will play the game the same, at least not until after MANY plays.
I really love the Dutrait art as well.

item.name: Libert
item.comment:
You know, I've played a good deal of Wallace games, and yet I still didn't know quite what to expect.
It's a mixture of hand management, area control, and something totally indescribable.
There's an immense amount amount of information to process, not just as a first timer, but even throughout the game in general.
I think the most unique aspect was managing when to apply your cards for tie breakers. Further, creating intentional ties that you know only you can win due to having the proper colored card is nothing short of sinister.
It's a classic Wallace game that will surely see more plays in the future, but one thing is for certain: it's one of my top 5 heaviest games played of all time.
Tentative 9, with aspirations of a 10; just like Age of Steam began, and lived up to.

item.name: Linkity
item.comment:
Very nearly a clone of Blink, but with the mechanic of choosing a word for the letter on the card you play, that is related to the previous card played in some aspect. Quick, fun and painless. Requires more thought than a hard day at work will allow though.
Last play was with 9 and was a riot! Raised my rating to a 7.

item.name: Log Jam
item.comment:
Silly, fast dexterity game similar in feel to Don't Break the Ice.
The best part is the cursing beaver.

item.name: Logistico
item.comment: The purest logistics game I've ever played. It's no frills, but then again, it doesn't need it.

item.name: London
item.comment:
In my mind this is Wallace's take on RftG; not an entirely bad thing.
As a whole I have no issues with the design itself. The cards work well. The cards, while basic, blend together seamlessly with no "dead" ones in the mix. I even like the discard area and the player driven timer that it represents.
The game is, however, completely unintuitive and dare I say totally counter intuitive. This in combination with the classic unforgiving Wallace design sense in which there are usually few chances to catch up created a very frustrating and skewed-scoring first play.
Willing to play at least one more time to decide how disappointed I really am.
Update:
Play number two with two major changes:
1 - It's amazing how much better the game plays when you have the rules correct and play more than one card per "play cards" action.
2 - Everyone took loans. Another massive improvement and removed many barriers in the game's economy.
Those being said the game was wonderful, tense, highly competitive, and thoroughly enjoyable.
My rating rises from a 6 to an 8.
item.wishlistcomment: Ordered as a gift for us.

item.name: Long Shot
item.comment: While our first play was with 3 and I think we need more players I think it's just a fact that racing games like this aren't really for me. This offers some interesting card play yet most of the game is still cruise control. I still think the best one is Manilla as there is actual change and interaction round to round an a larger variety of bets that aren't game-long.

item.name: Loopin' Louie
item.comment: This is silly stupid fun that is great over and over again. I never had it when I was a kid, so maybe that adds to it.

item.name: Loot
item.comment: Luck based take that card play. Fast and fun, easy to learn gameplay.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Friends & Foes
The Lord of the Rings: Nazgul
item.comment:
It was our group's pleasure to test this game for 8 months. We were even lucky enough to relieve a final prototype to play before the game was sent to the printer. It's extremely gratifying to finally play the finished product.
The game is about completing all the stages in 9 rounds which takes a cooperative effort but along the way the system allows you to take advantage of the system itself, but more importantly the other players for your own gain. Some really clever things can be done, some wild situations occur, and most importantly the game continues to surprise me with the failures and triumphs I become a part of and this is with almost 20 games under my belt.
I still think it's pointless to play completely coop. I think the connecting symbols between the locations is unclear at first and make it harder to track which path is which.
I'm glad to own it and will continue to play.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment:
A coop LCG, who'd have thunk it?
It's really just an expandable and variable coop with customizable decks, which while the essence of LCG is still something new altogether.
Wonderful new and classic art, great new mechanics, and a blast to play.
item.wishlistcomment: Will be widely available, wait on purchase.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: Copy 2.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game A Journey to Rhosgobel
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Assault on Osgiliath
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Conflict at the Carrock
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Encounter at Amon Dn
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Foundations of Stone
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Heirs of Nmenor
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Khazad-dm
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Nightmare Deck: A Journey to Rhosgobel
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Nightmare Deck: Conflict at the Carrock
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Nightmare Deck: Escape from Dol Guldur
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Nightmare Deck: Journey Along the Anduin
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Nightmare Deck: Passage Through Mirkwood
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Nightmare Deck: The Hunt for Gollum
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Return to Mirkwood
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Road to Rivendell
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game Shadow and Flame
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Battle of Lake-town
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Black Riders
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Blood of Gondor
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Dead Marshes
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Dradan Forest
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Dunland Trap
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Hills of Emyn Muil
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Hobbit: On the Doorstep
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Hobbit: Over Hill and Under Hill
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Hunt for Gollum
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Long Dark
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Massing at Osgiliath
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Morgul Vale
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Redhorn Gate
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Steward's Fear
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Stone of Erech
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Three Trials
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Voice of Isengard
The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game The Watcher in the Water
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment:
It's like someone reinvented Stratego....with more strategy, killer artwork, fantastic bits, and added power cards.
Actually this game is NOTHING like Stratego.

item.name: Lost Cities
