item.comment: Randomness can screw the fun up occasionally.

item.name: Lost Valley
item.comment: Nice exploration. Good strategy (in the form of having to create triangular spaces for the "bonus tiles", even though the rules say nothing about this). Incredible variety.

item.name: Louis XIV
item.comment:
Nice little majorities game. Some random elements, yet there is enough strategy to make play measurable. Close games with experienced players might be resolved in luck .....time will tell.
Update:
Another good play after a long hiatus results in the confirmation that this is a 7, but a strong one. If not for a luck based endgame it would likely be an 8.
I wouldn't play it with any variants as the game isn't long or heavy enough to warrant it, and experience really evens things out. I suppose you might lose by a point or two because of the chips, but most often you're going to lose by a goal card or two.

item.name: Love Letter: Kanai Factory Limited Edition
item.comment:
Love letter is a light game of deduction with a splash of screw your buddy. Some times it's simply hoping you make it past a somewhat random early game to get to the heart of the play where the real decisions take place. More often than not, there are smart decisions to be made for the entirety of play and you will often look back and see what you could have done "right" for the next play. Any game you can learn from tells me that the game space has room for you to grow as a player and make intelligent decisions.
Sometimes you'll get screwed, but most of the time there's tension and fun. Given the short duration and round structure, the fun is all you'll remember.

item.name: Macao
item.comment:
There may or may not be to much randomness in the cube generation. I do love the wind rose mechanism, and there are tons of ways to spend the cubes to make points, so in the long run these option might serve to mitigate my feelings about the luck factor.
This game unsurprisingly has quite a bit in common with Keythedral and Caylus.
Worth a few plays to see if it will stand the test or wear thin.

item.name: Die Macher
item.comment: One of the most mind-numbingly brain-burning games I have ever experienced, and OH WHAT AN EXPERIENCE! A fantastic blend of hand management, majorites, and negotiation. You owe it to yourself to try this game if you get the opportunity.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment:
I remember playing adventure games like Runebound wishing for a decent experience. I think what always killed them was random encounters. Most of those, if not all, are also lifeless dice chuckers.
MK takes deck building and makes it a central mechanic, yet not the entire game. You move, discover, new creatures are put out and you see them from a distance, making planned encounters. You visit locations, and because movement in the game can be fairly liberal, not to mention locations plentiful, there's little "man it's going to take me 5 turns to get all the way over there", it's more like "I can't wait to see what's over here".
Like any other deck builder you can have some soft turns, but because you can retain cards you can build toward more productive combat or purchasing turns. In the interim there are places you can easily sit for valuable resources or places to go and heal; villages are especially nice for the pillaging, IE extra cards for the next turn.
The game will play in about 45 minutes a player, so it's not short yet you are always looking forward to your next turn. There are some seriously creative ways to combo cards and you really do ave to think about the best way to use your hand each turn. One of the best things about hand management is that even is you cannot use a card for its face function it can still be used as a one value of one of four functions.
It's also wild to see the pacing of the rounds as they are dictated by players. Sometimes you want to burn through your deck to rush other players and harm their progress, other times you'd rather let them end the round (since ending the round means you have to skip a turn).
My initial rating was an 8. After a 3p, 2p, and a solo I now give it a 9.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
item.comment:
This does nothing but add more of everything I liked about the base game. There is a variety of new creatures, abilities, abilities combos, and of course new cards galore. There's a wonderful new hero, a new solo/coop mode, and more.
As I said, it doesn't alter the game as much as enhance and complete a game I already thought was complete. I integrated it and will never separate it. Even the color issues (color differences based on which edition you have, and you'll have some differences no matter what edition you have) it makes no difference; there's enough new content that you still don't know what you're getting or when.
Simply perfect.

item.name: Mage Wars Arena
item.comment:
This one lies somewhere between D&D, Magic the Gathering, Dream Blade, and Summoner Wars.
While this system isn't totally no-luck (there's still a 33% chance per die to do no damage), taking the random card play out of the equation is something that's never been done before.
The sky really is the limit for this system and I see no reason that this won't become a 10 for me.

item.name: Mage Wars: Conquest of Kumanjaro Spell Tome Expansion
Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: Love it or hate it (and I love it) it's still one of the best ideas for a game ever! Too bad most people think you need more than a deck of commons to be good...

item.name: Magna Grecia
item.comment: Semi-simple abstract road building and area control. I am certain with more plays it gets even better.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Magnet
item.comment:
This game has a VERY Stratego feel to it at first glance, but it's really nothing like that game.
I like the idea of having to hide your king, I like having the traps and the power of those pieces, and I LOVE the way the magnet works.
If you like abstracts then you'll love this one.

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
item.comment: Fantastic game. Too much to do in each turn, and too little time in the game to accomplish everything. Players can even directly impact the length of the game.
item.conditiontext:
Update:
While I understand that the theme of the game is about palace builing, the game should not always "force" you to do that as the main action 90% of the time, with the penalty for not doing so being losing.
I am starting to feel a distinct lack of variety and choices in the game.

item.name: Mall of Horror
item.comment:
Needs the right group to be fun, and the more people playing the better.
Update:
Years later I come back to this game and while there's a neat idea here, there are newer outguessing games I enjoy much more; such as Witch's Brew.
It's just "outdated" IMHO.

item.name: Mamma Mia!
item.comment: Nice, simple game of memory. Much better if not played with just 2. Playing with 5 feels like pure chaos. I have to believe this one to be best with 3-4.

item.name: Los Mampfos
item.comment: A light, quick and dirty memory game. There's a bit of luck in the fact that you may or may not choose the same color as another player; the net result being more or less biscuits than others. The game tends to even itself out if you are paying attention though. It's alot of silly fun, and I'm glad I own a copy.

item.name: Mancala
item.comment: One of the best original abstracts. Simple and fun. Can be predictable after many plays though.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: It's craps the boardgame! Goood clean random fun.

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment:
Mansions is Betrayal at House on the Hill done even better.
I'm personally a fan of Betrayal but have some caveats about the game. Mansions not only applies a theme/universe that I am passionate about but amps up the component quality while reducing the fiddlyness of the entire experience.
I'm so glad the game intentionally splits setup between the players and the keeps. This reduces front load down time by a large margin. It immediately involves all players. Another element that does this is the way the keep stays the moderator for all cards and puzzles that are revealed, and further the mythos cards that have to be played on the investigators turn; making the keeper highly interested in what the investigators are doing on their turn.
Turns go by fast generally. The play time is listed as 3-4 hours and our learning game with numerous interruptions was 4. I can easily see this game being a 2 hour experience with our group, which is simply awesome.
I'm not sure how necessary the monster figs are, as they are gigantic, but I simply wouldn't have the game any other way.
There are complaints about two other things:
Errata: Yep. All FF has it. I don't have an issue with it. Generally if we cannot find the answer here we all agree on one until we find out the "correct" answer.
Story Telling: There is a story here. It's all theme. No it doesn't read like a book, or even play out like a movie, but it does serve to get players involved and they are interested to hear what comes next. The story does get lost while your playing until that next chapter comes up again.
I'm looking forward to expansions for this one in a big way and indeed I also see this rising to a 10.

item.name: Mansions of Madness: House of Fears
Mansions of Madness: The Yellow Sign
The Market of Alturien
item.comment:
It definitely exemplifies the older works of Kramer in that it's a nice roll and move game with a large smattering of strategy. You also have the opportunity to see a couple of the concepts from Colosseum in their infant forms.
I also have to comment that overall the game has the nicest bits of any Mayfair game to date...albeit the design of the money is infantile, and I cannot fathom why they chose florescent purple as a player color.

item.name: MarraCash
item.comment:
I can't think of another game that plays like this one. You have the auctioning of the businesses, then the moving of the "customers", all the while you have to help your opponents to often get equal gain, and other times just keep the customers to yourself.
I love the experience, I love the relatively short amount of time this game plays in. This is one of my favorite Dorra games ever.

item.name: Masons
item.comment: Initial impressions are good for this abstract, though more plays will make this one sink or swim.
item.conditiontext: This one swims. Lots of strategy. There's card luck, but there's also biding your time, and waiting for the right moment to make the best play. There's luck, but it's calculable.

item.name: Medici
item.comment: Auction and set collectio at it's finest. Tons of tension and a tried and true Knizia scoring method. It's an oldie, but goodie. I'm afraid though that newer games have added extra chrome and tweaks that may have serve to make this one outmoded.

item.name: Medici vs Strozzi
item.comment:
The overall auction mechanic is alot like Medici, as well as the choices how you load your tiles.
The unique thing here is the "tug of war" that the central board represents for scoring.
I like this one alot, but more plays are needed before I "get it" and can raise it's score.

item.name: Medina
item.comment: Tons of wood in one box! I love how you are literally building the city as you go. It's visually impressive, but it's kind of hard to get past the feeling that your actions are driven by a "well you did that so i'll do this and get points" mentality. It almost feels like the game plays you. I need more plays to figure it out, because I have to believe that there is more here than meets the eye.

item.name: MegaCorps
item.comment:
Tentative rating after a first play with 5 puts this one on the bubble; we shall see where subsequent plays put it.
It's a hint of wargame with an interesting majorities mechanic. Really you're trying to control companies to increase the degree of control you have in various industries. There's only one possible payout a round, and given that you are only start player 3 times in a game you have to choose your investments wisely.
Mercenaries are a key to controlling countries, but to be honest there seemed to be less value in controlling the countries than simply trying to bribe your way into positions.
There's a good bit of old school feel here and though our inaugural game was 2.5 hours I can see that time reducing significantly with subsequent plays, and honestly it never felt as long as it did.

item.name: Megastar
item.comment:
Ironically I had just played Justinian before the first play of this, and they have the base mechanism of adjusting the rank of the core "groups" that you gain points from in common.
This could almost be called Justinian the card game even though they are from different designers.
I have enjoyed the 5 or 6 plays that we've had of this one, and hope to play it again soon.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: Fanatastic production values. Every bit as good as I hoped it would be. Interestingly worth getting even though I already had Command and Colors: Ancients.

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.comment:
What can I say? It is the quintessential pirate game.
It's as thought FF took Pirates Cove and said "let's up the ante".
Fantastic production and multiple paths to gain coin and upgrades. Really just super fun without too much complexity.
Absolutely nothing there that shouldn't be.

item.name: Merchants & Marauders: Seas of Glory
item.comment:
This expansion of modules does nothing but add virtually anything you might have thought was missing from the core game. There is also a huge number of variants to tweak things in virtually every way.
The game is now a 10 for me.

item.name: Merchants of Amsterdam
item.comment:
Pros:
Dutch auction with countdown clock. Press your luck game with the card draws. Fairly calculable benefit/loss system. Opportunities to spite opponents to get ahead.
Cons:
Clock can lead to "who hit it first". Cards are fairly random and not alway beneficial to the current player.
I see this game as a predecessor to games like Ys and Endeavor yet still different enough and relevant enough for an occasional play. It certainly needs the right group, however.

item.name: Merchants of the Middle Ages
item.comment: Cut-throat and brutal. Those are the only words that describe this game aside from great.

item.name: Meridian
item.comment: This is easily the simplest of the column-managing games of Colovini's stable; Submarine and Go West being two others. I think it's the simplicity that will keep it in my collection for an occasional play as with a single sheet of rules there's a guarantee of easy reentry.

item.name: Merkator
item.comment:
Played once with 4.
At first you have this total random mess of a game. What you don't realize is that your first goals should be to gather bonus cards and building cards to determine which contracts are most important to you.
Evaluating which contracts are worth retaining for continues revenue generation combined with timely culling of the chaff will allow you to collect further bonus and building cards.
In the end it was rather surprisingly strategic, though your strategy starts to materialize mid game, yet there is still plenty of time to see them to fruition. You simply have to ensure that while you try to maximize building cards that you continually evolve your contracts for the maximum points at the end of the game.
It's also surprisingly short. It was 90 minutes including rules explanation for our first play. So Uwe has returned to a reasonable play time again.
item.wishlistcomment:
It's a Ewe game. I've liked all his stuff to date. Definitely worth a look.
Uses time as a resource, emphasizes efficiency and ladder building of contracts.
Ordered on Funagain.
Update:
Funagain no longer importing as they are waiting for domestic distribution; cancelled from order.

item.name: Mesopotamia
item.comment:
Nothing in here that wowed me. It was a nice pick up and deliver game, but not the best I've played. The game has very nice production values (all the way down to using real rocks for the stone).
Update: More plays...more strategy. It's all in how the tiles come out. Strategy can vary wildly in this game, and playing it more was what the doctor ordered.
Update:
Played again and had 3 players who could not win based on how the tiles came out so the game virtually locked up for 3 of us.
It will get another play to see if it can save itself from the trade pile.

item.name: Metro
item.comment: The randomness can screw you.....It's just random tile draws with a smattering of strategy. I've craved heavier games and this was an early one for us. It's just a victim of our growing tastes.
item.conditiontext: Gently Used: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment:
Rating based on one play of the family rules.
While I enjoy the auction mechanism, this is really all the game is, and requires people to think and play quickly to keep the game interesing. Further, the full game will have several layers of depth, but without expedient play I can see this one becoming stagnant, and people becoming relucant to play.
I like the base ideas and enjoyed this, but if people try to play it more "thinky" it might not be worth the time.
Update:
Doesn't really play much differently with the full rules versus family rules. I'm thinking there's not a whole lot fo game here...

item.name: Midgard
item.comment:
A solid showing full of tension, and a game that will take more than a few plays to work out all of the strategies.
Ignore the comparisons to Fairy Tale and El Grande. Yes it has majorities, and yes it has drafting (a great part of this game).
Update:
After a couple years' hiatus a 5 player game was instigated, and it continued the tension. I think after having played so many different games that the strategy is more obvious than my first plays, however the competition combined with the drafting mechanism make this fun as long as people don't over think their moves.

item.name: The Mines of Zavandor
item.comment:
What we have here is a 4 player game.
I've read the variants and after having played with less than 4 players I really have no interest in ever doing it again.
That being said, Mines is a very neat little game of blind bidding, efficiency, and combo building. There are some interesting choices to make and a few tactical maneuvers to be had.
There is stiff competition in the form of Furstenfeld here; it both scales better and plays just as quickly.
I will give this game at least a couple of more plays to see if it will sink or swim. I think if it could get down to the 30-40 minute play time range that it definitely has a place in my collection, otherwise it will likely find a home with someone else.
Update:
SINK.

item.name: Mission: Red Planet
item.comment:
Mission Red Planet takes the role system from a game like Citadels, crosses that idea with the action selection mechanism from a game like Race for the Galaxy, and then has you taking control of regions and scoring points at set intervals just like in El Grande. Throw in a deck of bonuses (which has a smattering of "chaos" cards") and you have a game that's 70% strategy and 30% luck. It plays very well if you don't over think it. Our group played it in an hour including a brief explanation.
Worth playing again, and certainly as the filler-like game that most people describe it as. This was a 4 player game and certainly I think that 5 players would up the chaos level, but again its' such a short game you probably won't care.

item.name: Mississippi Queen
item.comment: I like the expanding board (though it can screw you)....good resource managementis key.

item.name: Mmm ... Brains!
item.comment:
Roll dice collect brains....roll dice make someone lose brains....someone wins basically at random. But then it's fast, you can re roll a few times per turn....plus it has mini brains.
The Good: Blissfully fast and reminiscent of a themed Toss Up.
The Bad: Totally random and not really a game; more of a "take turns rolling the dice and see who hits x points first".

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment: I am one mean auctioning machine. This game is pure auction, with tons of variety in built in with the different styles of auction that take place.

item.name: Money!
item.comment:
Medium light strategy, with light and fast paced gameplay. Quite the unique scoring system with a pleathora of paths to victory.
The more I play it the more I like it. this one is best played with 5; but meaning that the more players the better. It's awesome with any number.
Note: Spare copy in shrink for trade: Goldseiber.

item.name: Monsters Menace America
item.comment:
A semi-letdown. I like the dice-fest that it is, it's just a bit slow. The military seems almost useless to boot. It oozes flavor though.
I think it's the totally random roll off endgame that's the anticlimax which breaks the camel's back.

item.name: Moto Grand Prix
item.comment:
The flip dice system is brilliant!
It's fast, furious, and fun. The best part of this game lies in the fact that you don't have to count out your optimal move like many other racers.
The modular track system makes this fantastic, and I can even see tons of room for house rules to add depth if we ever wanted to.
The system allows for real back and forth battles, and plays VERY quickly with little down time between turns.
It's light, that's sure enough, so more hardcore racer fans probably won't be satisfied; but this one will fit in to most gamer's scope of acceptance.
Update:
Rating rises 1 point after racing on a more complex track with full rules and more players.

item.name: Das Motorsportspiel
item.comment:
While I had played Moto GP first I certainly see its' system is firmly rooted here.
I love the maximum speed, the imposed penalties, the timers, the "a die played is a die laid" rule, and the wonderful cars.
It's simple, and to me well worth the price of admission.

item.name: Mountain of Inferno
item.comment:
See my forum entry of "What it is" for a detailed description of the game.
It's a light game of random draws and minimal strategy. You can however make some very clever plays and it's so short that it's worth playing.
It's certainly different in play and theme from anything else.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment:
We've given this one 4 plays so far, and not untio the 4th did we have the Jack player win. But now that we have I can say that this can definately be a tough game for either player. I had originally thought that the Jack player had it worst, but now I see that it's just that the Jack player has to learn "the ways of the force". I also see that the Detective player must be aggressive.
This one's a winner in my book, and I'm definitely glad I was able to get a copy.

item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket
item.comment:
There's a lot of game in this 4"x4"x1" box!
They maintain the seen/unseen mechanism for elimination of suspects. They maintain the 1-2-1 rotation of actions each turn.
The kicker is that while it's a bit more abstract the game has the same feel and comes in at a 15-20 minute play time!
Great new Mr. Jack. I'd have never thunk it.

item.name: M & Lots More
item.comment: Played NJet, which is great, and Mu, which while confusing and takes the right group is good fun. Good collection of trick takers, especially for the price. I already bought Was Stich, but for 3 more for cheap...it's worth every penny.
item.conditiontext: Mu - An interesting mix of trick-taking ideas with a smattering of new ones that makes one great game. Should have bought this one years ago.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: This game is best with 4-6. "Backstab your friends".....oh yes....I do...

item.name: Munchkin Bites!
item.comment: Not much different from it's elder versions....just a fun theme and silly cards.

item.name: Municipium
item.comment:
I had the fortune of trying this at Game Days 2007. I won't walk about specifics since it isn't published yet.
I can say the following:
- It plays in about an hour - It's abstract - It's good, but unless a second play impresses me more, I'd say there are other Reiner games I'd rather play. Like I said, it was one play, and with 5. Good, not great.

item.name: Mykerinos
item.comment: There is a nice majorities game here with characters that give you powers to break the rules. There are some very tough decisions to be made, and the game can be over before you know it. Ystari wins 3 in a row (Y's, Caylus, and this one).

item.name: Myrmes
item.comment:
Much heavier than I was expecting yet as short as I wanted it to be. It's still not quite the "Antiquity Light" that some elluded to, but I'm actually glad for that. For sure there's the constant cycling economy, only tenuously comparible to Antiquity, but the other elements simply don't match up to much else.
One thing is for sure, this game is not only thematic but it beats the pants off the last attempt at making an Ant colony game.

item.name: Mystery Express
item.comment:
Think of this one as Mystery of the Abbey 2.0
It's an action point system that uses card peeks and passes to gather information and then "deduce" the 4 of the 5 major factors of the murder.
The "controversial" time element, which is actually quite less difficult to manage that others would have you believe.

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey
item.comment:
Clue for adults.
Update: Some of the cards are hokey, but the more this one gets played the better I like it. It's still clue for adults, but that's a good thing.

item.name: Mystery Rummy: Al Capone and the Chicago Underworld
item.comment: Not quite as good as Jack the Ripper, but I do like the bonuses for collecting the sets...plays better with 3 or 4...less so with 2.

item.name: Mystery Rummy: Jack the Ripper
item.comment: Rummy with a sweet twist. 2 victory conditions add nice tension over which cards to play or even discard.

item.name: Mystery Rummy: Murders in the Rue Morgue
item.comment: Murdered my passion for the series...that damned oragutan...

item.name: The Nacho Incident
item.comment:
The bits are on the cheap, and the card stock is a bit thinner than I'd prefer.
On the gameplay side, this game has quite a number of things going for it, including the tongue in cheek humor. I also like the fine balance of luck and strategy. There are even elements to help even out the luck.

item.name: Nanuk
item.comment: I'd rather play Perudo/liars dice.
item.conditiontext: Like new. Comes with original insert.

item.name: Navegador
item.comment:
I'm totally uncertain about how Mr. Gherdts does it. It's yet a totally new take on using the rondel, or at least building a game around it.
It's essentially set collection and each set on your personal tableau gives additive bonuses to the sets of buildings and colony tiles you collect. The buildings also expand other abilities on the rondel as your sets of them burgeon in size.
The sugar, gold, and spice "shacks" are used in conjunction with the colonies to either sell good and devalue the market or the shacks serve to revalue it; either way you can make great money and careful diversification is necessary.
I was hesitant and perhaps future plays will show it has some sort of limited staying power but the game was competitive and tense throughout, all players saw the other forks in the road they could have taken, and in all everyone agree about how good it was.
It's easily the second best in the series but could just as easily grow to be my favorite.
item.wishlistcomment:
I remain skeptical of a new use of the rondel from this designer. I think I'm officially tired of collecting them from him.
UPDATE:
Played and loved the damn thing. I LOVE being wrong ;)

item.name: Nefarious
item.comment:
This is a game of random chance. You try to get cards into play, the powers and values of which are random, which the higher valued ones almost always being preferable (given that 20 points ends the game). Your investments can pay out variably, higher to those who are somewhat luckier with what their neighbors do and when that luck aligns with what is in their hand the the order of the actions they just have happened to take.
There's not much of a game here. You play, collect, and there's likely to be a couple of people close in score at the end. Someone will definitely win, but most will lose, simply for having played.

item.name: Neuland
item.comment: A pure no-luck logistics game. Bland art...but then who cares? Nice action point system too, I hope to see it in future games. I hope repeated plays will show multiple avenues for strategy...but it's still new to me..
item.conditiontext: Update: repeated plays bring wonderful strategy. Glad to see this will be reprinted.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment:
This is one of the best tactical, albeit somewhat mathy, puzzle games ever made. I really love the mix of melee and ranged combat combined with the wonderfully balanced, yet over the top, special abilities.
It's seen tons of plays and will continue to see plenty more.

item.name: New England
item.comment: Luck can have a big effect on the tiles and cards drawn, but the auction always gives enough room to get what you want most of the time.

item.name: The New Era
item.comment:
51st State just got bitch-slapped down from a 9 to a 7 and this replaced it.
Ignacy does it again with a 2.0 of another design, really a 2.5, and makes a great game perfect.
This version has extreme balance across the board, more comboliciousness, and a wonderful new faction.
They claim you can combine both games but I say WHY WOULD YOU WANT TO??

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: Solid, simple, fun. It's a no frills dicefest with a randomized board. It's everything I hoped it would be.....

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: Interesting mechanism in terms of the lowest movement used effecting the movement of the river. That in turn can lend to free movement for your canoes...yet there is still a little guesswork involved.

item.name: Nightfall
item.comment:
Turn the stack from Magic into a fully featured, highly interactive game. It also borrows the kicker mechanic from Magic but evolves that as well.
That might seem like two strikes against it but the designer has taken those ideas and elevated them to such a degree that the game is surprisingly unique and plays well.
Much like Dominion or Thunderstone, there is a ton of information to absorb on the front end and will take multiple plays to bring the play time down to a reasonable length. Luckily even initial plays do not feel as long as they actually are.
Hopefully a few solid expansions will flesh out the system and it will be a contender to the Dominion throne in our group.

item.name: Nightfall: Martial Law
item.comment: Improves on the original formula, adds a couple of new mechanisms and makes the game a 9.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: Simple and fast. I need to get this one out for more plays to see if it will hold up in the long term. Deceptively deeper than it first appears.

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: Scales well, plays in less time than they say, and uses drafting to make the game fresh and new. There's alot going on, and the gameplay is always tight.

item.name: Nottingham
item.comment:
Set collection and a bit of take-that card play; but with a twist on the take-that.
Even though there is a wealth of card stealing and forced bidding, you always get a card in exchange; making the actions risky at times.
There are opportunities for keeping track of cards gained as well as seeing player hands.
While it's random our games have been rather close. It really needs to be played briskly for maximum enjoyment.
Finally, I cannot see playing this with more than 4-5 players.

item.name: O Zoo le Mio
item.comment:
It's an interesting blind-bidding game with a cool tie-breaking mechanism. It's fast and light.
Just decent imho.
item.conditiontext:
Minor separation on on screen, otherwise like new.
For Trade or Best Cash Offer.

item.name: Oh, Pharaoh!
item.comment: My wife loves this one.....:devil:

item.name: Oltre Mare
item.comment: One part set collection like Bohnanza, and the order stacking like Mamma Mia. There are a couple of other sprinkles of freshness that make this combo shine.

item.name: Olympos
item.comment:
The AP prone should not apply. The rest of us will find Small World for advanced players with a pseudo tech-tree; the tree is randomized but only in the costs that you'll pay and given that the available board spaces change each game there is a great amount of variability in each play.
It uses the time mechanism from Neuland/Jenseits to magnificent effect. I especially like that each player has their own separate end game trigger (timing not condition) and that they immediately get one last turn; though they sacrifice bonus points to do so. There seems to be some room for brilliant timing decisions here.
A total surprise.

item.name: One Night Ultimate Werewolf Daybreak
item.comment:
It's the original, with more granularity. That's a good thing, though it does add a learning curve for experienced players. I think it would even be hard for new players with no preconceptions or established habits.
I look forward to so many more plays.

item.name: Opera
item.comment:
Shares features with Neuland/Tinner's Trail, Traumfabrik, and Puerto Rico.
The AP mechanism is Neuland/Tinners. Blind Bids turn into an equal amount of budget for the round. These are your AP's. Whomever has spent the least (top and left most) goes next).
There is set collection like Traum where you build sets of composers, though no duplicate composers are allowed. There are multiple ways to score them, either combined or individually, and even a few ways to make extra cash from them. The interesting thing about the tableaus the composer tiles are placed on is that they are expandable, and this expansion is another way to get VP's.
The major mechanism for action spending is through role selection and other players can "play along"; though they have to buy in unlike Puerto.
Solid game. Could really grow on me and my group.
Further play lowers this one to a 6. The main reason is the wild swings in possible vp values in the composer market. I also think the the actions and opera houses force too much overlap and interconnection to the point where you could unintentionally or intentionally affect other players, perhaps all 3 of your opponents simultaneously. It leads to a "I don't want to do that action" syndrome that takes away quite a bit of the game for me.
I'm also not happy with how long it plays, or at least how long it feels like it's taking.

item.name: Organic Soup
item.comment:
Holy crap my brain hurts!
My head is still spinning from the velocity at which this game accelerates into a conclusion!
Lots of interesting combos happening, interesting timing, still working out if screw
8 plays:
(1) 2 Player (3) 3 Player (4) 4 Player
I think the 4 player strategy is keyed toward getting the most Complex and Simple with the chance of winning on a lucky Amino, however the game length is so much shorter I believe the former is the key to consistent victory.
Timing is the key to 3 player games using much of the ideas of 4 player however there is a much higher chance for an Amino to happen.
The two player game is wide open. It seems to me that the world is your oyster and that you can be more focused on building toward the Amino win, and moreover should likely always work toward that end with two players.

item.name: Ostia
item.comment: Ostia is a game of marginal gains and out guessing. The problem is that it's not all that interesting.

item.name: Pairs
item.comment:
We have played the basic game over 50 times now and it's still getting better. There are some important decision points, that while not varied, do have a big impact on each round. We used to have 2 minute games and now some stretch to 10. That doesn't sound like a lot, but when you're talking a cousin of blackjack, suddenly there's a real game here.
There are a TON of variants to try...eventually.

item.name: Palazzo
item.comment: Rating started out at 6, as I felt it a bit simple and mediocre, repeating many familiar mechanics. But the more I played it, the more I realized just how wonderfully tuned and blanaced the game was, and just how many tough decisions there are to make. Every play makes this one better, and while it may not be a 10, or even a 9, it is solid an 8 as any other game as I have rated an 8; perhaps even closer to 9 (but I don't do fractional ratings). Good production values and a lower price point make Alhambra's long lost sibling a winner in my book.
item.conditiontext: Gently Used: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Pandnte: Light & Dark
item.comment: It's different than the original game, which I didn't really find any true flaws in. That being said, I enjoy what's different, and the streamlining.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment:
Wow. Fast, fun, very well designed and themed.
Update:
40 plays later and it's losing a bit of luster, still a wonderful game tht I wouldn't refuse to play.

item.name: Pandemic Legacy
item.comment:
It's all the things Pandemic is, but the Legacy edge adds weight to everything you do. There's constant tension.
I also like that losing, while it sucks, makes you just as fulfilled as a win might; though wins in this game are hard-fought, so they're even better.
I'm not saying we should have Legacy everything, but I'm glad they took something other than Risk and ported it into this mechanic. I really hope they do a season 2.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment:
Gives the system great legs and adds some surprising interactions in a limited system.
Well worth having if you liked OR loved the first one as it takes a good design to a whole other level.

item.name: Pandemic: The Cure
item.comment:
To me, The Cure is almost equivalent to the original. The feel and tension are all there. It's a bit more abstracted, but it still plays essentially the same.
The big change is the decision making. While all of the information is out in the original game, the dice make this one so much more dynamic. Decisions do not come as easily, and often they have a much higher price when you make the wrong one. I also like that since the board state changes so often there is much more discussion of strategy, and indeed more real decision space.
I REALLY like it.
Update:
Same opinion after a dozen plays.

item.name: Paris Paris
item.comment:
Never let any comments or reviews convince you that this is a non-game. There is future planning despite the short term benefits of some decisions. The only wrinkle, and the one I won by, was that of the removed businesses. I'm sure you could track that information, but in a game this light why should you have to, and more to the point why should a close game be decided by such an arbitrary mechanism.
The game is light, fast, and some what of a light deduction experience. Purchased cheaply and played briskly I suppose it is worth it but it fits the same time frame as Chine or Web of Power. I can see the origins of both of those games here, but given that I own them I would default to them.

item.name: Parthenon: Rise of the Aegean
item.comment:
Wow this game is truely cruel and merciless. It is however, VERY even overall. By the end, we found that with a few more plays, and the experience that would bring, we could build more intuitively to ease the pain of those nasty events and hazards.
Overall our first play was quite even, and in future, will surely end before the end of the 3rd year.

item.name: Pass the Pigs
item.comment:
Slightly less fun than the deluxe edition.
See Pass the pigs for good and bad.

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment:
It's much like Vegas Showdown crossed with Ra, and retains about an hour play time. Various avenues to victory though that might not be evident at first blush.
It's light and fast but with a nice splash of strategy.

item.name: Peloponnes: Hellas Expansion
item.comment:
While it adds another upkeep round, it does stretch the disasters out a bit allowing for a tad more breathing room. The new tiles also add some nice strategy to the game.
We now never play without all the expansions and by the variant "6 tiles dealt" rules, allowing for one or more tiles to always be in the conquest area.

item.name: Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League
item.comment:
It's a game of hand management coupled with pick up and deliver. While the game has some randomness, it's no more so than my other fav Kosmos 2p Jambo. It actually has exactly the same level of strategy, tactics and luck as Jambo, so if you're a fan I couldn't recommend this one more.
One thing: Either the sun should be smaller or the player tokens should have been some sort of plastic bit or cube, not a ship shaped chit.

item.name: Perudo
item.comment: I'm good at bluffing....and I love to have a few libations with this one...

item.name: Pick & Pack
item.comment: GREAT 2 PLAYER GAME!! Another winner form Simon. Can't wait to see what he come up with next.

item.name: Pick Picknic
item.comment: Nice, fast-paced filler. Good for all ages.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment:
Caylus lite they say....nope...not really. Pillars is it's own game, plays faster, and is extremely tense.
The board could have been simplified...the art is over the top like Colosseum and Sienna. I could have also done without paying the extra 5 buck in wood for the cathedral.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
Piranha Pedro
item.comment:
There is alot of blind-luck in the card play, and unless you are first or second in the round, there is no true way to strategize.
I think it's easy to enjoy this game for what it is, and that's just a silly little game that's good with a full boat of players. It's kinda like playing chicken...only with Pedro.

item.name: Pirate Dice: Voyage on the Rolling Seas
item.comment:
How utterly disappointing. While the flavor of this game's inspiration, Robo Rally, is there, the unfortunate part is that the dice REALLY detract from your experience. While the cards in RR can screw you there are still a ton of board elements that help you make something of the lemons you've been handed. It just seems to me that in this game a bad roll is far worse than a bad hand.
The other negative for us was the take-that elements of denying a chosen action or forcing another to use yours. This makes it FAR too easy to mess with each other's plans and to make it worse it's hard to pull off your intended foil. You normally foil them doing something you didn't expect and then their altered movement will negatively effect you.
After an hour of going around in circles during our last game I think this one is a complete dud.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment:
A bit random, but oh so fun.
Too long for what it is though.

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment:
Game #400
Update: Fun in a box. It's like slot cars, only as a dexterity game. What a blast. Some configurations are too big for many tables, but that's not a bad thing.

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: Copy numero dos.

item.name: PitchCar Mini
item.comment:
While I think I get some of the comments about the "disappointing cars" I also equally don't understand.
There's a different technique you have to use, and while perhaps I'd like heavier cars I think it's just a matter getting a feel for how much lighter you have to be to get the same effect on the cars.
Most of our players were getting equal performance to that of the full size version in a matter of a lap or two.
I like this every bit as much as the full scale and it's totally portable!

item.name: Plague & Pestilence
item.comment:
Can drag a bit while you wait for the plague ship....theme carried it when I first played, later it was pure chaos.
The Good: Theme and take that elements.
The Bad: Totally random.

item.name: Poison
item.comment: SO much more strategy that meets the eye in this one. The art style in it is wonderfully colorful, and it's also a great gateway game.

item.name: Police Precinct
item.comment:
There was a time when I said "No More Coops, I have too many", then they started making coops like this.
Police Precinct, in many ways, reminds me of Arkham Horror. Random events or challenges pop up to be dealt with, some with a built in timer imposing negative consequences unless addressed. In fact, the game makes you plan well, coordinate well, and be proactive at all times.
Tension is high throughout, players are always engaged, and certainly the theme rises above what seems like a boring old cop game.
I own the 2nd edition, whose production values are second to none. If you're a coop lover, definitely look into this game.
item.wishlistcomment: Kickstarted, due fall 2014, stated as before Essen

item.name: Pony Express
item.comment: While it's a neat blend of theme, dice manipulation, and dexterity game, there's a serious run away leader issue that ruins the good time.

item.name: Portobello Market
item.comment:
An interesting abstract whrere you try to help your opponents as little as possible. There are chances for huge points, and it's easy to give them away as well.
I enjoyed my first play, and more plays will reveal how deep the strategies of this game lie.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: The more players the better, Phenomenal game! Did I mention this game was good?

item.name: Power Grid deluxe: Europe/North America
item.comment:
The maps feel like variants. Because of that, and the unimpressive Europe side, this is an 8.
New Art Direction: I can take or leave the minimalist approach. I'm not sure why the radical shift.
New Wood: The resources are great but the dynamos make me have to explain what they are to every new player. They should have just been factory shapes.
I like the variant with the 1; it really shakes the later game up. The extra space for Europe? Waste of time. Perhaps it shortens the game by a round?

item.name: Power Grid: BGG Promo Card Set
Power Grid: Brazil/Spain & Portugal
item.comment: Brazil at best is an average map that feels competent but familiar. Spain/Portugal creates a slower game of drudgery and drops a handful of eco plants late game at a crucial time that serves to harm those trailing and further slow the game down. This is the pack of maps that convinced me that I don't need any more for PG and I especially never need to play Spain/Portugal again EVER.

item.name: Power Grid: Factory Manager
item.comment:
I think that it's fortunate that I listen to some of the negative talk and lowered my expectations. I think it is even more fortunate that I had played Vegas Showdown and Peloponnes before this game.
Those things being said you end up with an above average game that is worth playing on occasion. Played quickly enough it does contain enough tactics and variety to make it intense and fun.
It's not destined to be a regular once everyone has had a shot at it; that's because Peloponnes does everything here a bit better, and is more popular in my group, though everyone still "enjoys" PGFM.

item.name: Power Grid: France/Italy
item.comment: Every bit as good as the original. It's kinda like chocolate and vanilla for me. They're both good....in the same way.

item.name: Power Grid: Northern Europe/United Kingdom & Ireland
Power Grid: The First Sparks
item.comment:
This is the essence of PG with a simplified auction and more emphasis on turn order.
In many ways this game feels like more of an economic engine than the original, and the knowledge cards create some light strategy avenues.
While the original is the best this is certainly worthwhile for fans of the game; it's lightning fast at a mere 45 minutes.

item.name: Power Grid: The New Power Plant Cards
item.comment: The new deck is soooo streamlined and plays even more toward a players' efficiency. It's a nice breath of fresh air for such a great game.

item.name: Power Struggle
item.comment:
This is really like many have eluded to: Tribune on steroids.
There seems to be a fair amount of chaos with a full complement regardless of the amount of open information.

item.name: Powerboats
item.comment:
I think the luck of the dice can spoil things a bit, and in a given race there can be a real runaway leader problem. It's tough to play quickly as things can change radically before your next turn.
It's very abstract, but solid.
Update:
While an amusing racer other games such as Moto GP, RallyMan, and especially Das Motorsportspeil simply outshine it and my desire to play.

item.name: Prt--Porter
item.comment:
Another of this seasons games that has a high degree of randomness that's completely manageable. I think competent decision making is derived from small number of cards in the game and the fact that there is perfect information among the players themselves.
Pret teaches you to focus on a handful of scoring categories and specialize in your buildings and employees to be successful. Failure to do so will not only see you lose but struggle throughout the game. In the latter sense Pret can be very brutal and unforgiving.

item.name: Primordial Soup
item.comment: Nice "old school" Eurogame that will need more plays to flesh out more strategy. Luck plays a large role, but it still has a lot of room to calculatingly screw other players and get ahead.

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment: Several avenues to victory. Auctions make the money tight too.

item.name: The Princes of Machu Picchu
item.comment:
I'm a bit torn about this one. Everyone, including my self was engaged by the variety of decisions and the sheer timing challenges involved in Princes. The whole game was tense, and in all there seems to be a ton of strategy.
It seems that running the sacrifice deck out isn't too difficult, which mitigates my major concern of the Spanish showing up and giving the random tripling or doubling of someone's score my pure venom toward the game.
Indeed the goal of a player who is ahead is to get priests/virgins, get 4+ cards, manipulate their pieces to fit those cards and run the deck out FTW.
Tentative 7 until I find out if my feelings are correct. Could easily be an 8, but I suspect the random element keeps it a solid, enjoyable 7; even if the game is a tad long for my tastes.

item.name: Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment: Worth every penny I paid. There's a tremendous amount of options and paths to succeed (and fail). Rating will probably rise with further plays.
item.conditiontext: Update: Wow! Another Wallace game in my 10's. This game has so many layers and so many approaches to victory; Will you collect vp tiles and devalue the status chart? Will you go military and collect laurels and command the status chart? How about using the pope to your own ends to guide "fate"? There are so many approaches...This game is underrated, but I suspect it has a lot to do with it's heavy nature, longer play time, and lack of availability.

item.name: Il Principe
item.comment: Another play will make this a 7 or 8 or perhaps a 3. It definately deserves another play to prove or disprove my suspicions.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Pueblo
item.comment: This is the first time I have seen an abstract in 3 dimensions. The scoring system actually uses all 3 as well. I even like the variants. Very unique.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: So many ways to play, and oh so flexible.

item.name: Puerto Rico: Expansion I New Buildings
Puzzle Strike
item.comment:
It's Super Puzzle Fighter 2 Turbo/Tetris Attack the deckbuilder.
Your goal is to make at least one other opponents accumulate 10+ penalty points to end the game then have the least among all other players. The deck building is more subtle, you buy fewer tiles, often having singles that simply enhance your goals or that will give you a quick leg up when they appear. The radical change, and what drives your game, are the 3 character specific tiles you receive; not only thematic but creating completely different strategies for all involved.
I have yet to do 2p, but I have the upgrade pack for the "balanced" characters and play by 3rd edition rules for free for alls.
If you've ever wanted some confrontation in your deck buiilder, this is the one for you; pink box et al be damned.

item.name: Puzzle Strike Shadows
item.comment: More goodness if you liked the original. It is obvious that more testing went into this up front and that the designers have grown in experience.

item.name: Puzzle Strike Upgrade Pack
item.comment: Necessary or the base set is a 5.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment:
Starts at a tentative 7. I'm currently an addict which is more than I can say for some of my 7's or some even more highly rated, however I have had and seen a couple of people have HORRIBLE games.
It is dice and my bad luck is down to 1 in 5 games; now I see other possibilities that have helped negate it. I also think the game plays better with less than 4, but time will tell.

item.name: Quarriors! Key Master Lord of the Quarry Promo Card
Quarriors! Quarmageddon Multiplying Mischievous Imp Promo Card
Quarriors! Quest of the Qladiator
item.comment: If you've liked this system up until now this is certainly the best yet. The big change here is locking, which is both innovative and interesting.

item.name: Quarto!
item.comment:
In the long term, could be "solved"....not any time soon though.
The Good: For a limited number of plays you can outguess and out play your opponent in this abstract.
The Bad: Moves eventually become obvious and the game loses it's charm and playability.

item.name: Queen's Necklace
item.comment: I have to say that this game has soo many more layers than one would first suspect. Like many others, I feel that this may be Bruno's best work. I feel ashamed for not getting this one sooner.

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment:
Several ways to win and I don't often see draws; even though after enough plays I think there could be.
The Good: Totally unique, visually appealing, lends itself to a few strategies.
The Bad: Runaway leader can spoil the game more often than not more than half way through.

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: It's much akin to scrabble with colors and shapes. Fun, light, fast, and great with any number.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: A very tight, tense, and yough auction game. Worthy of it's rank here on the Geek.

item.name: Ra: The Dice Game
item.comment:
This is the best dice multiplayer dice game of this style that you can play. It's tense, fun, and I actually don't care about winning or losing; I just love seeing if the gambles you take every turn pan out.
It's like Ra in feel and much in function yet still keeps it's own identity. Reiner has also done a great job of mitigating the penalties that could have been associated with the suns or ankhs.
5 plays in less than a week of ownership says it all, and that's with all numbers; so it scales beautifully to boot.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
This one is an improvement over San Juan. It's San Juan and SO much more. I've even heard they have expansions in the works, and it will only serve to make a great game even better.
It has no real player interaction, but then again most of the experience of this game is simply to do it better than anyone else.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Rebel vs Imperium
Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment: More great cards and ideas. The game plays perfectly with five. Bonuses are a great idea. Can't wait to try it solo.

item.name: Rage
item.comment:
A scalable version of spades.
Update:
Replaced by many newer, more fun games of this category.
Games such as:
Tichu Control Nut Wizard

item.name: Rails of New England
item.wishlistcomment: Wait for rules. Rio Grande. Readily available.

item.name: Railways of the World
item.comment:
The cards are still more random than I care for, but I like the game quite a bit without the tycoon cards. I still prefer chocolate over vanilla though.
Update:
Rating drops from an 8 to a 6 as I've never wanted to play it again since the first two times.

item.name: Raj
item.comment: A nice light filler, but there are newer games that do what this does and have refined the formula to a greater degree.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Rat Hot
item.comment: Just random enough to keep it from being too solidly strategic. Fun though. Good edition to the Schacht collection.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: The Rats in the Walls
item.comment:
It's Liars Dice played with VP's. The first person to lose all of their VPs (which are nifty little plastic brains) causes the game to end. Highest score wins.
The real bluffing here is claiming there are no rats, which is incredibly thematic. Worth every penny for this cheap game.

item.name: Razzia!
item.comment: Every bit as good as it's boardgame cousin.

item.name: Recess!
item.comment:
Fast and abstract.
One player got the surprise win with a kiss, though otherwise the game was very competitive and close.
The rules are somewhat wanting until you have played half a game then everything is clear.
I certainly like the bullying aspect and the shoving mechanic.

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment: Phenomenal strategy and agonizing decisions. This game can be truely cut-throat. If you can get your hands on it, it is well worth the time.

item.name: Reef Encounter of the Second Kind
Relationship Tightrope
item.comment:
A nice "sort-of" trick taking game. I have the original which doesn't have the idiotic theme.
This game is great with those that are experienced with it, but with new players this feels like an experiment in pure chaos.

item.name: Relic Runners
item.comment:
What a surprise this game is. Once you get past the Cleopatara-level chrome, there's quite a good game underneath.
It's a logistical exercise of trying to juggle increasing your movement, collecting bonuses, and setting up the collection of relics; the latter of which you'd normally like to be at antother player's expense.
What you end up with is something a bit more brain burny than DoW has ever produced. I suspect the sweet spot will be 4, though a cut throat 5 player game will be fun as well.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment:
This game is so evil and fast. Players really need to be experienced to pick up on who the spies are fast. I expect the spies to win the first 5-10 games before we start becoming comfortable with the deduction in our group.
An amazing little game that deftly combines the card play from BSG and the human interplay from Werewolf in an effective manner.
item.wishlistcomment: Will likely buy. Waiting for final rules. Might still do a basic PnP to make final decision.

item.name: Revolution!
item.comment:
While I will say that this game concludes quickly enough for "what it is", and further the guessing game does seem to have some valid tactics, it's still a guessing game that's better implemented first in Witch's Brew, and perhaps also in Castle for All Seasons.
Not worth buying, but an occasional play would be fine.
Update:
I began thinking more and more about this game and bought it. The thing is it's actually a fine game. It's got some interesting and at times exciting out guessing.

item.name: Rex: Final Days of an Empire
item.comment: Not as pirate themed as some raters would lead you to believe.

item.name: Rheinlnder
item.comment: There's alot to like in this game. It's card driven, and while there is luck inherent ot a system like that, every card is unique, and the deck gets reshuffled fairly often, so those cards get reused. I also like the "destruction tile-esque" bastions, that can screw with other people. The archbishop function is nice, and adds another element to broaden the spectrum of this game.

item.name: Rise of Empires
item.comment:
LONG. HEAVY. DIVERSE IN STRATEGIES.
If you can handle the 3 factors above then this is certainly for you.
It's really about choosing a path of terrain tiles + power tiles + some city tiles, while making sure to get a piece of the action on the main board; the latter of which is important to help garner timely resource markers and money and can also be a serious source of points.
The only negative is TIME. Our first game went four hours. I could see this getting down to 2.5-3 at best. I'm uncertain that it will see frequent play due this factor alone, but it certainly won't go untouched.

item.name: Road Kill Rally
item.comment:
I'm totally on the fence about this one.
For one: You must play this game with the intent of trying to eliminate each other (optional rule).
Two: There are some odd situations that can end in uneven pacing and an overly long game.
Fer Three: Doesn't play so well with 5-6.
The rule book is also a mess.
I do love the idea that this is a smattering of Car Wars and the best of Carmageddon.
Edit:
Gone, baby, gone. I guess future contenders like Road/Kill or the reprint of Car Wars will perhaps suffice.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment:
A quintessential pick up and deliver game.
Our first game was 4 hours including the rules explanation for 4 players. I agree with our teacher that more than 4 would take a serious commitment from all involved and the understanding that you may be looking at 1-1.5 hours more per player.
It's a game everyone should play at least once, though it's arguable which is better between this and Antiquity. They're different offerings, so it's really hard to play favorites.
One final thought is that I would probably have been more taken with the game had I not seen further plays take 5 hours; and another factor is having played other pick up and deliver games before this one, all of which are much shorter and nearly as satisfying.
I just wish it didn't take an hour for this game to really get going.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: I love the strategy and opponent screwage possibilities! ....I die alot tho lol I have the original and armed and dangerous....12 boards and 2 sets of option cards make this game nearly perfect. The more plays I get in, the better I love it.

item.name: RoboRally: Armed and Dangerous
item.comment: If you get one expansion, this is the one to get.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: While it does even out the odds of the dice it also easily doubles the length of the game, making the shorter version preferable IMHO. I'd rather play 3 times over the same length of time than just once.

item.name: Roma
item.comment: Random....may need a few more plays to impress me....or infuriate me.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Rum & Bones
item.comment:
Fast, furious, brutal, and fun. The powers really feel special across the board and make the system worth exploring.
The game also leans toward making it easier to hit, than to miss, so every round is full of success. Even the Kraken and Sea Dragon, though brutal, are thrilling.

item.name: Rune Age
item.comment:
Tentative 8 with a high chance of rising.
Rune Age is like:
- Night Fall in that each player has personal draft piles
- LotR the LCG in that you choose a scenario which has goals and sets the central draft piles
- Thunderstone in that you have a main deck that brings out enemies and events
That being said it plays like none of them. It's a 30 minute game full of fast play and neat combos.
Pluses:
- Awesome art
- Scenarios range from non interactive competition to fully pvp
- There are 4 factions each with their own style and unique draft piles
- Quick set up and break down
I think the game fills the same kind of filler niche as Dominion but while taking the best of many of its fore runners RA remains a beast all it's own.

item.name: Rush n' Crush
item.comment:
I have mixed feelings about this game so far.
While it has much less luck that it's cousin Formula De, there is still a significant level of luck in the lane changes.
The big positive is that your speed is dictated by your position. This is coupled with the fact that you choose your level of risk in terms of lane changes associated with your given speed. You also have quite a few more points to augment speed, shifts, and changes than it's cousin, though this is somewhat deceiving as one major blunder can leave you hurting and basically remove you from contention.
I'm still interested in playing more and those plays will either confirm or deny my feelings.
Finally: Why the hell couldn't there be either multicolored cars OR cars that you can intermix colored components that ACTUALLY STAY TOGETHER? I know the colors are teams, but this isn't really a team game.
Feelings confirmed: Random mess with a runaway leader issue.
item.conditiontext: Played twice. Original inserts included. Like New.

item.name: Russian Railroads
item.comment:
More an evolution than revolution, yet it's a tight design loaded with tense moments. There are multiple scoring avenues to persue in a myriad of combinations, none of which seem to be best.
The actual worker placement is the star and it's handled brilliantly. Engineer allow you to add to your personal options, they also serve as a revolving futures market that is shared for a time.
One thing is for sure: Make sure you manage your turn order or you will regret it.
Update: Another play and it's a 9.

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: It's an interesting concept that borrows from games like Bang. It's decent, and if it were longer, it would be a dud, but as it is it's just ok. It plays with enough players to keep it in the mix.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment: Randomness of the cards keeps St. Pete from being on top, though I have to say there is enough strategy in there that subsequent plays may make the rating rise. While the observatory seems a bit overpowered, I can see other ways to win....just not as easily.

item.name: Saint Petersburg: The Banquet
item.comment: I can live without all the cards. A few add some nice options to the game, the other few are totally imbalanced.

item.name: Samurai
item.comment: A nice mix of area control and majorities. Anyone who says the scoring system is broken or unpredictable either doesn't win, or just doesn't like this type of game.

item.name: San Francisco
item.comment:
This is an all auction game with a centralized board for player interaction. Many have panned it for just being a series of auctions but the central board holds a subtle majorities game. I think that the underexposure this might have gotten when it was released meant that when most people had a chance to play it there were "more interesting" games out there...however I still enjoyed the heck out of it.
The only other games that I love that are also in this category are Modern Art and Fist of Dragonstones.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment:
Puerto Rico in card form with a couple of twists. Scales well, but plays best with 4.
Updated: Downgraded partly due to so many plays making it semi-solvable, and further the release of RftG.

item.name: Santa Fe Rails
item.comment: This is a fine Moon original from his early designing days. You can truely see the roots of Union Pacific and Ticket to Ride in this title. In the collaborative track building, you also see the origins of Trans America.

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: Auction + area control + majorities = truely german.....this game is simple to play, but has such deceptively deep strategy.

item.name: Savannah Tails
item.comment:
Passable racing that is only saved by it's 30 minute time frame.
Much lighter than most, barely heavier than Ave Caesar by all accounts, and with the same luck level, but more opportunity for tactics.
You can certainly see that ti's the cast off of Snow Tails, and will likely live in the shadow of that great game.

item.name: Save Doctor Lucky
item.comment:
Meh. The boat is sinking...we should let it.
The Good: Creative opposite of killing the good doctor.
The Bad: Random elements and play time kill the fun; what little there is.

item.name: Scene It? Movie
item.comment: It's fast paced trivia, and sometimes the trivia is based on video or visual cues from the dvd included. They have included a folding board that lets you play the long or short version of the game as well. Novel, entertaining, and fun...just not hard or original. I would rate this a 7 or 8, but it is possible for someone to win having only anwered just one question. (on your turn you roll and move, then take a question and repeat this until you get one wrong, or in a special case until everyone beats you to the answer. You move at the beginning of each turn no matter what. So with good rolls, you can beat everyone to the end, having answered no questions right, and just answer your last question right for the win...on the rare side, but happened to us and is very lame)

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: Plays in the same vien as Goa and Industria Waste with a nice fantasy theme.

item.name: Schotten-Totten
item.comment: Simple and fun filler.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: My version is the deluxe on on the lazy susan....

item.name: Scream Machine
item.comment: Better than many give it credit for. It's a nice majorites game with a large smattering of luck and a wacky theme. Not to hit the table often, but it'll make it out often enough to make it worth the purchase.

item.name: Sentinel Tactics: Promo Power Card Pack
Sentinel Tactics: The Flame of Freedom
Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment:
While there are basic decisions you do have to be aware of what other characters were chosen and what villain is in play as creation of synergies is very important.
If you like superheroes, a game full of flavor and theme, and tons of replayability then I cannot recommend this more. The base set is a 9 but expansion content makes it a 10.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Infernal Relics
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Rook City
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Shattered Timelines
Sentinels of the Multiverse: Vengeance
item.comment:
This time it's a whole team of villains; it's nearly competitive multiplayer against AI. The new heroes are wonderful.
All in all a fantastic new way to play. I cannot wait to see what variants people come up with to use these villains in other ways.
item.wishlistcomment: Kickstarted - Due October 2013 - Now delayed until February 2014

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse: Wrath of the Cosmos
item.comment:
This is the best expansion to date. I'm having a hard time figuring out where they will go next. Vengeance added quite a bit of play time using that variant, while some aspects of this expansion add a ton of book keeping (I'm looking at you Bloodsworn Colloseum and titles).
I think with the advent, and backstory, of Progenitor, that I'd like to see a 1 vs many setup, perhaps with a Galactus clone with Progenitor at his side.

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment: More like Bang than Werewolf in that it's more of a game than a social experiment. I really having the blend of cards, direct attacks, and special abilities.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: Fantastic and hard. It's a pure cooperative game, and in that you have to make sure that everyone is into the idea. It's not a game for everyone, but I think it would see at least occasional play in most groups. It's definately best played in a full boat, ensuring one of you will be the traitor.

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment:
An abstract with alot of potential. The bits alone make this one worth the rating; it also doen't hurt that I have an innate love of abstracts.
I have to say this to the detractors: they don't look like precious moments figures, or even snow babies. They look like Nick Park did the graphic design.

item.name: Shipyard
item.comment:
WOW. This is one major lake of choices and options.
While the end game goals are significant they do seem balanced so far. There is a seemingly unending number of ways to accumulated points and bonuses, though overall you do have to obey your end game contracts in order to win.
While there are 5 rondels, there is truely only one, though it's much more complex than any other that has come before; the selectable actions move to the "front of the line" changing their order, affecting availability, and finally serve as a timer for each round - PHEW!!
The other 4 rondels are neutral, and while you have to be mindful of them to time your primary actions from the main rondel properly, they are not something you control in a way as to thwart other players.
This is truly a game of efficiency, organization, and impeccable timing.
Looking forward to MANY more plays. The only down side to this game is time (2-3 hours, 30-40 minutes to explain the rules properly), and the 4 player cap (thank god it cannot play more :) )
More thoughts:
It's a tough call but I have to give Shipyard the nod this month. I'm a sucker for a rondel and this game has FIVE OF THEM.
They're not quite rondels in the way we think. Really it's all about the main rondel and simply timing the actions on it with the position of the neutral markers on the "sub-rondels". You can pay to move the "sub-rondies" further along, so in a way I [i]guess[/i] they are more akin to the "traditional" rondel....enough of the quotations already. The main rondel has actions that correspond to each of the other sub-rondels as well as 3 other piles (ship pieces, map pieces, train cars). After people move off of a space they chose in a previous turn this space ROTATES TO THE FRONT OF THE ROW! You cannot choose the action again (though there's a way to buy an extra action each turn to break this rule). There are a limited number of spaces on the main rondel and once the action spaces have advanced full circle it triggers the start of the next round.
Pile on the fact that there is ship building, then sailing said ships on a test run when they are completed, and even further that the ships have features on them (life preservers, lanterns, etc) printed on them plus ones you can manually add (different types of crew and passengers, masts, etc), and also also wik that the tiles that you use to create your route to sail contain triggers for some of said multipliers.
The real crux of this game is the fact that you start with 2 contracts in each of 2 groups/colors. At one point you have to choose one of each group. These contracts have conditional VP on them as well that score at game end.
It is long, tough, heavy, complex, and not easy to learn....but SO worth it if you're into heavy games and/or the rondel.

item.name: Shocking Roulette
item.comment:
It is what it is. It randomly shocks a participant. It's good for a dozen laughs. I don't se it ending too soon.
That being said, this isn't really a game.

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: The game is relatively unchanged. The new maps are wonderful, the clear base on the cube tower makes it easy to see what came out without hovering over it, and the new turn order system isn't half bad either.If you have Wallenstien this isn't a must-buy, and if you don't it is.

item.name: Shut the Box
item.comment:
When anyone plays this they just sit there and roll for an hour....I have never seen crack in wooden form before...
That's all there is to it though. Roll over and over until you shut the box. I can see how this was a drinking game as there is little reason to play it unless you want something to amuse you as you drink yourself silly.
Fun in limited doses.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
item.comment:
This is essentially Civ Revolution translated into board game form.
While I've read comments as to "why would you do that?" I would say this: There are a number of major elements that are different enough to say this is a different experience albeit heavily derivative of the source material. Further the human interaction in the game makes any comparison impossible.
There truly is the diversity of choices and strategy with just enough randomness in the system to create a new experience with every play, requiring changes in strategy every time.
Expect initial plays to be in the four hour range though I expect that to drop dramatically with experience, weighing in at 45 minutes a player at the utmost.
item.wishlistcomment:
Keeping a close eye on this. Kevin Wilson says it's primarily built on the Revolution idea. Articles detailing the game sound promising.
Will be widely available. Wait on purchase.
Update: Purchased.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game Fame and Fortune
Siena
item.comment: A turn order mechanism, much like Power Grid's, yet taken to a whole new level. Lots of chances to screw your opponents, even to the point of shutting them out of winning entirely. Fantastic production values. May be best with 4 IMHO.

item.name: Silk Road
item.comment: Alot more strategy than meets the eye in this one. Alot of tough choices. This game will definately take a few plays before we are able to start fleshing out the strategy fully.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Silverton
item.comment: A very luck driven train game. Long term strategies can be developed that can help counteract a bit of the luck, but you never know when nearby mines will come up, and the passenger routes suffer from the same "randomness...though there at least less of those. The game also has very little player interaction, and has a very sllloooww plodding pace.

item.name: Sky Tango
item.comment: I'm uncertain there's even a filler here.

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
Sometimes it's not about originality. Sometimes it's about the additions to the game when there's a reprint.
The racial and special power combinations really make this one fascinating. Further the scalable nature of the game via the different board sizes for each number of players make this game play the same regardless of how many are playing it.
What we have here is Vinci; Vinci with a pile more chrome and features, with very little extra weighing it down. Our first plays were VERY tight, and everyone involved really liked this.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
Smash Up
item.comment: It's a close cousin to Blood Bowl: The Card Game, and certainly both are like sons of Battle Line. This game has some serious synergy across the board, pays fast, and interesting things are always happening. I can't wait to see the expansions.

item.name: Smash Up: Science Fiction Double Feature
Smash Up: The Big Geeky Box
Smash Up: The Obligatory Cthulhu Set
item.comment:
I like the ideas here, but unlike Power Level these factions seem best mixed only with each other to get the best effect. It was gratifying to see that the Madness cards didn't ruin the flow or play time, and I do like the new locations.
If I had played it first, I might actually have passed on this.

item.name: Snow Tails
item.comment:
Takes everything I love about Ave Caesar and elevates it to the next level. There are some really tough decisions here, and some real risks/gambles that evoke a ton of tension.
The modular board also makes this game a total winner.

item.name: Soccer Tactics World
item.comment:
This game really does feel like soccer and with the minimum of rules. It's fairly random but there's still some strategy to how to place your pawns and some general odds estimation.
The rules aren't totally terrible but the player aid certainly serves to crystallize your understanding. I know this company had a bad reputation for bad behavior in the past but denying yourself the experience for that reason is a disservice to your gaming ID.

item.name: Sole Mio!
item.comment: Mamma Mia with a few new, and harder, twists.
