item.name: Space Alert
item.comment:
This game is just plain fun, and I think it's furthered by the fact that there are training missions that baby step you up to the full game; without which it could be a VERY frustrating experience.
Yes it's chaotic; if you're not a fan of programmed movement a-la Robo Rally stay away, or of coop games this is definitely not for you. But we played 4 times in a row and did all of the training and found we wanted to play more and more, regardless of the increasing obstacles.
There's a vast variety of things you can do, and thankfully you can freely converse and plan, and on occasion trade cards.
This one is oozing with theme, magnificent bits, and plenty of fun.
I would certainly say that this one deserves 4-5 players for best effect.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment: It's all about how fast you can think on your feet, and how efficiently you can use your time. I hope to see more player interaction in terms of trading cubes in future plays, otherwise this is just an exercise in speed and efficiency.
item.conditiontext: Update: Finally got a second set on the cheap and played with 6. I would never play with more than 6, but with the full rules and more players, this game is killer.

item.name: Spectral Rails
item.comment:
Played at Prezcon '06 at the Cafe Games booth. High quality, well tested design from this young new designer. I look forward to buying my copy when it's finally released. You owe it to yourself to try this game. It's a pick up and deliver game at it's core, with a smattering of logistics and set collection thrown in. Add a few twists I've never seen in any other game, and you've got a winner. Expect to hear ALOT about this game.
Update:
Years later its finally released, we finally play more, and remember why we liked it so much. This remains an 8, And a joy to play.

item.name: Spite & Malice
item.comment:
Basic...
The Good: It has cards?
The Bad: No real game here. Comparable strategies to Old Maid and Go Fish.

item.name: Splendor
item.comment:
A somewhat straight-forward set collection game. There are opportunities to try and foil others' plans, or protect your own, but I suspect equal player skill would lead to some games boiling down to luck of the draw.
It's fast enough, and interesting enough, for now.

item.name: Spy
item.comment:
WOW. I cannot believe Knizia designed thsi total luckfest. I felt the most minimal amount of strategy, and no tension. I have to believe this one was made with kids in mind.
The Good: Knizia's name is on the box
The Bad: A singular mechanic does not a game make. Make it a random one and you have very little game.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Spyfall
item.comment:
This one is teetering on the edge for me. I honestly enjoy playing, however, there are some minor issues:
- Being the spy and going first. It's incredibly difficult even if you are experienced with social games like this one.
- The roles are amusing, but honestly I wonder if they really add anything to the game?
- Some of the locations are a bit bizarre, and can lead to seriously uneven, or unfun, results.
So far I've liked most of my plays, but I'm not so sure everyone has. Time will tell.

item.name: Spyrium
item.comment:
When I first read about Spyrium I was interested but hesitant simply because it seemed like a novel mechanic and not much else. Color me impressed after my first play.
As the game develops you have several major avenues of vp generation and within each there are multiple combinations. This alone kept my interest, but it's the further tension and pressure of the worker placement mechanism, what I thought was the lone novel mechanic, was what really helped tie everything togethers. It's not just a vehicle but a true strategic element.
What I think I like the most is that the game is uncluttered; it's unfettered by the other layers of false strategy some games try to pile on in the name of complexity (I'm looking at you Vinhos).
I REALLY like this one. Way to go William, way to go.

item.name: Stack Market
item.comment:
There's just not alot of game here. You take all the risk with little reward. Sure you can duck out of a building after you stack it too high, but it's still a guessing game as to which building to jump to next. 1 play was enough to convince me that while I enjoyed the stacking, there's no market in my collection for this game.
The Good: [i]Minor[/i] dexterity game
The Bad: Not much more interesting here than the stacking and subsequent toppling of towers
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Star Munchkin
item.comment: I like this one best with it's combinable lasers.

item.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: The Next Generation
item.comment:
There seems to be some question as to how thematic the game is. I find the characters, in the stats and powers they have to be very much so. The random encounters deck, much like Thunderstones', also befits the theme.
The issue I have is play time. It needs to be MUCH faster otherwise even the theme cannot save it. I would also like to test the hypothesis that the first to get a ship wins; I do not believe that to be true.
Update:
While still as luck driven as Thunderstone's dungeon deck, the exploration deck NEVER screws you even when someone can benefit greatly from lucky draws. Then again, the person who explores the most will win. It's an interesting push your luck element that I enjoy.
The play time also came down to 40 minutes!
Finally, two players got ships early and one of them won. Yes you must get a ship to win. Yes you should learn to build your deck well to get one. No it's not "broken" like the forums intimate.
I'm going to keep playing it :) Rating rises to a 7.

item.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: The Next Generation The Next Phase
item.comment:
While the game is no shorter for the expansion, and certainly this is based on several plays of the expansion on it's own not incorporated with the original game, it's actually quite different in fee. and approach. There are cards that I miss from the base game but that I do not want to diminish the value of the new content. I really like the new cards in their entirety and certainly this game feel more focused on maneuvers which I thought was a weaker link in the original. The biggest change is the space deck which feels more varied, fair, and forgiving, making the game more fun overall.
If you liked the original then there is more to like here.

item.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: The Original Series
Star Trek: Catan
item.comment:
It's still your grand daddy's Catan, but with a twist of rule enhancing (not breaking) characters; and they're surprisingly balanced and useful. The theme is no more useful to this game than it would be for Monopoly, but the character twist, while not a necessity, would have been nice as a stand-alone for the original game.
That all being said: This is my go-to Settlers.

item.name: Star Wars: The Card Game
item.comment:
Easily the weakest LCG out of the gate yet. It's a good thing that FF does an amazing job of expanding their systems, developing them, and honing them to a razor sharp edge.
There's a TON of potential here, it's just a shame that more of it wasn't in the box to begin with.
Update:
More plays, rating rises to 8

item.name: Star Wars: The Card Game A Dark Time
Star Wars: The Card Game Assault on Echo Base
Star Wars: The Card Game Balance of the Force
Star Wars: The Card Game Edge of Darkness
Star Wars: The Card Game Escape from Hoth
Star Wars: The Card Game Heroes and Legends
Star Wars: The Card Game Join Us or Die
Star Wars: The Card Game Knowledge and Defense
Star Wars: The Card Game Lure of the Dark Side
Star Wars: The Card Game The Battle of Hoth
Star Wars: The Card Game The Desolation of Hoth
Star Wars: The Card Game The Search for Skywalker
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game
item.comment:
Take the Wings of War system, add easy and simple customization, squad building, keep the play time the same, and then make sure the models look even better with a Star Wars theme?? Yep, that's brilliant.
Current set:
(2 Base Sets) 5 X-Wing 5 Tie Fighter 2 Tie Advanced 3 Y-Wing (1 is Scum)
4 Tie Interceptor 3 A-Wing 1 Millenium Falcon 2 Slave one
4 B-Wing 1 HWK 2 Lambda 2 Tie Bomber
1 Transport 1 Tantive
1 E-Wing 5 Headhuner (2 are Scum) 1 Tie Defender 2 Tie Phantom
1 Decimator 1 Outrider
1 Starviper 1 Aggresor 1 M3-A
1 Tie Punisher 1 K-Wing 1 Hound's Tooth 2 Kihraxz
1 T-70 2 Tie/FO
Update:
More ships, more plays, more awesome. Upped to a 9.

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game A-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game B-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game E-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Hound's Tooth Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game HWK-290 Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Imperial Aces Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Lambda-class Shuttle Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game M3-A Interceptor Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Millennium Falcon Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Most Wanted Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Rebel Aces Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Rebel Transport Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Slave I Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Tantive IV Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game TIE Advanced Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game TIE Advanced Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game TIE Bomber Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game TIE Defender Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game TIE Fighter Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game TIE Interceptor Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game TIE Phantom Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game VT-49 Decimator Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game X-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Y-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Y-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game YT-2400 Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game Z-95 Headhunter Expansion Pack
StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment: One of the best FFG designs yet. Scales well, plays in less than 3 hours, has fantastic bits, and retains all the flavor of the PC game, while still being it's own thing.

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game Brood War Expansion
Starfarers of Catan
item.comment:
Tentative 7. I think this is ONLY a 4 player game in order to ensure there are enough resources flowing among the players.
There are also some very basic things that you can do wrong in the early game due to inexperience that can make the game MUCH longer than it should be. It's still likely pushing two hours regardless of experience however.
I enjoyed the first play with all it's wondrous bits and crazy encounters, playing with 4 (3p first game) will tell me where this one truly lies.

item.name: The Stars Are Right
item.comment:
It's a game of hand management coupled with pattern recognition and board manipulation; much like Wasabi in most respects.
It's got some chaos, but when the game ended, there was little to feel cheated about and no one thought the game overstayed it's welcome. Initial plays are wrought with downtime, as the puzzle aspect of this game will certainly generate a wealth of AP.

item.name: Starship Merchants
item.comment:
There's nothing really bad about this game. Much like Power Grid: Factory Manager you have a straight economic engine building game. It's the finer timing points and tweaks that win or lose you the game and there is enough game here that you could spend time teasing out those details. The issue I have is that there is SO much that's obvious that I lose interest and I'm ready for the game to end.
The game is also artificially close. Unless someone is playing VERY poorly your games will certainly be won by a close margin.

item.name: Steam
item.comment:
Gorgeous graphics, streamlined rules, new mechanics, a "beginner" option and more makes this every bit as good as Martin's original effort.
Update: More plays mean that this one IS as great as the original. It's every bit as nail biting and pulse pounding. I cannot wait to use the original maps with the new system.

item.name: Steampunk Rally
item.comment:
Take one part card draft, one part Galaxy Trucker building, and one part Troyes dice conversion play style, and you get Steampunk Rally.
It's a crazy mash-up and works really well. Others have said it doesn't feel like a race, but to me it does. It's not the turn-by-turn tension of being neck and neck but rather the stress of sometimes being the tortoise trying to make a desperate attempt to get ahead of the hare.
The game play can be fairly heavy and thinky, while the machine building is just plain fun. The fact that you can rearrange your machine at any time, or even dump cards at any time allows for amazing flexibility.
I'm not sure what the higher player counts will be like, or if I'm brave enough, but honestly it seems like it wouldn't add as much time as it might chaos, and even then I suspect it would still be fun.

item.name: Steel Driver
item.comment:
Reminiscent of games in the past where shares are auctioned, the monies bid are put in the bank of the railway, and in turn that money is used for the expansion of said railway.
Interesting elements include:
- Shares auctioned are limited to 1 per company per round - Winner of the share each round controls the railway - Railways must spend as much of their capital as possible - Order of play has a subtle nuance in it's rotation
The endgame, which many might see as chaotic, though the more I think about it the more predictable it could be, is that of set collection which in turn creates the final values for stocks.
There's really quite a bit going on in a game that plays with 6 in 90 minutes or less.

item.name: Stephensons Rocket
item.comment: Another fine game in the the Knizia line. It's all about collecting sets of the tokens from each city to get points that way, sets of the different symbols on the tokens to get points that way, and sets of the stocks from the individual railways. Choosing what lines to isolate and which lines to merge is a huge strategy in this game.

item.name: Stoner Fluxx
item.comment: Hilarious theme makes a simple fun game even better. Too bad there isn't more game here.

item.name: StreetSoccer
item.comment:
There's alot more to this game than meets the eye. There's the luck of the die, bit it takes a back seat on how you choose to position your players, and how well you can "milk" the action points that you gain from each roll. I haven't played a game yet that felt like luck every played a primary roll in the game.
I also have to say that the back and forth action of the game does a very good job of conveying that soccer feeling, even though I hadn't entered the game seeking that.

item.name: Stronghold
item.comment:
It's a tense, fairly fast, board game adaptation of the siege of Helm's Deep ripped straight from the LotR movies.
Lot's of variety in that you only choose one phase card for each per game. The new heroes also add nice variety for the defender.

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: Some games give you too many choices, too little time. This game does all that, and then puts a tourniquet on your resources (not to mention a penalty for needing extra money). Tough, tight game with lots of tokens. Fiddly, but solid.

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment: As Peloponnes is to Civ, Suburbia is to Sim City. It's a fast, fun, varied tableau builder that doesnt' take itself too seriously, and because of that it's a winner in my book.

item.name: Suburbia Inc
item.comment:
This is an expansion that does everything right; it adds to the play without making the game longer or more complex. Given the relative simplicity of the play I have to believe the importance of not altering the overall feel was not lost on the designer.
Indeed, if you have the base game this does nothing but add more of what you already love about it.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Bellor's Retribution Reinforcement Pack
Summoner Wars: Fallen Kingdom Faction Deck
Summoner Wars: Goodwin's Blade Reinforcement Pack
Summoner Wars: Grungor's Charge Reinforcement Pack
Summoner Wars: Guild Dwarves vs Cave Goblins
Summoner Wars: Hawk's Strike Reinforcement Pack
Summoner Wars: Jungle Elves Faction Deck
Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment: Unbelievable new armies coupled with a mostly usable storage vessel and a new board cut so it's not warped: What is not to love for a SW fan???

item.name: Summoner Wars: Mercenaries Faction Deck
item.comment: My favorite faction to date. They go after and synergize off of walls. It's great fun to make the spawn points the target rather than simply units.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Phoenix Elves vs Tundra Orcs
Summoner Wars: Phoenix Elves Second Summoner
Summoner Wars: Piclo's Magic Reinforcement Pack
Summoner Wars: Rukar's Power Reinforcements Pack
Summoner Wars: Saella's Precision Reinforcement Pack
Summoner Wars: Taliya's Spirit Reinforcement Pack
Summoner Wars: The Filth Faction Deck
item.comment: While fun, a bit more convoluted than they need to be; and then that's also the other side: they're a bit inconsistent.

item.name: Sunken City
item.comment:
In SC you can see the origins of Kramer's other fare such as Caavum and Der Schwarm.
What we have here is a light hand management/movement/set collection game. There are some interesting tactical decisions ot be made in tile and building placement as well as that of Neptune's movement.
It's certainly deserving of an occasional play but I have to believe that Der Schwarm obsoletes it for the most part in both weight and play time.
Don't get me wrong SC still has a place in my collection for a different twist for what it does but I just have the feeling that if I play DS again I might feel more strongly about my obsolescent thoughts.

item.name: Surf's Up, Dude!
item.comment:
There's quite a bit more to this game than at first meets the eye. About half way through our first play we realized what we would an should have done differently. There's quite a few decisions, and a nice amount of tension. It plays well, and fast, even with a large number of players.
Update:
I'm just not inspired to play. There are other games of equal weight and speed that keep getting chosen.

item.name: Sutter's Mill
item.comment:
I really wasn't sure what to expect and was pleasantly surprised.
Though it will take a play or two to grasp the strategy and overall flow of the game, the payoff seems worthwhile for the 60 minutes you'll play.
It's an area majorities game at it's heart, with a smattering of intuitive worker placement. It also has a distant resemblance to Thebes as the "digging for gold" is a random string that pays out an average of two, but can be as high as 4. Certainly with a good plan, though, one can net great profit with minimal attempts. You can however get equally thwarted if someone else is planning a step ahead; another good sign that it's the game that rewards good planning rather than just plain luck.
I'm not sure you can catch up if you're behind, though often times players are much closer in score than might first appear. The game's also only an hour, so that plays to it's favor.
I still wonder if it's the newness of the game or not, so it earns a tentative 7 until I play once more.

item.name: The Swarm
item.comment:
Distant cousin of Caavum with more style and flavor, not to mention much shorter play time.
Perhaps plays best with 4, time will tell.

item.name: Sylla
item.comment:
The duality of the buildings as a resource/function is really tough, and is truly the central mechanism. I don't think the central stock market mechanism is as predictable or manageable as it is in Ys, but this game seems to be more about volume than value.
It's worth playing, and even owning, but I think for many it will be a straight split between love and hate.

item.name: Tahuantinsuyu
item.comment: I'm not a big fan of crayon line drawing games but this one only uses that lightly. Territory control here makes it nice.

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment:
There's either alot more going on than I'm seeing, or it's just random. More plays needed to see if this game sinks or floats.
Update: It's definately much more deep than it first appears. Rating went up to a 8.

item.name: Take Stock
item.comment:
A solid hand management and "stock market" game. Reminds me very much of Union Pacific if it were a card game. I know there has been alot said about the randomness in this game, but one has to give up cards to set off the random events, which means they have less to use to alter their own stick prices and even less to put out into play in front of them.
I like the tension that lies in this game. The game has been said to be too long, but that's only with people who like to over think a simple game like this.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment:
Totally a non-game, and I like it that way.
It's worth the occasional play and certainly not with more than 4 players.
It need to be played quickly and totally non seriously for best effect.
Which-way gaming at it's best never (hopefully) to be duplicated.

item.name: Talisman (third edition)
item.comment:
I love the idea and theme...playing makes me hate it tho. Sold this game for more than I paid....that's the only redeeming quality of it.
The Good: Fantasy theme, character building, and feeling like you are playing "against the game".
The Bad: Random elements that strip everything you have worked for can put you out of the game completely. Way too long for what I derive from it.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: This one will definitly take more plays to ferret out the strategy. I'm actually worried that there isn't very much here. It's a light, fast-paced game, and has some nice elements in that you can create situations for yourself to get out multiple pieces. The luck of the draw seems mitigated by the fact that there is such a wide variety of terrain, and the fact that you can build upwards (which also allows you to play multiple pieces more predictably).The one thing that got me with this one is that there doesn't seem to be much of a way to affect other players' progress, and the game can end quite abruptly. At the end of our first game I felt like That's It?!?".
item.conditiontext: Update: Increased to a 7. I'm still unsure how many viable strategies there are in the game, but recent plays with more experienced players showed me that there is a true game here, and that there is a fair amount of tension when playing it. The game can be competitive, and brutal. More plays will make this rise a notch more, or make it fall off forever.

item.name: Tannhuser
item.comment: Will either become exponentially better with expansions, or be destined to need house rules to make this game better.
item.conditiontext: Like New: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Tanz der Hornochsen!
item.comment: A very nice mix of 6 Nimmt! and Hornochsen that melds into a game with far less luck and a ton more fun. There is alot more strategy here than meets the eye. While the game can get much more random when you have more than 5 or 6 players, it's still tons of fun.

item.name: Telestrations
item.comment:
It's the telephone game crossed with pictionary, and a TON of fun if you've got the right group.
Thankfully I do, and nothing is a laugh riot like "artificial insemination".

item.name: Tempus
item.comment: Played twice at Prezcon '06, and taught to me by the indominable Morgan Dontanville. Tight gameplay that builds increasing tension over each round of the game. Well balanced action cards insure none are completely useless. It's a bit abstract, but I like that in a game. This will be a surefire win for Cafe Games....if they can ever get it off the presses. Slated for May '06 when I played it.

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment: While my initial rating for this was an 8 it has now risen to a 9 after 3 plays. I've tried 3 races and seen most of the others played and I keep seeing not just variety in the races but variety in the flow and play of the game between sessions. I enjoy this game with any number simply because the lack of power from a lack of neighbors adds another challenge to the game as much as a crowded board does. 5p is a bit long for my tastes but I am still willing to play that way for an occasional session.

item.name: Terra Mystica: Fire & Ice
item.comment: Rebalanced map, new races, and more. The only thing I don't love is the broken-ass variable races. :)

item.name: Terra Prime
item.comment:
Some random elements yet with avenues to victory that rely on planning more than luck.
It's fast even with 5, and has some really adrenaline fueled moments.
It remains to be seen if it will hold up under continued plays.
Update: Repeated plays have shown that this game just starts getting good when it comes to an end. Certain avenues of victory seem only favorable to those who can start them first.
I'm really disappointed and of to the trade pile it goes.

item.name: Terror in Meeple City
item.comment: While the game is nothing amazing, played quickly it's quite a bit of fun. The mechanics and theme marry perfectly in a monster throw down that you should at least try once if you have the slightest interest.

item.name: Texas Roll'Em
item.comment:
Sorry, this one ruins the classic formula for me.
The Good: Take the Perudo/Bluff formula...
The Bad: ...then add more elements that ruin the simplicity and elegance.

item.name: That's Life!
item.comment: It is a roll and move game, but the luck is heavily mitigated by the use of the guards. After 4 plays I can say that the game plays at a good speed, with a moderate play time. I will say that while playing with 6 is fun, I have to believe that this one is best with 4.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: I love the "digging" mechanisms found in the combination of tile draw and "wheel". It's a unique combo that offers many layers of strategy, and serves up alot of tension. The only down side being that the randomness of the digging can be hit or miss; though this aspect is exactly why many love it, and often why I loathe it.

item.name: This Town Ain't Big Enough for the 2-4 of Us
Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment:
Finally played the FULL game, which is the way everyone should experience this game the first time. We called it with 1/3 of the 3rd deck left, as it was clear who would win.
I've played Civ and Advanced Civ before, and this definitely fits the bill as a card version of those, but I feel that unless you play it enough to know the game, the play time doesn't actually come in at any less than those games. It's supposed to be shorter, and with experience I'm certain it is.
The question is, will I want to play this again, or even frequently?
Update:
Another play, and soon to see even more. It's been a long time coming getting it to the table, but since we've now got a following for it in our club I have no doubt that the plays for this one will rise.

item.name: Through the Desert
item.comment: I love Knizia and abstract strategy....and pastel camels ...As you build chains of camels and make connections to the oases for points, you struggle to keep majority in the different colors. You also try to corner off some landscape for some extra points. This is a very nice abstract, and can easily win over those who dislike abstracts.

item.name: Thunderstone
item.comment:
Certainly not hiding it's Dominion influenced play, nor it's D&D roots, Thunderstone is VERY good. It's also very easy on the eyes.
Anyone not wanting to play a more richly themed more objective based Dominion with a 60 minute play time stay away.
Gameplay is about recognizing what monsters there are, what tools you have available and what combination will work best to defeat them. It's familiar but not.
I'm truly looking forward to more plays and any expansions this will have.
Update:
Additional expansions slow this game down to a crawl making it a shadow of what the base game promised.
Wrath of the Elements and the first two promo packs included together in the Wrath of the Elements box.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment:
Mebbe we missed something when we played his with 4, but the game feels neither original, nor does it feel very interactive. I know many relate it to Ticket, but while they might be kissing cousins, they are entirely different games.
This one will need to have more plays before we decide it's worth.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment:
This one is gonna take a lot more plays to truly start to grasp the depth of the strategy to be found. This is a very fine trick taking game. If you haven't had the opportunity you definitely should give it a try.
Update: A very good trick taker. One of my favorites.
After tons of plays later, this is not only the best trick taking game there is, but it makes you long to play it while you play others like it. It still needs 4 players, so there are other games I reach for with 3 or 5, but there are no other 3- player experiences that compare.
Update:
Played again. Realized I hadn't rated it a ten, yet it is. ;)

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: Nothing but fun. I hate it when my wife (who knows me far too well for my own good in this game) intentionally screws my connections.
item.conditiontext:
Update:
The gameplay, and the sometimes eteral wait for the one card you need have started to wear thin. I have played so many games since these, that the lack of control has begun to irk me.
It's stil a ten as a family or gateway game though.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 Team Asia & Legendary Asia
Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 3 The Heart of Africa
item.comment: It took a couple of plays, but I believe I like what the terrain cards add to the game. It's not a beginner map to be sure, and thankfully the secondary fuction added for wilds keeps the game from bogging down.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: Every bit as good as the original, with a few new twists. I also like the cleaner, smaller route map. The game seems to stay closer.
item.conditiontext:
Update:
Over time the forced competition of this edition has begun to detract from the replayability. I enjoy the new ideas for what they are, and this game is as good as the original, but the system is beginning to wear thin.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Mrklin
item.comment:
I love the passengers....I love the streamlined board.....I even love the new ticket system and the elimination of the longest route for most tickets completed; but for some reason I feel like the +4 Locos spoil the game, at least with 3 players.
What beautiful production values.
Update:
Much better with more than 3 players. Will have to try 3 again and see if strategy was the flaw.
Update:
No flaws here. It's just a deeper version of ticket that take more learning to understand the nuances of the map.
item.conditiontext:
Update:
This one takes itself way too seriously, and tries to add strategic elements that just don't work as well when you already have a game with limited control.
Good as the original, but not great.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Mystery Train Expansion
item.comment: Doesn't really add anything to the game.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment: The best Ticket in a long time, especially for 2-3.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Switzerland
item.comment: This might be my favorite version of the game yet. There are a ton of different options due to the new type of tickets. Having a large number of tunnels, and being able to pick up multiple face up wilds are interesting twists as well.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Card Game
item.comment:
It's light, it's fast, and it's a nicely distilled version of the board game. It's worth it cause it's so fast, and if you like the original then I firmly belive you will enjoy this one.
Update: Doesn't hold up under repeated plays. Seems to be best with 3, and almost unplayable with 4.
item.conditiontext: Gently Used: For Trade or Best Cash Offer

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Dice Expansion
item.comment: Makes a game that has a wealth of randomness even more random. These dice are a total chaos fest and make the game longer.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: Reiner is one helluva designer. That being said, this game is one of the most streamlined designs ever conceived. Screwed planning and the ability to swap your tiles for an action nearly eliminates luck as a factor.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment:
I just can't like this game as much as I always hoped I would.
Invested in a copy recently as I wanted the entire mask trilogy. I'm hoping my tastes have evolved into seeing how good this game realy is.
Update:
Years later I play again and finally see some good in Tikal. It's still my least favorite of the series, and the annoyance that is "player to your left flips a tile with tokens, everyone takes them before you can get any" puts a cramp in my enjoyment.
I also think the game is VERY dependent upon the skill of the players and how well they place the tiles.

item.name: Tikal II: The Lost Temple
item.comment:
Yet another mistake in naming/branding a game with a previous one by the same designer.
FF made this mistake, and while I think the game he made was fine, it's just not related very closely to it's predecessor.
K & K have done the same here and made a game that's only marginally related.
No action points. No worker placement. No area majority.
The similarity lies in the traversing of boundaries. In Tikal it was an action point cost. You could make the cost more prohibitive in the orientation of the hexes when you place them. In T2 it's about set collection to allow yourself to cross the boundaries. You can still orient tiles to make them more prohibitive but only slightly so.
So what we end up with is a much more tactical game that falls into the light-medium area of gaming. There is still the min-maxing but in much simpler form. On the up side the AP is really kept to a minimum and the game plays much faster overall.
I think that group-think has grabbed most of the early adopters and players who, like with Factory Manager before it, were lead to the wrong assumption about T2's game play. There's a quality game here that I'm willing to play again; indeed much more than games like Stone Age, Kingsburg, or even Fresco.
This is obviously meant to bring a mere slice of the flavor that was Tikal while delivering something else altogether different. There's really not much out there like it either IMHO.
One thing is for sure, and sadly has been for a while: one of my favorite designers, Wolfgang Kramer, is just not designing game for the more hardcore crowd any more. Like Knizia before him, the stuff that made him legend is not only his legacy, but the games we should turn to rather than anything newer released by him.

item.name: Times Square
item.comment: WOW! Was I ever surprised with this game. I thought it would be a decent romp for two players, but it turned out to be a really fin hand management game! I never realized the playing pieces had special abilities which drastically effects gameplay (before I read the rules that is). Luck if the draw can swing things the wrong direction sometimes, but strategy and good choices still ruled the day.

item.name: Tinners' Trail
item.comment:
It's a game of minor gambles; however the risks can be mitigated.
If you invest wider, control your spending, and take care with your turn order there's little that luck has to do with here.
I really like:
- When you mine future mining costs rise - Adits and trains give motivation for consolidated building and the chance for synergy. - The bonuses of the developments still apply when an area is "explored"
Play is brisk thanks to the time track, which is a mini-Neuland mechanism :)
Another play:
The random market is evil and the tougher/more favorable the market, the more ferocious the bidding is. The wilder the swings the more fun this game can be.
I do have concerns that there is a high potential for draws given the way external investments are proportioned.

item.name: Tiny Epic Kingdoms
item.comment:
I'm not sure what to make of this game. Just as everything gets going, and competitive, the game is over. I have a strange feeling there will be later variations on this design that vastly improve upon the concept.
- When you finally unlock certain racial abilities they feel like too little too late
- Some of the races aren't very good
- This game feels like more of a race than 4x.
I do like it, and will play it at least a few more times, but I'm losing interest rapidly.

item.name: Tobago
item.comment:
Don't be fooled into thinking this is deduction; it's not. There are 4 piles to play into. The clue cards are rules. Once a few rules are in place you can place the cubes from a particular pile out on the board adhering to the rules as a visual aid.
Your real goal is to steer the last cube/cubes toward your area to you can score the color and get first choice on treasures.
There are some real decisions to be made here, though the luck element still leaves a good deal of guess work. This should be played at a brisk pace for best results.
It currently sits on the bubble to see how it fares after repeated plays.

item.name: Tonga Bonga
item.comment:
The Dorra game that I never gave consideration to is now in my top 3 favorite games by this designer.
It looks like a family game, but there are layers of strategy underneath the surface that are easy to miss at first glance.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: The cards are random, but the point based action system really makes you think and work for your points. Such a tiny board forces players to fight for them.

item.name: Tournay
item.comment: An adequate twist on the system that made Troyes so good. You're tableau building and don't have to worry about die luck, so this has a place in my collection for occasional play.

item.name: Tower of Babel
item.comment: It's a basic majorities game with action cards you can earn for good measure. There are some very nice balancing mechanisms built in....and there is very little luck involved.

item.name: Traders of Osaka
item.comment: A small game with a lot going on. It's set collection, plus hand management, and just a dash of luck. I certainly like the utility of the reservation token.

item.name: Trains
item.comment:
As long as the variability remains high I forsee a bright future and a rising rating.
While it's not the pick up and deliver game that I had hoped it might be, it's an equally good route builder. I like the ability to offensively use stations to sap opponents liquid cash. There's a real challenge to stay as lean and mean with your deck building too.
This will see regular play for some time to come.

item.name: Trains: Map Pack 1 Germany/Northeastern USA
item.comment: Personally I think the layout of these boards is superior to the base game in every way. There seems to be more "good" starting positions, and the competition feels better and closer.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment:
I like it...but darn if it isnt super random...god I HATE this game. Sold this turd to make money for games that are worth the cardboard they are printed on.
The Good: It has a good idea as a basic premise and the game makes sense....
The Bad: ...until you realize the random destinations can totally utterly hose you and give the game to an opponent or worse than you are forced to help another player, who already has the upper hand, gain an even larger advantage.

item.name: Tribune: Primus Inter Pares
item.comment:
I'm thinking the rating on this one will rise.
It's most certainly an overlooked gem from Essen '07.
While it's just worker placement, hand management, and majorities, the way each area implements the collection of these objects gives such wide variety, not to mention the multiple ways to collect points. There seems no way to be shut out.
There's just something about the swift flow of the game, faction benefits, and not to mention the short playtime that really make this one come together.

item.name: Troyes
item.comment:
For a game with piles of dice, random events, and random action spaces there is sure a ton of control in this game.
The key is that no player is ever locked out of being able to use a given action space. There's even the ability to "flip" dice to their opposite face, reroll dice, or action spaces to convert the color of dice.
In all quite a fine game that I hope to own some day.

item.name: Trump, Tricks, Game!
item.comment:
While it will take a few more plays to ferret out the strategies, I did see alot of the potentials that were inherent to the game. I do feel like this game could be rated higher, but in comparison to all the other great trick taking games that I have, this one still falls into the "neat" category. It'll see occasional plays, but not as often as others.
Update: Repeat plays downgrade this one to a "meh".

item.name: Tumblin-Dice
item.comment:
A winner.
Totally random score wise, though with "skilled" tosses you can score consistently, or cause others not to, and likely do consistently well.
So fast that you can play it several times in a row.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment: I TOTALLY disagree with the ISC debaucle. That being said, I do believe that the errata, faq, and options recently released made a good game approach even closer to greatness.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition): Shards of the Throne
Twilight Struggle
item.comment: So far, so good with one play of this one. It definately has begun to change my mind about what war games are becoming, and makes me want to delve deeper into the card driven war game world.

item.name: Tycoon
item.comment:
A VERY solid Kramer game. Rating may rise from a 7 with further play, as there are alot of nice twists, yet the randomness of the tickets can force you into spending more than you planned, thereby weakening the game a tad.
Update: This rose to a 9, then back to an 8 as El Capitain trumps it in every way.
item.conditiontext: Update: More plays brings this up 2 points to a 9. Now I need to play El Capitain.

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment: It's like Checkers for grown-ups. You spend the game kinging yourself over and over. I also like the way the game accelerates with the increase in attrition. It's fast, thinky, and devious.

item.name: Ubongo
item.comment: One part dexterity game, one part puzzle. Add the timer and the frantic pace of this game adds a nice dose of tension. Everyone scrambling for their pieces (as we played by the rules which state you take your pieces after the timer has been turned) makes it feel a tad like Twister :p

item.name: Um Reifenbreite
item.comment: WOW, what a sleek little racing game. So simple, and it doesn't feel like it takes as long as it does. There are so many options for the races. I wish it played more than 4, but I dunno hoe it could.

item.name: Union Pacific
item.comment: Fantastic game in the vein of Aquire. There is tension surrounding your every decision.

item.name: UNO
item.comment:
It's UNO. I will leave this one in the past and not sully it's good memories.
The Good: Childhood memories
The Bad: People who still suggest I play this game with them.

item.name: Up the Creek
item.comment: This one is a set collecting, semi-take-that card game. I think that it's just ok. We got it on the cheap, so no harm, no foul.

item.name: Urban Sprawl
item.comment:
US is a game of focusing on building in the most valuable areas in order to reap the greatest money and points. You have to be careful to focus not only on single blocks but in entire rows for majorities. The major complication is that of the zoning rules. Building in such a manner as to facilitate not only early game but also late game plays is important otherwise you will not be able to adapt. All of this is also a key in gaining control of the different roles in the game.
At first blush the game seem VERY random yet there is a subtle balance in the events over the entirety of the game. I have already seen, and predict in the future of this game, that most will play once and be completely turned off. It's a shame that Mr. Jensen's games require multiple plays, more so than almost any other designs that I have tried, in order to begin understanding the play, the "story arc" of the game, and indeed how to play competitively.
With two plays under our belt, our last game being VERY close and back and forth on all players parts, we look forward to more and I foresee the rating rising.

item.name: Valdora
item.comment:
Tentative rating after one play with 5.
It's pickup and deliver with random chances at the orders you fulfill and the equipment available to you.
I will say this; the more players the more chaos. I saw another play with 3 that was much closer and much more strategic.
It's what I was expecting from this game, and had feared with 5 players. I'm thinking this one caps out with 4.

item.name: Vasco da Gama
item.comment:
It's a worker placement game, know that up front.
The real twist is managing the timing of your actions combined with smart use of the character powers and perhaps a little luck.
Really a solid mix of gather, manage, and place. The real key is the timing of the actions as well as clever placement of your ships in the exploration section.
Solid game.

item.name: Vegas Showdown
item.comment:
Better upon playing with 4 instead of 3. 4 might just be the magic number for this one, as it has just enough going on.
Update: Downgraded to a 6. It's just "meh". It shares the aspects of so many "better" games I love. This is just a family version of those, and serves it purpose, but definitely not my first choice.

item.name: Vikings
item.comment:
What we have here is a bit of hand management, set collection, and something quite new.
There's a smattering of luck and a smattering of planning.
Overall I like it, but it will take more plays to see if it's as good as it seems at first.
I also haven't tried the advanced/variant version, which will either add a layer of depth, or a layer of unwelcome chaos.

item.name: Village
item.comment:
While I cannot think of any specific examples at the time I write this, Village is one of a newer breed of games that offers a fair variety of scoring possibilities, with a fair number of routes to obtain each, the trick is that all of them are equal opportunity. What's more is that because all things are fairly equal and it's by the narrow margin of points here or there that you will win.
You have to keep track of the big picture, not only that but the fact that you have to time the use of your workers as they age out in order, this latter bit being the most interesting and tension inducing. I quite enjoyed what this package had to offer. It does fill a niche in my collection, which means that it will see more play and stick around for some time to come.

item.name: Village Inn
item.comment: Takes the game and gives you even more choices and variety and still retains the balance. Modular expansions like this are always the best.

item.name: Village Port
item.comment: This expansion swaps out a portion of the board to add pick up and deliver to the game. WOW. Never imagined that would be possible. The best part is that it's still balanced! I love the expansions for this game.

item.name: Vinhos
item.comment:
This game is CONVOLUTED. It's as though they created the game and then tried to find ways to make things more difficult, primarily by adding more steps to very simple goals. That means there are more rules governing play and more times you'll be referencing the rules to ensure you're playing right.
I'm not sure I want to play this again. I already own Pret A Porter which does something similar without all the chaff. It also plays faster (not incredibly so), so I think Vinhos is on it's way out.

item.name: The Walking Dead: The Board Game
item.comment:
The only thing that comes remotely close to saving this game for me is the theme. While I found the character powers interesting the rest of the game isn't all that great. The randomness of events really hurts some players while helping others; it especially helps those who get followers early.
I did think the Tron Light-Cycle-like streams of zombies you leave behind you was an interesting, and lightly strategic, concept however there's no benefit or real penalty to killing zombies.
One last warning: the goal of the game is to scout 3 locations and while gettting your first two seems to come relatively swiftly the last one drags the game out, and that's not even due to the influence of players on one another!

item.name: Wallenstein (first edition)
item.comment: Another great game of tight play and agonizing decisions.....god damn that cube tower can be cruel though!

item.name: Walnut Grove
item.comment: While it's not quite the predescribed Carcassonne + Agricola there are some design and game play cue derived directly from those games. Overall it's very light, fast, easy to get into, and quite competitive. Even when the tiles are "not in your favor" you can utilize the abundance of a resource you don't need in other ways. Turn order is also surprisingly important adding some significant tension to an otherwise solitaire game.

item.name: War of the Ring (first edition)
item.comment: I can't quite understand why the different nations pieces weren't color-coded to match their borders (like many other games - Axis and Allies did this 20 YEARS AGO!) I also find it hard to distinguish some features and locations when the board gets crowded. On the plus side, this game is a LOTR fan's dream (if you dig deep strategy, or sometimes even if you don't) and even though there is a random nature given to it by the dice, the abilities the characters and minions add and the cards give make the game level out in terms of luck. What would a war game be without some luck in it? It is obviously not made for casual gamers, Grognards (for the most part), or perhaps even Spielfreaks; However, for those who seek a moderate war game with a fantastic theme and have the patience to play a 2-3 hour game, none will be disappointed. I like this game alot and look forward to many future plays.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment:
WOW! This is the first LCG/CCG in quite some time that was so simple yet still has layers of interaction. It's simply the best one I've played since CoC, and interestingly enough from the same designer.
More big praises:
- Beautiful Artwork, and I mean STUNNING - Quality multi-player - Cards are used as resources and still function normally rather than sacrifice or choose what they are used for; something new in this genre.
I can only see this one getting better.
Update:
Many Battle Packs, 2 large box expansions and plenty of deck building later and I still love this game as much as ever. Great fun, great design, and especially in the last large expansion, great new ideas and strategies to try out.
item.conditiontext: Have 2 base sets, 3 of the first 6 BP's, 3 Assaults, and one of everything else.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion The Eclipse of Hope
Warhammer: Invasion Battle for the Old World
Warhammer: Invasion Glory of Days Past
Warhammer: Invasion March of the Damned
Warhammer: Invasion Path of the Zealot
Warhammer: Invasion Realm of the Phoenix King
Warhammer: Invasion Redemption of a Mage
Warhammer: Invasion Shield of the Gods
Warhammer: Invasion Signs in the Stars
Warhammer: Invasion The Burning of Derricksburg
Warhammer: Invasion The Fall of Karak Grimaz
Warhammer: Invasion The Twin Tailed Comet
Warhammer: Invasion Vessel of the Winds
Wasabi!
item.comment:
Dripping with theme, incredible amounts of chrome, and interesting game play leave this one at 7. It's still too random to be better, but certainly worth occasional table time.
Update:
This game is about pattern recognition and tile placement. I think playing with a full compliment is chaos, but the game is so fast and flavorful it doesn't really matter.

item.name: Way Out West
item.comment:
The game play:
Some old school majorities and synergy. You can see this is an obvious early "Martin Wallace does something not involving trains". It has potential, and I think if he ever revised it and smoothed out the rough edges (bad comparison but think Brass to Age of Industry) that it would be possible to make a game I'd want to play here.
The Combat:
This game requires and encourages combat. Combat is simply roll offs of D6's. The results of this are equal parts encouraging and distressing.
I wouldn't seek it out. Perhaps it needs another play but with so much good Wallace out there I'm not sure that I would want to.

item.name: Web of Power
item.comment: Superior rules-wise and map-wise to it's descendant, China. I was never all that taken with China but this one I like very much. It's one of the original so-called "super-fillers". It's filled with tension and just the right amount of tactics. It's fairly random, but plays so quickly I cannot care.

item.name: WildLife
item.comment: The more players the better this game gets. You have to be a bit cut-throat though. You have to work in your pieces to gain majorities for the best points, but the action cards are the nasty part of the game. The longer you can keep them the better you can do.

item.name: Winds Of Plunder
item.comment:
This seems like an attempt to improve on Pirate's Cove. For the most part I would say it's successful, yet still not all that great a game. Perhaps it's because I played this game now, in 2012, not back in 2007 when it was released. It's not a design that has aged very well.
I find the blind bidding, especially late game, becomes predictable and almost a joke. The best move in the game is to move then gust of wind, allowing you to usually move and score twice in a round. This coupled with scoring influence in the zones of play and trasure maps makes WoP shallow and generally un-fun. The only redeeming quality is it is easy to learn and it is short.

item.name: Wings of War: Famous Aces
item.comment:
A nice fast-paced programmed move game that causes a veritable riot whenever it's played; now all I need are the minis.
Update: More expansions and minis make this one a 9.

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment:
I enjoy "betting on the ponies". While the die rolling to move the horses makes the game 70% luck, threre is the idea of screwing with your oponents by making a worse movement decision for a horse they are betting on.
The game suggests 3 rounds, but if people get behind, there sems to be no way for them to catch up in some cases.

item.name: Winter
item.comment:
Played with New Era:
I LOVE the new cards. There are some scoring cards that really benefit from the longer game that this expansion creates and to that end there are an ennumerable number of ways to get points.
The new Winter board is a nice touch. The new leaders are a welcome change and having coop and conquest instants stripped out of the deck means almost always drafting more meaningful cards while still having a chance to splash them in.
The supply die is interesting and actually speeds up the game start a bit.
The game is longer, that's to be sure, but if you liked the system I don't think you'll mind.

item.name: Witch of Salem
item.comment: An inoffensive completely random cooperative game with a light Cthulhu theme. It was fast and my group likes it so while I'm not likely to ask for it I'm also unlikely to refuse to play. There are decisions to be made but if you're doing well there comes a point where you almost know you have won.

item.name: Witch's Brew
item.comment:
Based on one play with five. There's a lot of chaos here, but quite a bit of strategy. It's probably in the same realm of the second half of For Sale when it comes to the level of luck and screwage there can be, however there's a glimmer of depth here that more plays might reveal.
Update:
After dozens of plays I think this one is best with 4, however the overall experience is as I had originally observed; it is one part chaos, one part strategy. It certainly helps knowing the other players so as you can divine some knowledge of their possible next moves.
Solid 7. Oh, and I will also say the game is a bit long with 5 as this one is a "the faster the better" kind of game.

item.name: Wiz-War (eighth edition)
item.comment:
Combos, misdirection, and deceit! Our group had a seriously good time and played twice, back to back. Both games were entirely different. Managing your hand and recognizing the opportunities you have with what cards you were dealt is important to your success.
We've played by the new rules but in time we'll be interested in changing things back to old school, or a combination of both.

item.name: Wizard
item.comment: Nice variant on Oh hell and Spades.

item.name: Wok Star
item.comment:
I'm blown away by this game for two reasons:
- The theme works. When you're screaming for different ingredients or shouting out the current order it DEFINITELY feels like a short order kitchen.
- Unlike most fully coop games it's vital for each player to fully control the generation of the ingredients in front of them as well as spend ingredients for and collect completed orders efficiently. It's all hands on deck.
This game takes such serious focus to play well I was mentally fatigued as much as most heavy games I play, and I guess that's a certain weight of the game in and of itself.
There are multiple approaches at the start of the game, important and varied decisions on buying mid game, and it all culminates in what you hope will be success in the final round, but initial plays have shown that the best laid plans are not always fruitful.
What a great game. It's a shame that it's among so many games shelved by the Filosofia buy out.

item.name: World Without End
item.comment:
In many ways a reverse version of Pillars of the Earth; instead of worker placement to activate abilities and cards you use a hand of cards to gain tokens, resources, and points.
This game has a tight design and some clever elements. The upkeep at th end of each era is a source of major tension. I also like the sheer variety of ways to achieve vp's.
Finally, though it's a totally randomizing element, the events keep things constantly changing, evolving, and keep you off step.
I'm not sure I could ever play Pillars again.

item.name: YINSH
item.comment: Brilliant! Othello + Checkers = FUN

item.name: Ys
item.comment:
Nice semi blind bidding game. Also has a nice duality with having the main board and the marketplace to play into.
Can't wait to have the expansion so this will see more play.
UPDATE:
After a play with the expansion (with 5 players): This is one of the best games I own, even better with the expansion. I'm sorry I never made the 5th set of pieces myself.

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment:
More plays might make this one sink, but I don't think so. It's aazing how the mechanics in this game almost eliminate the luck of the dice, and their effect on the gameplay.
Update:
A good mix fo luck and strategy just might make this game Spiel Des Jahres.
item.conditiontext:
Update:
Play number 4 solidifies this as one of the best I own. Everyone who has played has liked or loved it, and wanted to play again. I think this will definitely be game of the year.

item.name: ZRTZ
item.comment: One of the most unique games I have ever played. High production values here.

item.name: Zing!
item.comment: It's waaay too counterintuative to try and take a trick as it can often give you a penalty token (Zing!)

item.name: Zombie Dice
item.comment:
A press your luck game in the same vein as Toss Up, but offers more statistically based decisions and strategy as well as a blisteringly fast play time.
Roll 3 blindly drawn dice. Keep brains and shotgun blasts. Stop and score your brains, keep going and refill your hand to 3 dice (blind draw). You reuse footprints as part of your 3, so the number you refresh to is variable. Get 3 shotgun blasts and lose that rounds' progress.
The best thing is that of the 13 dice 6 are green (2 footprint, 3 brain, one shotty), 4 are yellow (2 footprint, 2 brain, 2 shotty) and 3 are red (2 footprint, 1 brain, 3 shotty), so now you see the statistical chances for your rolls as well as your blind draws. It's really a neat system.
Neat-O theme as well.

item.name: Zombies!!!
item.comment:
Can drag on a bit.
The Good: Zombies and killing zombies.
The Bad: Without the variant movement takes far too long, especially given better choices that are on the market in the past few years.
Update:
In spirit it will always be a 10.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment:
Add 3 more layers of depth and strategy without adding complexity and you get Zooloretto.
I think some might feel fiddling with the original formula is a travesty, but i'm glad this idea was revisited properly. It could almost be it's own new game.

item.name: Zooloretto XXL
item.comment: Duplicate copy given away to someone who loves the game.
